别小瞧那本包罗万象的《罗杰词典》。这本书很容易让人捧腹大笑。比如，查一下“恶棍”（villain），你就会看到琳琅满目的恶棍词汇，只有词典编纂者才能从几个世纪的罪恶、奸诈、堕落、奸诈、挥霍、脆弱、明目张胆、臭名昭著、不道德、腐败、邪恶、不当行为、背叛和罪孽中挖掘出来。你会发现流氓和乌合之众、恶棍和作恶者、无赖和流氓、流氓和恶棍、无赖和骗子、恶棍和无赖、荡妇和妖妇。你会发现各种形容词（比如“肮脏的”、“邪恶的”、“魔鬼般的”、“魔鬼般的”），以及描述作恶者如何作恶的副词和动词，还有指向其他罪恶和贪婪领域的交叉引用。不过，要说最能帮你回忆起这些词语的朋友，罗杰词典绝对是最佳选择。它能帮你省去在大脑——那片充斥着过多词汇的沟壑——里翻找的时间，让你不必费力地寻找那些明明就在嘴边却毫无用处的词语。词典之于作家，正如韵律词典之于词曲作家——提醒你所有可用的选择——你应该心怀感激地使用它。如果你找到了“scalawag”（无赖）和“scapegrace”（逃犯）这两个词，想知道它们之间的区别，那就去查词典吧。

Also bear in mind, when you’re choosing words and stringing them together, how they sound. This may seem absurd: readers read with their eyes. But in fact they hear what they are reading far more than you realize. Therefore such matters as rhythm and alliteration are vital to every sentence. A typical example—maybe not the best, but undeniably the nearest—is the preceding paragraph. Obviously I enjoyed making a certain arrangement of my ruffians and riffraff, my hooligans and hoodlums, and my readers enjoyed it too—far more than if I had provided a mere list. They enjoyed not only the arrangement but the effort to entertain them. They weren’t enjoying it, however, with their eyes. They were hearing the words in their inner ear.

此外，在选择词语并将它们串联起来时，也要记住它们的音韵。这听起来或许有些荒谬：读者是用眼睛阅读的。但事实上，他们聆听阅读内容的程度远超你的想象。因此，节奏和头韵等要素对每个句子都至关重要。一个典型的例子——或许并非最佳，但无疑是最贴切的——就是上一段。显然，我乐于将我的流氓恶棍、乌合之众、暴徒和流氓团伙进行某种特定的排列组合，我的读者也同样乐在其中——远胜于我仅仅罗列一个清单。他们不仅欣赏这种排列组合，也欣赏我为他们带来的娱乐。然而，他们并非用眼睛欣赏，而是用他们的“内耳”聆听这些文字。

E. B. White makes the case cogently in The Elements of Style , a book every writer should read once a year, when he suggests trying to rearrange any phrase that has survived for a century or two, such as Thomas Paine’s “These are the times that try men’s souls”:

E·B·怀特在《风格的要素》一书中提出了一个令人信服的观点，这本书每个作家都应该每年读一遍。他建议尝试重新排列任何流传了一两个世纪的短语，例如托马斯·潘恩的“这是考验人们灵魂的时代”：

Times like these try men’s souls.

这样的时刻考验着人们的灵魂。

How trying it is to live in these times!

生活在如今这个时代真是太难了！

These are trying times for men’s souls.

这是考验男人心灵的时代。

Soulwise, these are trying times.

从灵魂层面来说，这是一段艰难的时期。

Paine’s phrase is like poetry and the other four are like oatmeal—which is the divine mystery of the creative process. Good writers of prose must be part poet, always listening to what they write. E. B. White is one of my favorite stylists because I’m conscious of being with a man who cares about the cadences and sonorities of the language. I relish (in my ear) the pattern his words make as they fall into a sentence. I try to surmise how in rewriting the sentence he reassembled it to end with a phrase that will momentarily linger, or how he chose one word over another because he was after a certain emotional weight. It’s the difference between, say, “serene” and “tranquil”—one so soft, the other strangely disturbing because of the unusual n and q .

潘恩的短语如同诗歌，而其他四个短语则如同燕麦粥——这正是创作过程中的神圣奥秘。优秀的散文作家必须具备诗人的特质，时刻聆听自己笔下的文字。E·B·怀特是我最喜欢的文体家之一，因为我能感受到他是一位如此注重语言韵律和音韵的人。我细细品味他文字的韵律，感受它们如何构成句子。我试图揣摩他是如何重写句子，最终以一个令人回味无穷的短语结尾，或者他如何选择某个词而非另一个词，因为他想要表达某种特定的情感分量。这就像“serene”（宁静的）和“tranquil”（安详的）之间的区别——前者如此柔和，后者却因为不寻常的n和q而显得怪异而令人不安。

Such considerations of sound and rhythm should go into everything you write. If all your sentences move at the same plodding gait, which even you recognize as deadly but don’t know how to cure, read them aloud. (I write entirely by ear and read everything aloud before letting it go out into the world.) You’ll begin to hear where the trouble lies. See if you can gain variety by reversing the order of a sentence, or by substituting a word that has freshness or oddity, or by altering the length of your sentences so they don’t all sound as if they came out of the same machine. An occasional short sentence can carry a tremendous punch. It stays in the reader’s ear.

你应该在写作的每一个环节都考虑到声音和节奏。如果你的所有句子都像行云流水般沉重，即使你自己也意识到这是致命的缺陷却又不知如何改进，那就大声朗读一遍。（我完全凭感觉写作，在正式发表之前都会大声朗读一遍。）你会开始听出问题所在。尝试改变句子的顺序，或者用一个新鲜或独特的词语替换原句，或者调整句子的长度，让它们听起来不那么千篇一律，从而增加文章的多样性。偶尔使用一个短句，往往能产生巨大的冲击力，让读者印象深刻。

Remember that words are the only tools you’ve got. Learn to use them with originality and care. And also remember: somebody out there is listening.

记住，语言是你唯一的工具。学会用心、巧妙地运用它们。还要记住：有人在倾听。

#↩

7

Usage

用法

All this talk about good words and bad words brings us to a gray but important area called “usage.” What is good usage? What is good English? What newly minted words is it O.K. to use, and who is to be the judge? Is it O.K. to use “O.K.”?

所有关于好词和坏词的讨论都引出了一个灰色地带，但却至关重要的领域，那就是“用法”。什么是好的用法？什么是好的英语？哪些新造词可以使用，谁又有资格评判？使用“OK”这个词可以吗？

Earlier I mentioned an incident of college students hassling the administration, and in the last chapter I described myself as a word freak. Here are two fairly recent arrivals. “Hassle” is both a verb and a noun, meaning to give somebody a hard time, or the act of being given a hard time, and anyone who has ever been hassled for not properly filling out Form 35-BX will agree that the word sounds exactly right. “Freak” means an enthusiast, and there’s no missing the aura of obsession that goes with calling someone a jazz freak, or a chess freak, or a sun freak, though it would probably be pushing my luck to describe a man who compulsively visits circus sideshows as a freak freak.

前面我提到过大学生骚扰校方的事件，上一章我还自嘲是个“文字控”。这里再补充两个新词。“Hassle”既是动词又是名词，意思是刁难某人，或者被刁难。任何因为没正确填写35-BX表格而被刁难过的人都会觉得这个词用得恰到好处。“Freak”的意思是狂热爱好者，叫某人“爵士乐狂热者”、“国际象棋狂热者”或“日光浴狂热者”都透着一股痴迷的气息，不过要我说，把一个痴迷于马戏团杂耍表演的人称为“怪胎狂热者”可能就有点过分了。

Anyway, I accept these two usages gladly. I don’t consider them slang, or put quotation marks around them to show that I’m mucking about in the argot of the youth culture and really know better. They’re good words and we need them But I won’t accept “notables” and “greats” and “upcoming” and many other newcomers. They are cheap words and we don’t need them.

总之，我欣然接受这两种用法。我不认为它们是俚语，也不会特意加引号来表明我是在玩弄青年文化的行话，其实我比他们懂得多。这些词很好，我们需要它们。但我不会接受“notables”、“greats”、“upcoming”以及其他许多新词。这些词很廉价，我们不需要它们。

Why is one word good and another word cheap? I can’t give you an answer, because usage has no fixed boundaries. Language is a fabric that changes from one week to another, adding new strands and dropping old ones, and even word freaks fight over what is allowable, often reaching their decision on a wholly subjective basis such as taste (“notables” is sleazy). Which still leaves the question of who our tastemakers are.

为什么有的词好，有的词却很廉价？我无法回答，因为语言的使用没有固定的界限。语言就像一张织锦，每周都在变化，增添新的元素，舍弃旧的元素，即使是语言爱好者也会为了哪些词可以使用而争论不休，他们的决定往往完全基于主观感受，比如品味（“notables”这个词很低俗）。但这仍然引出一个问题：谁才是我们这些“品味引领者”？

The question was confronted in the 1960s by the editors of a brand-new dictionary, The American Heritage Dictionary . They assembled a “Usage Panel” to help them appraise the new words and dubious constructions that had come knocking at the door. Which ones should be ushered in, which thrown out on their ear? The panel consisted of 104 men and women—mostly writers, poets, editors and teachers—who were known for caring about the language and trying to use it well. I was a member of the panel, and over the next few years I kept getting questionnaires. Would I accept “finalize” and “escalate”? How did I feel about “It’s me”? Would I allow “like” to be used as a conjunction—like so many people do? How about “mighty,” as in “mighty fine”?

20世纪60年代，新编纂的《美国传统词典》的编辑们就面临着这个问题。他们组建了一个“用法小组”，帮助他们评估那些涌现的新词和存疑的句式。哪些词应该被采纳，哪些词应该被弃之不用？小组由104位成员组成，他们大多是作家、诗人、编辑和教师，以热爱语言、力求正确运用语言而闻名。我也是小组成员之一，在接下来的几年里，我不断收到调查问卷。我会接受“finalize”（最终化）和“escalate”（升级）这两个词吗？我对“It’s me”（是我）这个说法有什么看法？我会允许像很多人那样把“like”用作连词吗？“mighty”这个词，比如“mighty fine”（非常棒）呢？

We were told that in the dictionary our opinions would be tabulated in a separate “Usage Note,” so that readers could see how we voted. The questionnaire also left room for any comments we might feel impelled to make—an opportunity the panelists seized avidly, as we found when the dictionary was published and our comments were released to the press. Passions ran high. “Good God, no! Never!” cried Barbara W. Tuchman, asked about the verb “to author.” Scholarship hath no fury like that of a language purist faced with sludge, and I shared Tuchman’s vow that “author” should never be authorized, just as I agreed with Lewis Mumford that the adverb “good” should be “left as the exclusive property of Ernest Hemingway.”

我们被告知，词典中会将我们的意见单独列为“用法说明”，以便读者了解我们的投票情况。问卷还留有空间让我们发表任何意见——正如词典出版后，我们的评论被公之于众时，专家组成员们欣然接受了这一机会。他们的情绪十分激动。“我的天哪，不！绝对不行！”芭芭拉·W·塔奇曼在被问及动词“to author”时惊呼道。学术界最愤怒的莫过于语言纯粹主义者面对污泥般的词语时，我与塔奇曼一样坚信“author”一词永远不应被授权使用，正如我同意刘易斯·芒福德的观点，即副词“good”应该“永远是欧内斯特·海明威的专属”。

But guardians of usage are doing only half their job if they merely keep the language from becoming sloppy. Any dolt can rule that the suffix “wise,” as in “healthwise,” is doltwise, or that being “rather unique” is no more possible than being rather pregnant. The other half of the job is to help the language grow by welcoming any immigrant that will bring strength or color. Therefore I was glad that 97 percent of us voted to admit “dropout,” which is clean and vivid, but that only 47 percent would accept “senior citizen,” which is typical of the pudgy new intruders from the land of sociology, where an illegal alien is now an undocumented resident. I’m glad we accepted “escalate,” the kind of verbal contraption I generally dislike but which the Vietnam war endowed with a precise meaning, complete with overtones of blunder.

但如果语言规范的守护者仅仅阻止语言变得粗俗不堪，那他们只完成了一半的工作。任何一个笨蛋都可以认定后缀“wise”（如“healthwise”）是愚蠢的，或者认定“rather unique”（相当独特）和“rather pregnant”（相当怀孕）一样不可能。另一半工作是促进语言发展，欢迎任何能带来力量或色彩的新词。因此，我很高兴97%的人投票通过了“dropout”（辍学生）这个词，它简洁明了，但只有47%的人接受“senior citizen”（老年人），这个词很典型地体现了来自社会学领域的臃肿新入侵者的特点——在社会学领域，非法移民现在变成了无证居民。我很高兴我们接受了“escalate”（升级），这种语言造作我通常不喜欢，但越战赋予了它精确的含义，甚至带有一丝失误的意味。

I’m glad we took into full membership all sorts of robust words that previous dictionaries derided as “colloquial”: adjectives like “rambunctious,” verbs like “trigger” and “rile,” nouns like “shambles” and “tycoon” and “trek,” the latter approved by 78 percent to mean any difficult trip, as in “the commuter’s daily trek to Manhattan.” Originally it was a Cape Dutch word applied to the Boers’ arduous journey by ox wagon. But our panel evidently felt that the Manhattan commuter’s daily trek is no less arduous.

我很高兴我们收录了各种各样强有力的词汇，而之前的词典却将它们贬为“口语化”：比如形容词“rambunctious”（喧闹的），动词“trigger”（激怒）和“rile”（激怒），名词“shambles”（混乱的）、“tycoon”（大亨）和“trek”（跋涉）。其中，“trek”一词获得了78%的认可，用来指代任何艰难的旅程，例如“通勤者每天跋涉到曼哈顿”。这个词最初源于开普敦荷兰语，用来形容布尔人乘坐牛车的艰辛旅程。但我们的评审小组显然认为，曼哈顿通勤者的日常跋涉同样艰辛。

Still, 22 percent were unwilling to let “trek” slip into general usage. That was the virtue of revealing how our panel voted—it put our opinions on display, and writers in doubt can conduct themselves accordingly. Thus our 95 percent vote against “myself,” as in “He invited Mary and myself to dinner,” a word condemned as “prissy,” “horrible” and “a genteelism,” ought to warn off anyone who doesn’t want to be prissy, horrible or genteel. As Red Smith put it, “‘Myself’ is the refuge of idiots taught early that ‘me’ is a dirty word.”

尽管如此，仍有22%的人不愿意让“trek”这个词进入日常用语。这就是公开投票结果的好处——它让我们的观点一目了然，而那些对此犹豫不决的作者可以据此调整自己的写作方式。因此，我们95%的人反对使用“myself”，例如“他邀请玛丽和我共进晚餐”，这个词被斥为“矫揉造作”、“糟糕透顶”和“矫情做作”。这应该足以警示那些不想显得矫揉造作、糟糕透顶或矫情做作的人。正如雷德·史密斯所说，“‘Myself’是那些从小就被灌输‘me’是个脏字的傻瓜们的避难所。”

On the other hand, only 66 percent of our panel rejected the verb “to contact,” once regarded as tacky, and only half opposed the split infinitive and the verbs “to fault” and “to bus.” So only 50 percent of your readers will fault you if you decide to voluntarily call your school board and to bus your children to another town. If you contact your school board you risk your reputation by another 16 percent. Our apparent rule of thumb was stated by Theodore M. Bernstein, author of the excellent The Careful Writer: “We should apply the test of convenience. Does the word fill a real need? If it does, let’s give it a franchise.”

另一方面，只有66%的专家组成员反对使用动词“联系”（contact），这个动词曾被认为不够正式；也只有一半的人反对分裂不定式以及动词“指责”（fault）和“乘坐校车”（bus）。因此，如果您主动致电学校董事会并安排孩子乘坐校车前往其他城镇，只有50%的读者会指责您。如果您联系学校董事会，则会增加16%的声誉风险。我们遵循的经验法则来自西奥多·M·伯恩斯坦（Theodore M. Bernstein），他是优秀著作《谨慎写作》（The Careful Writer）的作者：“我们应该运用便利性检验法。这个词是否满足了实际需求？如果是，那就赋予它特权。”

All of this confirms what lexicographers have always known: that the laws of usage are relative, bending with the taste of the lawmaker. One of our panelists, Katherine Anne Porter, called “O.K.” a “detestable vulgarity” and claimed she had never spoken the word in her life, whereas I freely admit that I have spoken the word “O.K.” “Most,” as in “most everyone,” was scorned as “cute farmer talk” by Isaac Asimov and embraced as a “good English idiom” by Virgil Thomson. “Regime,” meaning any administration, as in “the Truman regime,” drew the approval of most everyone on the panel, as did “dynasty.” But they drew the wrath of Jacques Barzun, who said, “These are technical terms, you blasted non-historians!” Probably I gave my O.K. to “regime.” Now, chided by Barzun for imprecision, I think it looks like journalese. One of the words I railed against was “personality,” as in a “TV personality.” But now I wonder if it isn’t the only word for that vast swarm of people who are famous for being famous—and possibly nothing else. What did the Gabor sisters actually do?

这一切都印证了词典编纂者们一直以来的认知：用法规则是相对的，会随着立法者的喜好而变化。我们的一位小组成员凯瑟琳·安妮·波特称“OK”是“令人厌恶的粗俗用语”，并声称她这辈子从未说过这个词，而我却坦然承认自己说过“OK”。“Most”（如“most everyone”）被艾萨克·阿西莫夫斥为“矫揉造作的农民用语”，却被维吉尔·汤姆森奉为“优秀的英语习语”。“Regime”（指任何政府，如“杜鲁门政权”）和“dynasty”（王朝）都得到了小组中大多数人的认可。但它们却激怒了雅克·巴尔赞，他说：“这些都是专业术语，你们这些该死的非历史学家！”我大概也认可了“regime”这个词。现在，巴尔赞批评它不够严谨，我觉得它看起来像新闻用语。我曾极力反对的词之一就是“个性”，比如“电视名人”。但现在我开始怀疑，这或许是唯一能用来形容那一大群因出名而出名——或许除此之外一无是处——的人的词。加博尔姐妹究竟做了什么？

In the end it comes down to what is “correct” usage. We have no king to establish the King’s English; we only have the President’s English, which we don’t want. Webster , long a defender of the faith, muddied the waters in 1961 with its permissive Third Edition, which argued that almost anything goes as long as somebody uses it, noting that “ain’t” is “used orally in most parts of the U.S. by many cultivated speakers.”

归根结底，问题在于什么是“正确”的用法。我们没有国王来制定“国王英语”的标准；我们只有“总统英语”，而我们并不想要这种英语。韦氏词典长期以来都是英语规范的捍卫者，但它在1961年出版的第三版却搅浑了水。该版本认为，只要有人用，几乎什么都可以用，并指出“ain't”这个词“在美国大部分地区被许多有教养的人口语化使用”。

Just where Webster cultivated those speakers I ain’t sure. Nevertheless it’s true that the spoken language is looser than the written language, and The American Heritage Dictionary properly put its question to us in both forms. Often we allowed an oral idiom that we forbade in print as too informal, fully realizing, however, that “the pen must at length comply with the tongue,” as Samuel Johnson said, and that today’s spoken garbage may be tomorrow’s written gold. The growing acceptance of the split infinitive, or of the preposition at the end of a sentence, proves that formal syntax can’t hold the fort forever against a speaker’s more comfortable way of getting the same thing said—and it shouldn’t. I think a sentence is a fine thing to put a preposition at the end of.

我不太确定韦伯斯特究竟在哪里培养了这些口语使用者。不过，口语确实比书面语更随意，《美国传统词典》也恰当地以两种形式向我们提出了这个问题。我们常常允许一些口语习语出现在书面语中，却因为过于随意而禁止使用，但我们也充分意识到，正如塞缪尔·约翰逊所说，“笔终究要服从舌头”，今天的口语垃圾或许就是明天的书面金句。人们越来越接受分裂不定式或介词置于句末，这证明正式的语法规则无法永远阻挡说话者更习惯的表达方式——而且也不应该阻挡。我认为在句末使用介词是完全可以的。

Our panel recognized that correctness can even vary within a word. We voted heavily against “cohort” as a synonym for “colleague,” except when the tone was jocular. Thus a professor would not be among his cohorts at a faculty meeting, but they would abound at his college reunion, wearing funny hats. We rejected “too” as a synonym for “very,” as in “His health is not too good.” Whose health is? But we approved it in sardonic or humorous use, as in “He was not too happy when she ignored him.”

我们的专家组认识到，即使在同一词语内部，正确性也可能有所不同。我们强烈反对将“cohort”（同伙）作为“colleague”（同事）的同义词，除非语气带有玩笑意味。因此，教授在教职工会议上不会与他的同伙们在一起，但在他的大学同学聚会上，他们会蜂拥而至，戴着滑稽的帽子。我们反对将“too”（太）作为“very”（非常）的同义词，例如“His health is not too good”（他的健康状况不太好）。谁的健康状况好呢？但我们认可在讽刺或幽默的语境中使用它，例如“He was not too happy when she ignored him”（当她忽略他时，他不太高兴）。

These may seem like picayune distinctions. They’re not. They are signals to the reader that you are sensitive to the shadings of usage. “Too” when substituted for “very” is clutter: “He didn’t feel too much like going shopping.” But the wry example in the previous paragraph is worthy of Ring Lardner. It adds a tinge of sarcasm that otherwise wouldn’t be there.

这些看似微不足道的区别，实则不然。它们向读者表明你对用法的细微差别十分敏感。“Too”代替“very”会显得冗赘：“He didn’t feel too much like going shopping.” 但上一段中那个略带讽刺的例子却堪称妙笔，堪比林·拉德纳（Ring Lardner）的风格。它增添了一丝原本不会出现的讽刺意味。

Luckily, a pattern emerged from the deliberations of our panel, and it offers a guideline that is still useful. We turned out to be liberal in accepting new words and phrases, but conservative in grammar.

幸运的是，我们小组的讨论最终形成了一套模式，这套模式至今仍然适用。我们最终决定对新词新语持开放态度，但在语法方面则较为保守。

It would be foolish to reject a word as perfect as “dropout,” or to pretend that countless words and phrases are not entering the gates of correct usage every day, borne on the winds of science and technology, business and sports and social change: “outsource,” “blog,” “laptop,” “mousepad,” “geek,” “boomer,” “Google,” “iPod,” “hedge fund,” “24/7,” “multi-tasking,” “slam dunk” and hundreds of others. Nor should we forget all the short words invented by the counterculture in the 1960s as a way of lashing back at the self-important verbiage of the Establishment: “trip,” “rap,” “crash,” “trash,” “funky,” “split,” “rip-off,” “vibes,” “downer,” “bummer.” If brevity is a prize, these were winners. The only trouble with accepting words that entered the language overnight is that they often leave just as abruptly. The “happenings” of the late 1960s no longer happen, “out of sight” is out of sight, and even “awesome” has begun to chill out. The writer who cares about usage must always know the quick from the dead.

拒绝像“dropout”（辍学）这样完美的词语是愚蠢的，假装无数的词语和短语没有随着科技、商业、体育和社会变革的浪潮，每天涌入语言的殿堂也是愚蠢的，例如“outsource”（外包）、“blog”（博客）、“laptop”（笔记本电脑）、“mousepad”（鼠标垫）、“geek”（极客）、“boomer”（婴儿潮一代）、“Google”（谷歌）、“iPod”（iPod）、“hedge fund”（对冲基金）、“24/7”（全天候）、“multi-tasking”（多任务处理）、“slam dunk”（扣篮）等等，不胜枚举。我们也不应忘记20世纪60年代反主流文化为了反击主流社会自以为是的冗长辞藻而创造的那些短词，例如“trip”（旅行）、“rap”（说唱）、“crash”（崩溃）、“trash”（垃圾）、“funky”（时髦的）、“split”（分裂）、“rip-off”（骗局）、“vibes”（氛围）、“downer”（令人沮丧的）、“bummer”（糟糕的）。如果简洁是一种奖赏，那么这些词无疑是赢家。接受一夜之间进入语言的词语唯一的麻烦之处在于，它们往往也会同样突然地消失。 20世纪60年代末的那些“奇闻异事”如今已不再发生，“眼不见为净”也已不再流行，就连“棒极了”也开始不再常用。注重用法的写作者必须时刻辨别哪些词语依然流行，哪些词语已经过时。

As for the area where our Usage Panel was conservative, we upheld most of the classic distinctions in grammar—“can” and “may,” “fewer” and “less,” “eldest” and “oldest,” etc.—and decried the classic errors, insisting that “flout” still doesn’t mean “flaunt,” no matter how many writers flaunt their ignorance by flouting the rule, and that “fortuitous” still means “accidental,” “disinterested” still means “impartial,” and “infer” doesn’t mean “imply.” Here we were motivated by our love of the language’s beautiful precision. Incorrect usage will lose you the readers you would most like to win. Know the difference between a “reference” and an “allusion,” between “connive” and “conspire,” between “compare with” and “compare to.” If you must use “comprise,” use it right. It means “include”; dinner comprises meat, potatoes, salad and dessert.

至于我们用法小组持保守立场的领域，我们坚持了大多数经典的语法区别——例如“can”和“may”、“fewer”和“less”、“eldest”和“oldest”等等——并谴责了常见的错误用法，坚持认为“flout”仍然不等于“flaunt”，无论有多少作者通过无视规则来炫耀他们的无知；“fortuitous”仍然指“accidental”，“disinterested”仍然指“impartial”，“infer”也不等于“imply”。我们这样做是出于对语言优美精准的热爱。错误的用法会让你失去你最想赢得的读者。要了解“reference”和“allusion”之间的区别，“connive”和“conspire”之间的区别，“compare with”和“compare to”之间的区别。如果你必须使用“comprise”，请务必正确使用。它的意思是“包含”；晚餐包含肉、土豆、沙拉和甜点。

“I choose always the grammatical form unless it sounds affected,” Marianne Moore explained, and that’s finally where our panel took its stand. We were not pedants, so hung up on correctness that we didn’t want the language to keep refreshing itself with phrases like “hung up.” But that didn’t mean we had to accept every atrocity that comes lumbering in.

“除非听起来矫揉造作，否则我总是选择语法正确的形式，”玛丽安·摩尔解释道，而这正是我们小组最终的立场。我们并非迂腐之人，并非执着于语法正确，以至于不希望语言不断涌现出像“hung up”这样的短语。但这并不意味着我们必须接受所有突如其来的糟糕表达。

Meanwhile the battle continues. Today I still receive ballots from The American Heritage Dictionary soliciting my opinion on new locutions: verbs like “definitize” (“Congress definitized a proposal”), nouns like “affordables,” colloquialisms like “the bottom line” and strays like “into” (“He’s into backgammon and she’s into jogging”).

与此同时，这场争论仍在继续。今天，我仍然会收到《美国传统词典》的选票，征求我对一些新词条的意见：例如动词“definitize”（“国会确定了一项提案”），名词“affordables”，口语表达“the bottom line”，以及一些不太常用的词，例如“into”（“他喜欢西洋双陆棋，她喜欢慢跑”）。

It no longer takes a panel of experts to notice that jargon is flooding our daily life and language. President Carter signed an executive order directing that federal regulations be written “simply and clearly.” President Clinton’s attorney general, Janet Reno, urged the nation’s lawyers to replace “a lot of legalese” with “small, old words that all people understand”—words like “right” and “wrong” and “justice.” Corporations have hired consultants to make their prose less opaque, and even the insurance industry is trying to rewrite its policies to tell us in less disastrous English what redress will be ours when disaster strikes. Whether these efforts will do much good I wouldn’t want to bet. Still, there’s comfort in the sight of so many watchdogs standing Canute-like on the beach, trying to hold back the tide. That’s where all careful writers ought to be—looking at every new piece of flotsam that washes up and asking “Do we need it?”

如今，无需专家小组也能看出，术语正充斥着我们的日常生活和语言。卡特总统签署了一项行政命令，指示联邦法规的编写必须“简洁明了”。克林顿总统的司法部长珍妮特·雷诺敦促全国的律师用“人人都能理解的简单词汇”——例如“对”、“错”和“正义”——来取代“大量的法律术语”。各大公司纷纷聘请顾问，力求使他们的文字更加通俗易懂，甚至连保险业也在努力修改保单，用更清晰易懂的语言告诉我们，当灾难来临时，我们能获得哪些赔偿。这些努力究竟能起到多大作用，我不敢妄下断言。不过，看到这么多监督者像克努特将军一样坚守在沙滩上，试图阻止潮水涌来，还是令人感到欣慰的。所有严谨的写作者都应该如此——审视每一件被冲上岸的新事物，并扪心自问：“我们需要它吗？”

I remember the first time somebody asked me, “How does that impact you?” I always thought “impact” was a noun, except in dentistry. Then I began to meet “de-impact,” usually in connection with programs to de-impact the effects of some adversity. Nouns now turn overnight into verbs. We target goals and we access facts. Train conductors announce that the train won’t platform. A sign on an airport door tells me that the door is alarmed. Companies are downsizing. It’s part of an ongoing effort to grow the business. “Ongoing” is a jargon word whose main use is to raise morale. We face our daily job with more zest if the boss tells us it’s an ongoing project; we give more willingly to institutions if they have targeted our funds for ongoing needs. Otherwise we might fall prey to disincentivization.

我记得第一次有人问我：“这对你有什么影响？”我一直以为“影响”（impact）是个名词，除了在牙科领域。后来我开始接触“消除影响”（de-impact）这个词，通常是指那些旨在消除某些不利影响的项目。名词一夜之间就变成了动词。我们设定目标，获取事实。列车员会宣布列车不会停靠站台。机场大门上的标志告诉我，这扇门已启动警报。公司正在裁员。这是公司持续发展业务的一部分。“持续”（Ongoing）这个词现在成了行话，它的主要作用是鼓舞士气。如果老板告诉我们这是一个持续进行的项目，我们就会更有热情地投入到日常工作中；如果机构明确表示我们的捐款将用于持续的需求，我们就会更乐意捐款。否则，我们可能会失去动力。

I could go on; I have enough examples to fill a book, but it’s not a book I would want anyone to read. We’re still left with the question: What is good usage? One helpful approach is to try to separate usage from jargon.

我还可以继续列举；我有很多例子可以写成一本书，但我并不想让任何人读这本书。我们仍然面临着一个问题：什么是好的用法？一个有用的方法是尝试将用法与术语区分开来。

I would say, for example, that “prioritize” is jargon—a pompous new verb that sounds more important than “rank”—and that “bottom line” is usage, a metaphor borrowed from the world of bookkeeping that conveys an image we can picture. As every businessman knows, the bottom line is the one that matters. If someone says, “The bottom line is that we just can’t work together,” we know what he means. I don’t much like the phrase, but the bottom line is that it’s here to stay.

例如，我会说“优先排序”是行话——一个听起来比“排名”更重要的浮夸新动词——而“底线”则是一种用法，一个借用自会计领域的比喻，它能形象地描绘出一幅画面。正如每个商人都知道的那样，底线才是最重要的。如果有人说：“底线是我们根本无法合作”，我们就知道他的意思。我不太喜欢这个短语，但底线是它会一直存在下去。

New usages also arrive with new political events. Just as Vietnam gave us “escalate,” Watergate gave us a whole lexicon of words connoting obstruction and deceit, including “deep-six,” “launder,” “enemies list” and other “gate”-suffix scandals (“Irangate”). It’s a fitting irony that under Richard Nixon “launder” became a dirty word. Today when we hear that someone laundered his funds to hide the origin of the money and the route it took, the word has a precise meaning. It’s short, it’s vivid, and we need it. I accept “launder” and “stonewall”; I don’t accept “prioritize” and “disincentive.”

随着新的政治事件发生，新的词汇用法也随之而来。正如越南战争催生了“升级”（escalate）一词一样，水门事件也为我们带来了一整套暗示阻挠和欺骗的词汇，包括“深埋”（deep-six）、“洗钱”（launder）、“敌人名单”（enemies list）以及其他以“gate”结尾的丑闻（例如“伊朗门”）。颇具讽刺意味的是，在尼克松执政时期，“洗钱”（launder）一词却成了贬义词。如今，当我们听到有人洗钱以掩盖资金来源和流向时，这个词就有了明确的含义。它简洁明了，生动形象，而且我们确实需要它。我接受“洗钱”（launder）和“阻挠”（stonewall）这两个词；但我不能接受“优先处理”（prioritize）和“抑制”（disincentive）这两个词。

I would suggest a similar guideline for separating good English from technical English. It’s the difference between, say, “printout” and “input.” A printout is a specific object that a computer emits. Before the advent of computers it wasn’t needed; now it is. But it has stayed where it belongs. Not so with “input,” which was coined to describe the information that’s fed to a computer. Our input is sought on every subject, from diets to philosophical discourse (“I’d like your input on whether God really exists”).

我建议用类似的准则来区分规范英语和技术英语。比如，“printout”（打印输出）和“input”（输入）的区别。打印输出是指计算机输出的特定对象。在计算机出现之前，它并非必需；现在却必不可少。但它始终保持着其应有的位置。而“input”则不然，它最初是用来描述输入到计算机的信息。从饮食到哲学探讨，我们几乎在所有方面都需要提供“input”（输入）信息（“我想听听你对上帝是否存在的看法”）。

I don’t want to give somebody my input and get his feedback, though I’d be glad to offer my ideas and hear what he thinks of them. Good usage, to me, consists of using good words if they already exist—as they almost always do—to express myself clearly and simply to someone else. You might say it’s how I verbalize the interpersonal.

我不想主动向别人提供意见并征求他们的反馈，虽然我很乐意分享我的想法并听听他们的看法。对我而言，好的表达方式在于，如果已有合适的词语——而它们几乎总是存在的——就使用它们来清晰简洁地向他人表达自己。你可以说，这是我用语言来表达人际交往的方式。

#↩

PART II

第二部分

#↩

Methods

方法

#↩

8

Unity

统一

You learn to write by writing. It’s a truism, but what makes it a truism is that it’s true. The only way to learn to write is to force yourself to produce a certain number of words on a regular basis.

写作就是学习写作。这虽然是老生常谈，但它之所以是老生常谈，是因为它是真理。学习写作的唯一方法就是强迫自己定期写出一定数量的字。

If you went to work for a newspaper that required you to write two or three articles every day, you would be a better writer after six months. You wouldn’t necessarily be writing well; your style might still be full of clutter and clichés. But you would be exercising your powers of putting the English language on paper, gaining confidence and identifying the most common problems.

如果你去报社工作，每天需要写两三篇文章，六个月后你的写作水平肯定会提高。你未必能写出好文章；你的文风可能仍然冗杂陈旧。但你会锻炼运用英语的能力，增强自信，并发现最常见的写作问题。

All writing is ultimately a question of solving a problem. It may be a problem of where to obtain the facts or how to organize the material. It may be a problem of approach or attitude, tone or style. Whatever it is, it has to be confronted and solved. Sometimes you will despair of finding the right solution—or any solution. You’ll think, “If I live to be ninety I’ll never get out of this mess.” I’ve often thought it myself. But when I finally do solve the problem it’s because I’m like a surgeon removing his 500th appendix; I’ve been there before.

写作归根结底都是解决问题的过程。问题可能在于如何获取事实，或者如何组织素材；也可能在于写作方法、态度、语气或风格。无论是什么问题，都必须面对并解决。有时你会对找到合适的解决方案——或者任何解决方案——感到绝望。你会想：“就算我活到九十岁，也永远摆脱不了这团乱麻。”我自己也常常这么想。但当我最终解决问题时，那是因为我就像一位外科医生切除了五百个阑尾一样；我已经经历过类似的情况了。

Unity is the anchor of good writing. So, first, get your unities straight. Unity not only keeps the reader from straggling off in all directions; it satisfies your readers’ subconscious need for order and reassures them that all is well at the helm. Therefore choose from among the many variables and stick to your choice.

统一性是优秀写作的基石。因此，首先要确保你的文章结构严谨。统一性不仅能防止读者偏离主题，还能满足读者潜意识里对秩序的需求，让他们感到一切尽在掌握。所以，在众多要素中做出选择，并坚持下去。

One choice is unity of pronoun. Are you going to write in the first person, as a participant, or in the third person, as an observer? Or even in the second person, that darling of sportswriters hung up on Hemingway? (“You knew this had to be the most spine-tingling clash of giants you’d ever seen from a pressbox seat, and you weren’t just some green kid who was still wet behind the ears.”)

其中一个选择是使用统一的人称代词。你是打算用第一人称，以参与者的身份写作，还是用第三人称，以观察者的身份写作？或者甚至是用第二人称，就像体育记者们钟爱的海明威那样？（“你知道这一定是你在媒体席上见过的最激动人心的巨人对决，而你可不是什么初出茅庐的毛头小子。”）

Unity of tense is another choice. Most people write mainly in the past tense (“I went up to Boston the other day”), but some people write agreeably in the present (“I’m sitting in the dining car of the Yankee Limited and we’re pulling into Boston”). What is not agreeable is to switch back and forth. I’m not saying you can’t use more than one tense; the whole purpose of tenses is to enable a writer to deal with time in its various gradations, from the past to the hypothetical future (“When I telephoned my mother from the Boston station, I realized that if I had written to tell her I would be coming she would have waited for me”). But you must choose the tense in which you are principally going to address the reader, no matter how many glances you may take backward or forward along the way.

时态的统一是另一个选择。大多数人主要使用过去时写作（“前几天我去了波士顿”），但有些人也乐于使用现在时（“我正坐在扬基特快列车的餐车里，我们正驶入波士顿”）。不宜在两种时态之间来回切换。我并不是说你不能使用多种时态；时态的全部意义就在于使作者能够处理时间的各种变化，从过去到假设的未来（“当我从波士顿车站打电话给母亲时，我意识到如果我写信告诉她我会来，她就会等我了”）。但是，无论你在写作过程中如何回顾或展望过去，你都必须选择你主要用来与读者对话的时态。

Another choice is unity of mood. You might want to talk to the reader in the casual voice that The New Yorker has strenuously refined. Or you might want to approach the reader with a certain formality to describe a serious event or to present a set of important facts. Both tones are acceptable. In fact, any tone is acceptable. But don’t mix two or three.

另一种选择是保持语气的统一。你可以用《纽约客》精心打磨的那种轻松随意的语气与读者交谈。或者，你也可以用某种正式的语气来描述严肃的事件或呈现一系列重要的事实。两种语气都可以接受。事实上，任何语气都可以接受。但不要混用两到三种语气。

Such fatal mixtures are common in writers who haven’t learned control. Travel writing is a conspicuous example. “My wife, Ann, and I had always wanted to visit Hong Kong,” the writer begins, his blood astir with reminiscence, “and one day last spring we found ourselves looking at an airline poster and I said, ‘Let’s go!’ The kids were grown up,” he continues, and he proceeds to describe in genial detail how he and his wife stopped off in Hawaii and had such a comical time changing their money at the Hong Kong airport and finding their hotel. Fine. He is a real person taking us along on a real trip, and we can identify with him and Ann.

这种致命的混合在那些尚未学会控制自己情绪的作家身上很常见。游记就是一个明显的例子。“我和妻子安一直想去香港，”作者开篇写道，回忆涌上心头，“去年春天有一天，我们偶然看到一张航空公司的海报，我说，‘走吧！’孩子们都长大了，”他继续说道，然后兴致勃勃地详细描述了他和妻子如何在夏威夷停留，以及在香港机场换钱和寻找酒店时发生的种种滑稽经历。很好。他是一个真实的人，带着我们一起经历了一次真实的旅行，我们能够感同身受他和安的经历。

Suddenly he turns into a travel brochure. “Hong Kong affords many fascinating experiences to the curious sightseer,” he writes. “One can ride the picturesque ferry from Kowloon and gawk at the myriad sampans as they scuttle across the teeming harbor, or take a day’s trip to browse in the alleys of fabled Macao with its colorful history as a den of smuggling and intrigue. You will want to take the quaint funicular that climbs …” Then we get back to him and Ann and their efforts to eat at Chinese restaurants, and again all is well. Everyone is interested in food, and we are being told about a personal adventure.

他突然化身为旅游宣传册。“香港能为好奇的观光客提供许多精彩纷呈的体验，”他写道。“您可以乘坐风景如画的渡轮从九龙出发，欣赏五彩斑斓的舢板穿梭于熙熙攘攘的海港；或者花一天时间漫步于充满传奇色彩的澳门小巷，探寻其作为走私和阴谋之都的传奇历史。您一定会想乘坐那古色古香的缆车……”然后，我们又回到了他和安在中餐馆觅食的话题，一切又恢复了平静。每个人都对美食充满兴趣，我们也在聆听一段他个人的冒险故事。

Then suddenly the writer is a guidebook: “To enter Hong Kong it is necessary to have a valid passport, but no visa is required. You should definitely be immunized against hepatitis and you would also be well advised to consult your physician with regard to a possible inoculation for typhoid. The climate in Hong Kong is seasonable except in July and August when …” Our writer is gone, and so is Ann, and so—very soon—are we.

突然间，作者变成了旅游指南：“进入香港需要有效护照，但无需签证。您务必接种甲型肝炎疫苗，也建议您咨询医生是否需要接种伤寒疫苗。香港气候宜人，但七八月份除外……”作者走了，安也走了，很快，我们也将离开。

It’s not that the scuttling sampans and the hepatitis shots shouldn’t be included. What annoys us is that the writer never decided what kind of article he wanted to write or how he wanted to approach us. He comes at us in many guises, depending on what kind of material he is trying to purvey. Instead of controlling his material, his material is controlling him. That wouldn’t happen if he took time to establish certain unities.

并非说那些摇摇晃晃的舢板和肝炎疫苗不应该被提及。真正让我们恼火的是，作者始终没有决定他想写什么样的文章，或者想用什么方式来呈现。他总是以不同的面目出现，取决于他想要兜售的素材是什么。他不是掌控素材，而是被素材掌控。如果他能花时间建立起某些统一性，这种情况就不会发生了。

Therefore ask yourself some basic questions before you start. For example: “In what capacity am I going to address the reader?” (Reporter? Provider of information? Average man or woman?) “What pronoun and tense am I going to use?” “What style?” (Impersonal reportorial? Personal but formal? Personal and casual?) “What attitude am I going to take toward the material?” (Involved? Detached? Judgmental? Ironic? Amused?) “How much do I want to cover?” “What one point do I want to make?”

因此，在动笔之前，先问自己一些基本问题。例如：“我将以什么身份与读者交流？”（记者？信息提供者？普通人？）“我将使用什么代词和时态？”“采用什么风格？”（客观的报道风格？正式但亲切的风格？随意但亲切的风格？）“我将以什么态度对待材料？”（投入？超然？评判？讽刺？戏谑？）“我想涵盖多少内容？”“我想表达的观点是什么？”

The last two questions are especially important. Most nonfiction writers have a definitiveness complex. They feel that they are under some obligation—to the subject, to their honor, to the gods of writing—to make their article the last word. It’s a commendable impulse, but there is no last word. What you think is definitive today will turn undefinitive by tonight, and writers who doggedly pursue every last fact will find themselves pursuing the rainbow and never settling down to write. Nobody can write a book or an article “about” something. Tolstoy couldn’t write a book about war and peace, or Melville a book about whaling. They made certain reductive decisions about time and place and about individual characters in that time and place—one man pursuing one whale. Every writing project must be reduced before you start to write.

最后两个问题尤为重要。大多数非虚构类作家都有一种“定论情结”。他们觉得自己有义务——对主题、对自身荣誉、对写作之神——让自己的文章成为最终定论。这种冲动固然值得称赞，但根本不存在最终定论。你今天认为的定论，到了今晚可能就变得不再定论了。那些执着于追寻每一个细节的作家，最终只会发现自己是在追逐彩虹，永远无法静下心来写作。没有人能写出一本“关于”某件事的书或一篇文章。托尔斯泰写不出一本关于战争与和平的书，梅尔维尔也写不出一本关于捕鲸的书。他们对时间和地点，以及特定时间和地点中的人物都做出了某种简化的设定——比如一个人追逐一头鲸鱼。每个写作项目在动笔之前都必须进行精简。

Therefore think small. Decide what corner of your subject you’re going to bite off, and be content to cover it well and stop. This is also a matter of energy and morale. An unwieldy writing task is a drain on your enthusiasm. Enthusiasm is the force that keeps you going and keeps the reader in your grip. When your zest begins to ebb, the reader is the first person to know it.

因此，要从小处着手。决定你要深入研究主题的哪个方面，并满足于把它写好就此打住。这关乎精力和士气。一项棘手的写作任务会消耗你的热情。热情是让你坚持下去并牢牢抓住读者的动力。当你的热情开始消退时，读者会是第一个察觉到的人。

As for what point you want to make, every successful piece of nonfiction should leave the reader with one provocative thought that he or she didn’t have before. Not two thoughts, or five—just one. So decide what single point you want to leave in the reader’s mind. It will not only give you a better idea of what route you should follow and what destination you hope to reach; it will affect your decision about tone and attitude. Some points are best made by earnestness, some by dry understatement, some by humor.

至于你想表达什么观点，每一篇成功的非虚构作品都应该给读者留下一个他们之前从未想过的、发人深省的想法。不是两个，也不是五个——只有一个。所以，决定你想在读者心中留下什么。这不仅能让你更好地了解应该采取的策略和最终的目标，还会影响你对文章语气和态度的选择。有些观点用真诚表达效果最佳，有些用冷静的含蓄叙述效果最佳，有些则用幽默表达效果最佳。

Once you have your unities decided, there’s no material you can’t work into your frame. If the tourist in Hong Kong had chosen to write solely in the conversational vein about what he and Ann did, he would have found a natural way to weave into his narrative whatever he wanted to tell us about the Kowloon ferry and the local weather. His personality and purpose would have been intact, and his article would have held together.

一旦确定了文章的单元结构，任何素材都可以融入其中。如果那位在香港的游客选择完全以对话的形式来描述他和安妮的经历，他自然而然地就能将关于九龙渡轮和当地天气的趣事融入叙述之中。他的个性和写作目的依然完整，文章也依然连贯。

Now it often happens that you’ll make these prior decisions and then discover that they weren’t the right ones. The material begins to lead you in an unexpected direction, where you are more comfortable writing in a different tone. That’s normal—the act of writing generates some cluster of thoughts or memories that you didn’t anticipate. Don’t fight such a current if it feels right. Trust your material if it’s taking you into terrain you didn’t intend to enter but where the vibrations are good. Adjust your style accordingly and proceed to whatever destination you reach. Don’t become the prisoner of a preconceived plan. Writing is no respecter of blueprints.

现在，你常常会做出一些预先的决定，然后发现它们并不正确。素材开始引导你走向意想不到的方向，让你用不同的语气写作时感觉更自在。这很正常——写作本身就会引发一些你意想不到的思绪或记忆。如果这种感觉是对的，就不要抗拒。如果你的素材带你进入你原本没打算涉足的领域，但那里的氛围让你感觉良好，那就相信它。相应地调整你的写作风格，然后继续前进，到达你最终到达的目的地。不要成为预设计划的囚徒。写作不会遵循任何蓝图。

If this happens, the second part of your article will be badly out of joint with the first. But at least you know which part is truest to your instincts. Then it’s just a matter of making repairs. Go back to the beginning and rewrite it so that your mood and your style are consistent from start to finish.

如果出现这种情况，文章的第二部分就会与第一部分严重脱节。但至少你知道哪一部分最符合你的直觉。接下来只需进行修正。回到开头，重写一遍，确保你的情绪和风格从头到尾保持一致。

There’s nothing in such a method to be ashamed of. Scissors and paste—or their equivalent on a computer—are honorable writers’ tools. Just remember that all the unities must be fitted into the edifice you finally put together, however backwardly they may be assembled, or it will soon come tumbling down.

这种方法没什么可羞耻的。剪刀和粘贴——或者电脑上的类似工具——都是作家光荣的工具。记住，无论你最初是如何胡乱拼凑的，所有元素都必须融入你最终构建的整体之中，否则它很快就会崩塌。

#↩

9

The Lead and the Ending

开头和结尾

The most important sentence in any article is the first one. If it doesn’t induce the reader to proceed to the second sentence, your article is dead. And if the second sentence doesn’t induce him to continue to the third sentence, it’s equally dead. Of such a progression of sentences, each tugging the reader forward until he is hooked, a writer constructs that fateful unit, the “lead.”

任何文章中最重要的一句话都是第一句话。如果它不能引导读者继续阅读第二句话，那么你的文章就失去了意义。同样，如果第二句话不能引导读者继续阅读第三句话，那么这篇文章也同样失去了意义。正是通过这样一系列循序渐进的句子，一步步吸引读者，直到他们完全被吸引，作者才构建出那个至关重要的单元——“导语”。

How long should the lead be? One or two paragraphs? Four or five? There’s no pat answer. Some leads hook the reader with just a few well-baited sentences; others amble on for several pages, exerting a slow but steady pull. Every article poses a different problem, and the only valid test is: does it work? Your lead may not be the best of all possible leads, but if it does the job it’s supposed to do, be thankful and proceed.

文章开头应该写多长？一两段？四五段？没有标准答案。有些开头只需几句精心设计的句子就能抓住读者的眼球；有些开头则绵延数页，缓慢而稳定地吸引读者。每篇文章面临的问题都不同，唯一有效的检验标准是：它有效吗？你的开头或许不是所有开头中最完美的，但如果它完成了它应该完成的任务，那就应该感到欣慰并继续前进。

Sometimes the length may depend on the audience you’re writing for. Readers of a literary review expect its writers to start somewhat discursively, and they will stick with those writers for the pleasure of wondering where they will emerge as they move in leisurely circles toward the eventual point. But I urge you not to count on the reader to stick around. Readers want to know—very soon—what’s in it for them.

文章的长度有时取决于你的目标读者。文学评论的读者期待作者以较为散漫的方式开篇，他们会乐于跟随作者的思路，享受那种悠闲地兜圈子最终得出结论的乐趣。但我建议你不要指望读者会一直读下去。读者想知道——而且是越快越好——这篇文章对他们有什么意义。

Therefore your lead must capture the reader immediately and force him to keep reading. It must cajole him with freshness, or novelty, or paradox, or humor, or surprise, or with an unusual idea, or an interesting fact, or a question. Anything will do, as long as it nudges his curiosity and tugs at his sleeve.

因此，你的开头必须立刻抓住读者的眼球，让他忍不住继续读下去。它必须以新鲜感、新颖性、悖论、幽默、惊喜、不同寻常的想法、有趣的事实或问题来吸引他。任何方法都可以，只要能激起他的好奇心，让他忍不住想读下去。

Next the lead must do some real work. It must provide hard details that tell the reader why the piece was written and why he ought to read it. But don’t dwell on the reason. Coax the reader a little more; keep him inquisitive.

接下来，导语必须发挥实际作用。它必须提供确凿的细节，告诉读者这篇文章的写作缘由以及读者应该阅读它的理由。但不要过多赘述原因，要引导读者更进一步，保持他们的好奇心。

Continue to build. Every paragraph should amplify the one that preceded it. Give more thought to adding solid detail and less to entertaining the reader. But take special care with the last sentence of each paragraph—it’s the crucial springboard to the next paragraph. Try to give that sentence an extra twist of humor or surprise, like the periodic “snapper” in the routine of a stand-up comic. Make the reader smile and you’ve got him for at least one more paragraph.

继续推进。每个段落都应该在前一个段落的基础上进行拓展。多花些心思添加翔实的细节，少一些为了娱乐读者而刻意为之。但要特别注意每个段落的最后一句话——它是引出下一个段落的关键跳板。试着给这句话增添一些幽默或惊喜，就像脱口秀演员表演中时不时出现的“啪啪声”一样。让读者会心一笑，你就能让他至少再读一个段落。

Let’s look at a few leads that vary in pace but are alike in maintaining pressure. I’ll start with two columns of my own that first appeared in Life and Look —magazines which, judging by the comments of readers, found their consumers mainly in barbershops, hairdressing salons, airplanes and doctors’ offices (“I was getting a haircut the other day and I saw your article”). I mention this as a reminder that far more periodical reading is done under the dryer than under the reading lamp, so there isn’t much time for the writer to fool around.

让我们来看几个节奏各异但都同样引人入胜的开头。首先，我想分享我自己的两篇专栏文章，它们最初发表在《生活》和《展望》杂志上——从读者的评论来看，这两本杂志的读者主要集中在理发店、美发沙龙、飞机上和诊所里（“前几天我去理发的时候看到了你的文章”）。我提到这一点是为了提醒大家，人们阅读期刊文章的时间大多是在烘发机下而不是在阅读灯下，所以作者没有太多时间可以随意发挥。

The first is the lead of a piece called “Block That Chickenfurter”:

第一部分是题为“阻止那条鸡肠”的文章的开头：

I’ve often wondered what goes into a hot dog. Now I know and I wish I didn’t.

我一直很好奇热狗里都放了些什么。现在我知道了，但我真希望自己不知道。

Two very short sentences. But it would be hard not to continue to the second paragraph:

两句很短的话。但很难不继续写到第二段：

My trouble began when the Department of Agriculture published the hot dog’s ingredients—everything that may legally qualify—because it was asked by the poultry industry to relax the conditions under which the ingredients might also include chicken. In other words, can a chickenfurter find happiness in the land of the frank?

我的麻烦始于美国农业部公布热狗的配料表——所有符合法律规定的成分——因为家禽业要求放宽配料中可以包含鸡肉的条件。换句话说，鸡肉香肠能在法兰克福香肠的故乡找到归宿吗？

One sentence that explains the incident that the column is based on. Then a snapper to restore the easygoing tone.

用一句话解释专栏文章所依据的事件。然后用一句轻松的话语恢复轻松的语气。

Judging by the 1,066 mainly hostile answers that the Department got when it sent out a questionnaire on this point, the very thought is unthinkable. The public mood was most felicitously caught by the woman who replied: “I don’t eat feather meat of no kind.”

从该部门就此问题发放问卷后收到的1066份主要持反对意见的回复来看，这种想法简直不可思议。一位女士的回复最能体现公众的情绪：“我什么羽毛做的肉都不吃。”

Another fact and another smile. Whenever you’re lucky enough to get a quotation as funny as that one, find a way to use it. The article then specifies what the Department of Agriculture says may go into a hot dog—a list that includes “the edible part of the muscle of cattle, sheep, swine or goats, in the diaphragm, in the heart or in the esophagus … [but not including] the muscle found in the lips, snout or ears.”

又一个事实，又一个笑点。每当你幸运地遇到像这样有趣的引语时，一定要想办法用上它。文章接着列举了美国农业部规定的热狗配料——其中包括“牛、羊、猪或山羊的可食用肌肉部分，位于横膈膜、心脏或食道……[但不包括]嘴唇、鼻子或耳朵里的肌肉”。

From there it progresses—not without an involuntary reflex around the esophagus—into an account of the controversy between the poultry interests and the frankfurter interests, which in turn leads to the point that Americans will eat anything that even remotely resembles a hot dog. Implicit at the end is the larger point that Americans don’t know, or care, what goes into the food they eat. The style of the article has remained casual and touched with humor. But its content turns out to be more serious than readers expected when they were drawn into it by a whimsical lead.

文章由此展开——读来不禁让人感到一阵恶心——讲述了家禽业和法兰克福香肠业之间的争论，最终得出结论：美国人什么都吃，只要跟热狗沾边就行。文章结尾隐含着一个更深层次的观点：美国人既不了解也不关心自己吃的食物里都有些什么。文章的风格轻松诙谐，但其内容却比读者预想的要严肃得多，尽管开头看似轻松诙谐，却并未引起读者的注意。

A slower lead, luring the reader more with curiosity than with humor, introduced a piece called “Thank God for Nuts”:

文章开头节奏较慢，更多地用好奇心而非幽默来吸引读者，引出了一篇题为“感谢上帝赐予坚果”的文章：

By any reasonable standard, nobody would want to look twice—or even once—at the piece of slippery elm bark from Clear Lake, Wisc., birthplace of pitcher Burleigh Grimes, that is on display at the National Baseball Museum and Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. As the label explains, it is the kind of bark Grimes chewed during games “to increase saliva for throwing the spitball. When wet, the ball sailed to the plate in deceptive fashion.” This would seem to be one of the least interesting facts available in America today.

无论从哪个角度来看，没人会想多看一眼——甚至连看一眼都不愿意——那块产自威斯康星州克利尔湖的滑榆树皮。克利尔湖是棒球投手伯利·格莱姆斯的出生地，如今它陈列在纽约州库珀斯敦的国家棒球博物馆暨名人堂。正如标签上所解释的，格莱姆斯在比赛中会咀嚼这种树皮，“以增加唾液分泌，从而投出口水球。湿润的树皮能让球以一种迷惑的方式飞向本垒板。” 这似乎是当今美国最无趣的冷知识之一。

But baseball fans can’t be judged by any reasonable standard. We are obsessed by the minutiae of the game and nagged for the rest of our lives by the memory of players we once saw play. No item is therefore too trivial that puts us back in touch with them. I am just old enough to remember Burleigh Grimes and his well-moistened pitches sailing deceptively to the plate, and when I found his bark I studied it as intently as if I had come upon the Rosetta Stone. “So that’s how he did it,” I thought, peering at the odd botanical relic. “Slippery elm! I’ll be damned.”

但棒球迷无法用任何合理的标准来评判。我们痴迷于比赛的细枝末节，并且终生都会被曾经看过的球员的记忆所萦绕。因此，任何能让我们与他们重新建立联系的事物，都不算微不足道。我年纪刚好够大，还记得伯利·格莱姆斯和他那湿润的球路，它们以迷惑性的姿态飞向本垒板。当我找到他留下的树皮时，我像发现了罗塞塔石碑一样仔细地研究它。“原来他是这么做的，”我一边盯着这奇特的植物遗迹一边想。“滑榆！真是见鬼了。”

This was only one of several hundred encounters I had with my own boyhood as I prowled through the Museum. Probably no other museum is so personal a pilgrimage to our past....

这只是我在博物馆里漫步时，与童年记忆数百次邂逅中的一次。或许没有其他博物馆能像这里一样，成为我们如此私人的追忆之旅……

The reader is now safely hooked, and the hardest part of the writer’s job is over.

读者现在已经完全被吸引住了，作者工作中最为艰难的部分也已经过去了。

One reason for citing this lead is to note that salvation often lies not in the writer’s style but in some odd fact he or she was able to discover. I went up to Cooperstown and spent a whole afternoon in the museum, taking notes. Jostled everywhere by nostalgia, I gazed with reverence at Lou Gehrig’s locker and Bobby Thomson’s game-winning bat. I sat in a grandstand seat brought from the Polo Grounds, dug my unspiked soles into the home plate from Ebbets Field, and dutifully copied all the labels and captions that might be useful.

引用这条线索的原因之一是想说明，救赎往往不在于作者的文风，而在于他或她发现的某些奇特事实。我去了库珀斯敦，在博物馆里待了一整个下午，做笔记。怀旧的气息扑面而来，我怀着敬畏之心凝视着卢·格里克的更衣柜和鲍比·汤姆森的制胜球棒。我坐在从马球场搬来的看台上，用没穿钉鞋的鞋底踩着埃贝茨球场的本垒板，认真地抄录了所有可能用得上的标签和说明文字。

“These are the shoes that touched home plate as Ted finished his journey around the bases,” said a label identifying the shoes worn by Ted Williams when he famously hit a home run on his last time at bat. The shoes were in much better shape than the pair—rotted open at the sides—that belonged to Walter Johnson. But the caption provided exactly the kind of justifying fact a baseball nut would want. “My feet must be comfortable when I’m out there a-pitching,” the great Walter said.

“泰德绕垒跑完最后一圈时，脚上踩着的就是这双鞋，”鞋上的标签这样写道，上面标明了泰德·威廉姆斯最后一次击球时所穿的那双鞋——那一记著名的本垒打。这双鞋比沃尔特·约翰逊那双侧面已经腐烂开裂的鞋要好得多。但标签上的说明文字恰恰提供了棒球迷梦寐以求的佐证。“我上场投球的时候，脚必须舒服才行，”伟大的沃尔特说道。

The museum closed at five and I returned to my motel secure in my memories and my research. But instinct told me to go back the next morning for one more tour, and it was only then that I noticed Burleigh Grimes’s slippery elm bark, which struck me as an ideal lead. It still does.

博物馆五点关门，我带着美好的回忆和研究成果回到了汽车旅馆。但直觉告诉我第二天早上应该再去参观一次，直到那时我才注意到伯利·格莱姆斯的滑榆树皮，我觉得这是一个绝佳的线索。现在依然如此。

One moral of this story is that you should always collect more material than you will use. Every article is strong in proportion to the surplus of details from which you can choose the few that will serve you best—if you don’t go on gathering facts forever. At some point you must stop researching and start writing.

这个故事告诉我们，收集的素材应该永远比实际需要的多。文章的质量取决于你掌握的细节是否丰富，你可以从中挑选出最有用的部分——前提是你不会无休止地收集资料。在某个时刻，你必须停止研究，开始写作。

Another moral is to look for your material everywhere, not just by reading the obvious sources and interviewing the obvious people. Look at signs and at billboards and at all the junk written along the American roadside. Read the labels on our packages and the instructions on our toys, the claims on our medicines and the graffiti on our walls. Read the fillers, so rich in self-esteem, that come spilling out of your monthly statement from the electric company and the telephone company and the bank. Read menus and catalogues and second-class mail. Nose about in obscure crannies of the newspaper, like the Sunday real estate section—you can tell the temper of a society by what patio accessories it wants. Our daily landscape is thick with absurd messages and portents. Notice them. They not only have social significance; they are often just quirky enough to make a lead that’s different from everybody else’s.

另一个道理是，要到处寻找素材，而不仅仅局限于阅读显而易见的资料和采访显而易见的人。看看路标、广告牌，以及美国公路边上各种各样的垃圾信息。读读我们包裹上的标签、玩具上的说明书、药品上的宣传语，以及墙上的涂鸦。读读那些充斥着自恋的填充信息，它们从你每月收到的电力公司、电话公司和银行的账单中溢出来。读读菜单、产品目录和二等邮件。在报纸的犄角旮旯里翻翻，比如周日的房地产版——你可以通过一个社会对庭院装饰品的需求来判断它的风气。我们日常生活中充斥着各种荒诞的信息和预兆。注意它们。它们不仅具有社会意义；它们往往足够奇特，可以成为一条与众不同的新闻线索。

Speaking of everybody else’s lead, there are many categories I’d be glad never to see again. One is the future archaeologist: “When some future archaeologist stumbles on the remains of our civilization, what will he make of the jukebox?” I’m tired of him already and he’s not even here. I’m also tired of the visitor from Mars: “If a creature from Mars landed on our planet he would be amazed to see hordes of scantily clad earthlings lying on the sand barbecuing their skins.” I’m tired of the cute event that just happened to happen “one day not long ago” or on a conveniently recent Saturday afternoon: “One day not long ago a small button-nosed boy was walking with his dog, Terry, in a field outside Paramus, N.J., when he saw something that looked strangely like a balloon rising out of the ground.” And I’m very tired of the have-in-common lead: “What did Joseph Stalin, Douglas MacArthur, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Sherwood Anderson, Jorge Luis Borges and Akira Kurosawa have in common? They all loved Westerns.” Let’s retire the future archaeologist and the man from Mars and the button-nosed boy. Try to give your lead a freshness of perception or detail.

说到其他人的主导，有很多类别我巴不得永远别再看到。比如“未来的考古学家”：“当未来的考古学家偶然发现我们文明的遗迹时，他会如何看待这台点唱机？”我还没见过他就已经厌倦了。我也厌倦了“火星访客”：“如果一个火星生物降落到我们的星球上，他会惊讶地发现成群衣衫褴褛的地球人躺在沙滩上烤着自己的皮肤。”我也厌倦了那些“不久前的某一天”或者“就在不久前的某个周六下午”发生的可爱小插曲：“不久前的某一天，一个鼻子圆圆的小男孩带着他的狗特里在新泽西州帕拉姆斯郊外的一片田野里散步，突然看到一个看起来很像气球的东西从地里升了起来。”我已经厌倦了那种“共同点”式的开头：“约瑟夫·斯大林、道格拉斯·麦克阿瑟、路德维希·维特根斯坦、舍伍德·安德森、豪尔赫·路易斯·博尔赫斯和黑泽明有什么共同点？他们都喜欢西部片。” 别再用“未来的考古学家”、“火星人”和“小鼻子男孩”这些老梗了。试着给你的开头增添一些新鲜的视角或细节吧。

Consider this lead, by Joan Didion, on a piece called “7000 Romaine, Los Angeles 38”:

请看琼·迪迪恩 (Joan Didion) 在其题为《洛杉矶罗马大道 7000 号 38》的文章中撰写的这段引言：

Seven Thousand Romaine Street is in that part of Los Angeles familiar to admirers of Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett: the underside of Hollywood, south of Sunset Boulevard, a middle-class slum of “model studios” and warehouses and two-family bungalows. Because Paramount and Columbia and Desilu and the Samuel Goldwyn studios are nearby, many of the people who live around here have some tenuous connection with the motion-picture industry. They once processed fan photographs, say, or knew Jean Harlow’s manicurist. 7000 Romaine looks itself like a faded movie exterior, a pastel building with chipped art moderne detailing, the windows now either boarded or paned with chicken-wire glass and, at the entrance, among the dusty oleander, a rubber mat that reads WELCOME.

罗曼街七千号位于洛杉矶，是雷蒙德·钱德勒和达希尔·哈米特的读者们所熟悉的那片区域：好莱坞的底层，日落大道以南，一片由“样板间”、仓库和双拼平房组成的中产阶级贫民窟。由于派拉蒙、哥伦比亚、德西鲁和塞缪尔·戈德温制片厂都近在咫尺，许多住在附近的人都与电影行业有着某种程度的联系。比如说，他们曾经冲洗过影迷照片，或者认识简·哈洛的美甲师。罗曼街七千号本身就像一部褪色的电影外景，一栋粉彩色的建筑，装饰着斑驳的现代艺术风格细节，窗户如今要么用木板封住，要么装上了铁丝网玻璃，入口处，在布满灰尘的夹竹桃丛中，一块写着“欢迎”的橡胶垫。

Actually no one is welcome, for 7000 Romaine belongs to Howard Hughes, and the door is locked. That the Hughes “communications center” should lie here in the dull sunlight of Hammett-Chandler country is one of those circumstances that satisfy one’s suspicion that life is indeed a scenario, for the Hughes empire has been in our time the only industrial complex in the world—involving, over the years, machinery manufacture, foreign oil-tool subsidiaries, a brewery, two airlines, immense real-estate holdings, a major motion-picture studio, and an electronics and missile operation—run by a man whose modus operandi most closely resembles that of a character in The Big Sleep .

事实上，这里不欢迎任何人，因为7000 Romaine属于霍华德·休斯，而且大门紧锁。休斯的“通讯中心”竟然坐落在哈米特-钱德勒笔下这片阴沉的土地上，这似乎印证了人们心中“人生如戏”的猜想。休斯帝国是当今世界上唯一的工业综合体——多年来，它涵盖了机械制造、海外石油工具子公司、一家啤酒厂、两家航空公司、庞大的房地产、一家大型电影制片厂以及电子和导弹业务——而掌管这一切的人，其行事作风与《夜长梦多》中的人物极为相似。

As it happens, I live not far from 7000 Romaine, and I make a point of driving past it every now and then, I suppose in the same spirit that Arthurian scholars visit the Cornish coast. I am interested in the folklore of Howard Hughes....

碰巧，我住的地方离罗曼街7000号不远，我时不时会特意开车经过那里，我想这大概和亚瑟王研究学者造访康沃尔海岸的心情差不多吧。我对霍华德·休斯的民间传说很感兴趣……

What is pulling us into this article—toward, we hope, some glimpse of how Hughes operates, some hint of the riddle of the Sphinx—is the steady accumulation of facts that have pathos and faded glamour. Knowing Jean Harlow’s manicurist is such a minimal link to glory, the unwelcoming welcome mat such a queer relic of a golden age when Hollywood’s windows weren’t paned with chicken-wire glass and the roost was ruled by giants like Mayer and DeMille and Zanuck, who could actually be seen exercising their mighty power. We want to know more; we read on.

吸引我们阅读这篇文章的，是那些充满悲情和褪色魅力的事实。我们希望从中窥见休斯的创作手法，解开斯芬克斯之谜。了解简·哈洛的美甲师只是通往辉煌的微不足道的一点线索；那张冷漠的迎宾地毯，仿佛是好莱坞黄金时代的遗迹，那时好莱坞的窗户还没有装上铁丝网，而像梅耶、德米勒和扎努克这样的巨擘才是真正的掌权者，他们行使着自己强大的权力。我们渴望了解更多，于是继续阅读。

Another approach is to just tell a story. It’s such a simple solution, so obvious and unsophisticated, that we often forget that it’s available to us. But narrative is the oldest and most compelling method of holding someone’s attention; everybody wants to be told a story. Always look for ways to convey your information in narrative form. What follows is the lead of Edmund Wilson’s account of the discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls, one of the most astonishing relics of antiquity to turn up in modern times. Wilson doesn’t spend any time setting the stage. This is not the “breakfast-to-bed” format used by inexperienced writers, in which a fishing trip begins with the ringing of an alarm clock before daylight. Wilson starts right in—whap!—and we are caught:

另一种方法就是讲故事。这是一个如此简单、如此显而易见、如此朴实无华的解决方案，以至于我们常常忘记它的存在。但叙事是最古老、最能吸引读者注意力的方法；每个人都渴望听故事。要始终寻找以叙事形式传达信息的方法。以下是埃德蒙·威尔逊对死海古卷发现过程的描述，死海古卷是近代发现的最令人震惊的古代遗物之一。威尔逊没有花时间铺垫。这并非经验不足的作家常用的“从早餐到床”的叙事模式，那种模式中，钓鱼之旅以黎明前的闹钟声开始。威尔逊开门见山——砰！——我们就被吸引住了：

At some point rather early in the spring of 1947, a Bedouin boy called Muhammed the Wolf was minding some goats near a cliff on the western shore of the Dead Sea. Climbing up after one that had strayed, he noticed a cave that he had not seen before, and he idly threw a stone into it. There was an unfamiliar sound of breakage. The boy was frightened and ran away. But he later came back with another boy, and together they explored the cave. Inside were several tall clay jars, among fragments of other jars. When they took off the bowl-like lids, a very bad smell arose, which came from dark oblong lumps that were found inside all the jars. When they got these lumps out of the cave, they saw that they were wrapped up in lengths of linen and coated with a black layer of what seemed to be pitch or wax. They unrolled them and found long manuscripts, inscribed in parallel columns on thin sheets that had been sewn together. Though these manuscripts had faded and crumbled in places, they were in general remarkably clear. The character, they saw, was not Arabic. They wondered at the scrolls and kept them, carrying them along when they moved.

1947年早春的某个时候，一个名叫穆罕默德·沃尔夫的贝都因男孩在死海西岸的一处悬崖边放羊。一只羊走失后，他爬上去追赶，发现了一个从未见过的洞穴，便随手往里面扔了一块石头。洞穴里传来一阵异样的碎裂声。男孩吓了一跳，跑开了。但后来他又带着另一个男孩回来，一起探索了洞穴。洞里有几个高高的陶罐，还有一些陶罐的碎片。他们打开罐子碗状的盖子，一股恶臭扑面而来，原来是所有陶罐里都藏着一些黑色的长条状物。他们把这些物块从洞穴里拿出来，发现它们被亚麻布包裹着，表面涂了一层黑色的物质，像是沥青或蜡。他们展开亚麻布，发现里面是长长的手稿，写在缝合在一起的薄纸上，文字以平行列的形式排列。虽然这些手稿有些地方已经褪色破损，但总体上仍然清晰可见。他们发现，上面的文字并非阿拉伯文字。他们惊叹于这些卷轴，便将它们保存下来，搬家时也随身携带。

These Bedouin boys belonged to a party of contrabanders, who had been smuggling their goats and other goods out of Transjordan into Palestine. They had detoured so far to the south in order to circumvent the Jordan bridge, which the customs officers guarded with guns, and had floated their commodities across the stream. They were now on their way to Bethlehem to sell their stuff in the black market....

这些贝都因男孩属于一个走私团伙，他们一直将山羊和其他货物从外约旦走私到巴勒斯坦。为了绕过约旦河大桥（海关官员持枪把守），他们绕道向南走了很远，然后用船将货物漂过河。现在，他们正前往伯利恒，准备在黑市上出售这些货物……

Yet there can be no firm rules for how to write a lead. Within the broad rule of not letting the reader get away, all writers must approach their subject in a manner that most naturally suits what they are writing about and who they are. Sometimes you can tell your whole story in the first sentence. Here’s the opening sentence of seven memorable nonfiction books:

然而，如何写好导语并没有固定的规则。在不让读者走神的大原则下，所有作者都必须以最自然、最符合自身风格和写作主题的方式来切入主题。有时，你可以在第一句话中讲述整个故事。以下是七本令人难忘的非虚构类书籍的开篇句：

In the beginning God created heaven and earth.

起初，神创造天地。

—T HE B IBLE
——《圣经》

In the summer of the Roman year 699, now described as the year 55 before the birth of Christ, the Proconsul of Gaul, Gaius Julius Caesar, turned his gaze upon Britain.

公元 699 年夏天（现在被称为基督诞生前 55 年），高卢总督盖乌斯·尤利乌斯·凯撒将目光投向了不列颠。

— W INSTON S. C HURCHILL , A H ISTORY OF THE E NGLISH -S PEAKING P EOPLES
——温斯顿·S·丘吉尔，《英语民族史》

Put this puzzle together and you will find milk, cheese and eggs, meat, fish, beans and cereals, greens, fruits and root vegetables—foods that contain our essential daily needs.

把这个拼图拼起来，你会发现牛奶、奶酪和鸡蛋、肉类、鱼类、豆类和谷物、绿叶蔬菜、水果和根茎类蔬菜——这些食物包含了我们日常生活中必需的营养。

— I RMA S. R OMBAUER , J OY OF C OOKING
——艾尔玛·S·罗姆鲍尔，《烹饪的乐趣》

To the Manus native the world is a great platter, curving upwards on all sides, from his flat lagoon village where the pile-houses stand like long-legged birds, placid and unstirred by the changing tides.

对于马努斯岛的居民来说，世界就像一个巨大的盘子，四面向上弯曲，从他平坦的泻湖村庄望去，那里的桩屋像长腿鸟一样矗立着，平静而不受潮汐变化的影响。

— M ARGARET M EAD , G ROWING U P IN N EW G UINEA
——玛格丽特·米德，《在新几内亚长大》

The problem lay buried, unspoken, for many years in the minds of American women.

这个问题多年来一直被美国女性深埋心底，无人提及。

— B ETTY F RIEDAN , T HE F EMININE M YSTIQUE
——贝蒂·弗里丹，《女性的奥秘》

Within five minutes, or ten minutes, no more than that, three of the others had called her on the telephone to ask her if she had heard that something had happened out there.

不到五分钟，或者十分钟，其他三个人就打电话给她，问她是否听说外面发生了什么事。

— T OM W OLFE , T HE R IGHT S TUFF
——汤姆·沃尔夫，《太空先锋》

You know more than you think you do.

你比你想象的更了解自己。

— B ENJAMIN S POCK , B ABY AND C HILD C ARE
——本杰明·斯波克，《婴儿和儿童护理》

Those are some suggestions on how to get started. Now I want to tell you how to stop. Knowing when to end an article is far more important than most writers realize. You should give as much thought to choosing your last sentence as you did to your first. Well, almost as much.

以上是一些写作入门建议。现在我想告诉你如何收尾。知道何时结束一篇文章远比大多数作者意识到的要重要得多。你应该像斟酌第一句话一样认真地选择最后一句话。嗯，几乎一样。

That may seem hard to believe. If your readers have stuck with you from the beginning, trailing you around blind corners and over bumpy terrain, surely they won’t leave when the end is in sight. Surely they will, because the end that’s in sight turns out to be a mirage. Like the minister’s sermon that builds to a series of perfect conclusions that never conclude, an article that doesn’t stop where it should stop becomes a drag and therefore a failure.

这或许难以置信。如果你的读者从一开始就陪伴你，一路跟随你走过曲折坎坷，他们肯定不会在终点近在眼前时就离开。然而，他们最终还是会离开，因为那看似终点的景象其实只是海市蜃楼。就像牧师的布道总是试图给出完美的结论，却最终不了了之一样，一篇没有在应该结束的地方结束的文章，也会变得冗长乏味，最终沦为失败之作。

Most of us are still prisoners of the lesson pounded into us by the composition teachers of our youth: that every story must have a beginning, a middle and an end. We can still visualize the outline, with its Roman numerals (I, II and III), which staked out the road we would faithfully trudge, and its subnumerals (IIa and IIb) denoting lesser paths down which we would briefly poke. But we always promised to get back to III and summarize our journey.

我们大多数人仍然受困于童年时期作文老师灌输给我们的那条教条：每个故事都必须有开头、中间和结尾。我们仍然能清晰地记得那条用罗马数字（I、II 和 III）标示的框架，它指引着我们忠实前行的道路，而它的子数字（IIa 和 IIb）则代表着我们偶尔涉猎的支线。但我们总是承诺会回到 III，总结我们的旅程。

That’s all right for elementary and high school students uncertain of their ground. It forces them to see that every piece of writing should have a logical design. It’s a lesson worth knowing at any age—even professional writers are adrift more often than they would like to admit. But if you’re going to write good nonfiction you must wriggle out of III’s dread grip.

这对那些对自身基础尚不清晰的小学生和中学生来说当然没问题。它能迫使他们认识到，每篇文章都应该有逻辑结构。这在任何年龄段都是值得学习的——即使是专业作家，也常常会迷失方向，而他们自己却不愿承认。但如果你想写出优秀的非虚构作品，就必须摆脱逻辑思维的束缚。

You’ll know you have arrived at III when you see emerging on your screen a sentence that begins, “In sum, it can be noted that …” Or a question that asks, “What insights, then, have we been able to glean from …?” These are signals that you are about to repeat in compressed form what you have already said in detail. The reader’s interest begins to falter; the tension you have built begins to sag. Yet you will be true to Miss Potter, your teacher, who made you swear fealty to the holy outline. You remind the reader of what can, in sum, be noted. You go gleaning one more time in insights you have already adduced.

当你看到屏幕上出现以“总而言之，值得注意的是……”开头的句子，或者出现“那么，我们从……中获得了哪些见解？”这样的问题时，你就知道自己已经写到第三部分了。这些信号表明你即将以更简洁的形式重复之前详细阐述的内容。读者的兴趣开始减弱；你之前营造的紧张感也开始消退。然而，你仍然要忠于你的老师波特小姐，她曾让你宣誓要严格遵守这套神圣的提纲。你要提醒读者，总而言之，有哪些值得注意的地方。你要再次从你之前已经提出的见解中汲取精华。

But your readers hear the laborious sound of cranking. They notice what you are doing and how bored you are by it. They feel the stirrings of resentment. Why didn’t you give more thought to how you were going to wind this thing up? Or are you summarizing because you think they’re too dumb to get the point? Still, you keep cranking. But the readers have another option. They quit.

但你的读者听到了你费力地敲击键盘的声音。他们注意到你在做什么，以及你对此有多么厌倦。他们感到一丝不满。你为什么不多花点心思想想该如何结尾呢？还是你觉得他们太笨，理解不了你的意思，所以才用总结的方式？尽管如此，你仍然继续敲击键盘。但读者还有另一种选择：他们放弃了。

That’s the negative reason for remembering the importance of the last sentence. Failure to know where that sentence should occur can wreck an article that until its final stage has been tightly constructed. The positive reason for ending well is that a good last sentence—or last paragraph—is a joy in itself. It gives the reader a lift, and it lingers when the article is over.

这就是记住最后一句话重要性的负面原因。如果不知道最后一句话应该出现在哪里，一篇原本结构严谨的文章就会功亏一篑。而结尾的重要性则在于，一个好的结尾——或者说最后一个段落——本身就是一种享受。它能让读者精神振奋，并在文章结束后依然萦绕心头。

The perfect ending should take your readers slightly by surprise and yet seem exactly right. They didn’t expect the article to end so soon, or so abruptly, or to say what it said. But they know it when they see it. Like a good lead, it works. It’s like the curtain line in a theatrical comedy. We are in the middle of a scene (we think), when suddenly one of the actors says something funny, or outrageous, or epigrammatic, and the lights go out. We are startled to find the scene over, and then delighted by the aptness of how it ended. What delights us is the playwright’s perfect control.

完美的结尾应该让读者略感意外，却又恰到好处。他们没想到文章会这么快、这么突然地结束，或者会说出这样的话。但他们一眼就明白了。就像好的开头一样，它奏效了。这就像戏剧喜剧的落幕。我们正沉浸在剧情中（我们以为是这样），突然，一个演员说了句滑稽的、出格的或精辟的话，灯光熄灭了。我们惊讶地发现剧情结束了，然后又为结尾的巧妙而欣喜。让我们感到欣喜的是剧作家完美的掌控力。

For the nonfiction writer, the simplest way of putting this into a rule is: when you’re ready to stop, stop. If you have presented all the facts and made the point you want to make, look for the nearest exit.

对于非虚构类作家来说，最简单的概括就是：当你准备停下来的时候，就停下来。如果你已经呈现了所有事实，表达了你想表达的观点，那就找个最近的出口。

Often it takes just a few sentences to wrap things up. Ideally they should encapsulate the idea of the piece and conclude with a sentence that jolts us with its fitness or unexpectedness. Here’s how H. L. Mencken ends his appraisal of President Calvin Coolidge, whose appeal to the “customers” was that his “government governed hardly at all; thus the ideal of Jefferson was realized at last, and the Jeffersonians were delighted”:

通常只需寥寥数语即可总结全文。理想情况下，这些句子应该概括文章的主旨，并以一句恰到好处或出人意料的句子结尾，令人眼前一亮。以下是H·L·门肯在评价卡尔文·柯立芝总统时所做的结尾。柯立芝向“选民”宣称，他的“政府几乎不作任何干预；因此，杰斐逊的理想最终得以实现，杰斐逊的支持者们欣喜若狂”：

We suffer most, not when the White House is a peaceful dormitory, but when it [has] a tin-pot Paul bawling from the roof. Counting out Harding as a cipher only, Dr. Coolidge was preceded by one World Saver and followed by two more. What enlightened American, having to choose between any of them and another Coolidge, would hesitate for an instant? There were no thrills while he reigned, but neither were there any headaches. He had no ideas, and he was not a nuisance.

我们最痛苦的时候，不是白宫像个宁静的宿舍，而是当一个像保罗·柯立芝那样的庸才在屋顶上嚎叫的时候。撇开哈丁这个无足轻重的人物不谈，柯立芝博士之前有一位“世界救星”，之后又有两位。哪个有识之士，要在他们之中选一个，再选另一个柯立芝，会犹豫片刻呢？他执政期间没有惊天动地的大事，但也没有任何麻烦。他没有什么真知灼见，但也不令人厌烦。

The five short sentences send the reader on his way quickly and with an arresting thought to take along. The notion of Coolidge having no ideas and not being a nuisance can’t help leaving a residue of enjoyment. It works.

这五句简短的句子迅速将读者带入正题，并留下一个引人深思的思考。柯立芝没有真知灼见，却又不惹麻烦——这种设定本身就令人回味无穷。它确实奏效了。

Something I often do in my writing is to bring the story full circle—to strike at the end an echo of a note that was sounded at the beginning. It gratifies my sense of symmetry, and it also pleases the reader, completing with its resonance the journey we set out on together.

我写作时经常会采用一种首尾呼应的手法——在结尾处呼应开头出现的某个音符，使故事形成一个完整的首尾呼应。这既满足了我对对称性的追求，也让读者感到愉悦，这种呼应为我们共同开启的旅程画上了一个圆满的句号。

But what usually works best is a quotation. Go back through your notes to find some remark that has a sense of finality, or that’s funny, or that adds an unexpected closing detail. Sometimes it will jump out at you during the interview—I’ve often thought, “That’s my ending!”—or during the process of writing. In the mid-1960s, when Woody Allen was just becoming established as America’s resident neurotic, doing nightclub monologues, I wrote the first long magazine piece that took note of his arrival. It ended like this:

但通常来说，引用一句名言效果最好。回顾你的笔记，找到一些带有终结感、幽默感或能增添意想不到的结尾细节的评论。有时，它会在采访过程中突然闪现——我经常会想，“这就是我的结尾！”——或者在写作过程中。上世纪60年代中期，伍迪·艾伦刚刚凭借夜总会独白表演成为美国公认的神经质偶像，我写了第一篇长篇杂志文章来记录他的崛起。文章的结尾是这样的：

“If people come away relating to me as a person,” Allen says, “rather than just enjoying my jokes; if they come away wanting to hear me again, no matter what I might talk about, then I’m succeeding.” Judging by the returns, he is. Woody Allen is Mr. Related-To, and he seems a good bet to hold the franchise for many years.

“如果人们看完我的表演后能与我产生共鸣，”艾伦说，“而不仅仅是喜欢我的笑话；如果他们看完后还想再听我讲，无论我讲什么，那我就成功了。” 从观众的反应来看，他的确成功了。伍迪·艾伦堪称“感同身受先生”，而且他似乎很有可能在未来很多年里继续保持这一地位。

Yet he does have a problem all his own, unshared by, unrelated to, the rest of America. “I’m obsessed,” he says, “by the fact that my mother genuinely resembles Groucho Marx.”

但他确实有一个自己独有的问题，这个问题与美国其他地区的人无关，也与其他人无关。“我着迷于，”他说，“我母亲真的长得像格劳乔·马克斯。”

There’s a remark from so far out in left field that nobody could see it coming. The surprise it carries is tremendous. How could it not be a perfect ending? Surprise is the most refreshing element in nonfiction writing. If something surprises you it will also surprise—and delight—the people you are writing for, especially as you conclude your story and send them on their way.

有一句出人意料的评论，谁也没想到。它带来的惊喜巨大。这怎能不是一个完美的结尾呢？惊喜是非虚构写作中最令人耳目一新的元素。如果某件事让你感到惊讶，那么它也会给你的读者带来惊喜和愉悦，尤其是在你结束故事、送他们离开的时候。

#↩

10

Bits & Pieces

零碎信息

This is a chapter of scraps and morsels—small admonitions on many points that I have collected under one, as they say, umbrella.

这是零碎的篇章——我将许多要点的小小告诫汇集在一个小小范围内，正如他们所说。

V ERBS .

动词。

Use active verbs unless there is no comfortable way to get around using a passive verb. The difference between an activeverb style and a passive-verb style—in clarity and vigor—is the difference between life and death for a writer.

除非实在没有其他更合适的办法，否则尽量使用主动语态。主动语态和被动语态在清晰度和力度上的差异，对写作者而言，关乎生死。

“Joe saw him” is strong. “He was seen by Joe” is weak. The first is short and precise; it leaves no doubt about who did what. The second is necessarily longer and it has an insipid quality: something was done by somebody to someone else. It’s also ambiguous. How often was he seen by Joe? Once? Every day? Once a week? A style that consists of passive constructions will sap the reader’s energy. Nobody ever quite knows what is being perpetrated by whom and on whom.

“乔看见了他”这句话很有力。“他被乔看见了”则显得苍白无力。前者简洁明了，毫不含糊地说明了谁做了什么。后者则必然冗长，显得平淡乏味：某事是由某人对另一个人做的。而且，它还含糊不清。乔究竟多久看见他一次？一次？每天？一周一次？充斥着被动语态的表达方式会消耗读者的精力。没有人能确切地知道究竟是谁对谁做了什么。

I use “perpetrated” because it’s the kind of word that passive-voice writers are fond of. They prefer long words of Latin origin to short Anglo-Saxon words—which compounds their trouble and makes their sentences still more glutinous. Short is better than long. Of the 701 words in Lincoln’s Second Inaugural Address, a marvel of economy in itself, 505 are words of one syllable and 122 are words of two syllables.

我用“perpetrated”这个词，是因为被动语态的作者们偏爱这类词。他们更喜欢拉丁语系的长词，而不是盎格鲁-撒克逊语系的短词——这反而加剧了他们的写作问题，使他们的句子更加冗长拖沓。短比长好。林肯的第二次就职演说只有701个单词，本身就是语言精炼的奇迹，其中505个是单音节词，122个是双音节词。

Verbs are the most important of all your tools. They push the sentence forward and give it momentum. Active verbs push hard; passive verbs tug fitfully. Active verbs also enable us to visualize an activity because they require a pronoun (“he”), or a noun (“the boy”), or a person (“Mrs. Scott”) to put them in motion. Many verbs also carry in their imagery or in their sound a suggestion of what they mean: glitter, dazzle, twirl, beguile, scatter, swagger, poke, pamper, vex. Probably no other language has such a vast supply of verbs so bright with color. Don’t choose one that is dull or merely serviceable. Make active verbs activate your sentences, and avoid the kind that need an appended preposition to complete their work. Don’t set up a business that you can start or launch. Don’t say that the president of the company stepped down. Did he resign? Did he retire? Did he get fired? Be precise. Use precise verbs.

动词是你所有工具中最重要的一种。它们推动句子向前发展，赋予句子动力。主动动词有力地推动，被动动词则拖沓地拉扯。主动动词还能让我们想象出一个动作，因为它们需要代词（“他”）、名词（“那个男孩”）或人名（“斯科特夫人”）来引导。许多动词的意象或发音本身就暗示着它们的含义：闪耀、炫目、旋转、诱惑、散落、趾高气扬、戳、宠爱、惹恼。或许没有其他语言拥有如此丰富多彩的动词。不要选择那些枯燥乏味或仅仅实用的动词。让主动动词激活你的句子，并避免使用那些需要附加介词才能完成功能的动词。不要说你可以开始或启动一项业务。不要说公司总裁辞职了。他是辞职了吗？他是退休了吗？他是被解雇了吗？要准确。使用精确的动词。

If you want to see how active verbs give vitality to the written word, don’t just go back to Hemingway or Thurber or Thoreau. I commend the King James Bible and William Shakespeare.

如果你想了解活跃的动词如何赋予文字生命力，不要只去看海明威、瑟伯或梭罗的作品。我推荐《钦定版圣经》和威廉·莎士比亚的作品。

A DVERBS .

副词。

Most adverbs are unnecessary. You will clutter your sentence and annoy the reader if you choose a verb that has a specific meaning and then add an adverb that carries the same meaning. Don’t tell us that the radio blared loudly; “blare” connotes loudness. Don’t write that someone clenched his teeth tightly; there’s no other way to clench teeth. Again and again in careless writing, strong verbs are weakened by redundant adverbs. So are adjectives and other parts of speech: “effortlessly easy,” “slightly spartan,” “totally flabbergasted.” The beauty of “flabbergasted” is that it implies an astonishment that is total; I can’t picture someone being partly flabbergasted. If an action is so easy as to be effortless, use “effortless.” And what is “slightly spartan”? Perhaps a monk’s cell with wall-to-wall carpeting. Don’t use adverbs unless they do necessary work. Spare us the news that the winning athlete grinned widely.

大多数副词都是不必要的。如果你选择一个含义明确的动词，然后又加上一个意思相同的副词，你的句子就会显得冗长，让读者感到厌烦。不要说收音机大声地播放着；“大声地”本身就表示音量大。不要写某人紧紧地咬着牙；咬牙没有其他表达方式。在粗心的写作中，我们常常看到，强有力的动词因为冗余的副词而显得苍白无力。形容词和其他词类也同样如此，例如“毫不费力地轻松”、“略显简朴”、“完全震惊”。“完全震惊”的妙处在于它暗示了一种彻底的惊讶；我无法想象有人会只是略感震惊。如果一个动作轻松到毫不费力，那就用“毫不费力”。那么“略显简朴”是什么意思呢？也许是指铺满地毯的僧侣房间。除非必要，否则不要使用副词。别告诉我们获胜的运动员咧嘴大笑了。

And while we’re at it, let’s retire “decidedly” and all its slippery cousins. Every day I see in the paper that some situations are decidedly better and others are decidedly worse, but I never know how decided the improvement is, or who did the deciding, just as I never know how eminent a result is that’s eminently fair, or whether to believe a fact that’s arguably true. “He’s arguably the best pitcher on the Mets,” the preening sportswriter writes, aspiring to Parnassus, which Red Smith reached by never using words like “arguably.” Is the pitcher—it can be proved by argument—the best pitcher on the team? If so, please omit “arguably.” Or is he perhaps —the opinion is open to argument—the best pitcher? Admittedly I don’t know. It’s virtually a toss-up.

既然说到这儿，不如咱们干脆把“绝对地”以及所有类似的模糊说法都弃用吧。我每天在报纸上看到，有些情况明显好转，有些情况明显恶化，但我从来不知道这种改善究竟有多明显，也不知道是谁做出的决定，就像我从来不知道一个“绝对公平”的结果究竟有多显著，也不知道一个“可能正确”的事实是否可信一样。“他可以说是大都会队最好的投手，”那些自鸣得意的体育记者写道，一心想攀登帕那索斯山——就像雷德·史密斯那样，他从不用“可能”这样的词就能登顶。这位投手——这可以通过论证来证明——真的是队里最好的投手吗？如果是，那就请省略“可能”。或者，他或许——这个观点尚待商榷——是最好的投手？说实话，我也不知道。这几乎是五五开。

A DJECTIVES .

形容词。

Most adjectives are also unnecessary. Like adverbs, they are sprinkled into sentences by writers who don’t stop to think that the concept is already in the noun. This kind of prose is littered with precipitous cliffs and lacy spiderwebs, or with adjectives denoting the color of an object whose color is well known: yellow daffodils and brownish dirt. If you want to make a value judgment about daffodils, choose an adjective like “garish.” If you’re in a part of the country where the dirt is red, feel free to mention the red dirt. Those adjectives would do a job that the noun alone wouldn’t be doing.

大多数形容词都是不必要的。和副词一样，它们被一些作者随意地添加到句子中，而没有仔细思考名词本身已经表达了相应的概念。这类文章充斥着“陡峭的悬崖”和“精致的蜘蛛网”之类的形容词，或者用形容词来描述颜色众所周知的物体：比如“黄色的水仙花”和“棕色的泥土”。如果你想对水仙花做出价值判断，可以选择像“艳丽的”这样的形容词。如果你身处一个泥土是红色的地区，那就直接提到红色的泥土。这些形容词的作用，是名词本身无法达到的。

Most writers sow adjectives almost unconsciously into the soil of their prose to make it more lush and pretty, and the sentences become longer and longer as they fill up with stately elms and frisky kittens and hard-bitten detectives and sleepy lagoons. This is adjective-by-habit—a habit you should get rid of. Not every oak has to be gnarled. The adjective that exists solely as decoration is a self-indulgence for the writer and a burden for the reader.

大多数作家几乎无意识地在散文中撒播形容词，使其更加丰盈优美，句子也因此越写越长，充斥着高耸的榆树、活泼的小猫、老练的侦探和宁静的泻湖。这是一种习惯性的形容词堆砌——一种你应该摒弃的习惯。并非每一棵橡树都必须虬曲苍劲。仅仅作为装饰而存在的形容词，对作者而言是一种自我放纵，对读者而言则是一种负担。

Again, the rule is simple: make your adjectives do work that needs to be done. “He looked at the gray sky and the black clouds and decided to sail back to the harbor.” The darkness of the sky and the clouds is the reason for the decision. If it’s important to tell the reader that a house was drab or a girl was beautiful, by all means use “drab” and “beautiful.” They will have their proper power because you have learned to use adjectives sparsely.

再次强调，规则很简单：让形容词发挥作用。“他望着灰蒙蒙的天空和乌云，决定驶回港口。”天空和乌云的阴沉正是他做出这个决定的原因。如果一定要告诉读者一栋房子很简陋，或者一个女孩很漂亮，那就用“简陋”和“漂亮”吧。因为你已经学会了谨慎使用形容词，所以它们才能发挥应有的作用。

L ITTLE Q UALIFIERS .

一些小资格赛。

Prune out the small words that qualify how you feel and how you think and what you saw: “a bit,” “a little,” “sort of,” “kind of,” “rather,” “quite,” “very,” “too,” “pretty much,” “in a sense” and dozens more. They dilute your style and your persuasiveness.

删掉那些修饰你感受、想法和所见所闻的小词，比如“有点”、“一点点”、“算是”、“有点像”、“相当”、“非常”、“太”、“几乎”、“某种程度上”等等。它们会削弱你的表达风格和说服力。

Don’t say you were a bit confused and sort of tired and a little depressed and somewhat annoyed. Be confused. Be tired. Be depressed. Be annoyed. Don’t hedge your prose with little timidities. Good writing is lean and confident.

别说你有点困惑、有点累、有点沮丧、还有点恼火。就坦诚地表达你的困惑、疲惫、沮丧和恼火。别让你的文字充满怯懦。好的文字简洁而自信。

Don’t say you weren’t too happy because the hotel was pretty expensive. Say you weren’t happy because the hotel was expensive. Don’t tell us you were quite fortunate. How fortunate is that? Don’t describe an event as rather spectacular or very awesome. Words like “spectacular” and “awesome” don’t submit to measurement. “Very” is a useful word to achieve emphasis, but far more often it’s clutter. There’s no need to call someone very methodical. Either he is methodical or he isn’t.

别说你不太高兴是因为酒店太贵。直接说你不高兴是因为酒店贵。别说你很幸运。到底有多幸运？别把某件事描述成“相当精彩”或“非常棒”。“精彩”和“非常棒”这样的词无法量化。“非常”这个词可以用来强调，但更多时候它只是冗余。没必要说某人做事很有条理。他要么有条理，要么没有。

The large point is one of authority. Every little qualifier whittles away some fraction of the reader’s trust. Readers want a writer who believes in himself and in what he is saying. Don’t diminish that belief. Don’t be kind of bold. Be bold.

关键在于权威性。每一个小小的限定词都会削弱读者的信任。读者想要的是一个对自己和自己所说的话都充满信心的作者。不要削弱这种信心。不要只是略带自信，要真正自信。

P UNCTUATION .

标点。

These are brief thoughts on punctuation, in no way intended as a primer. If you don’t know how to punctuate—and many college students still don’t—get a grammar book.

以上是关于标点符号的一些简要思考，绝非入门指南。如果你不知道如何使用标点符号——很多大学生仍然不知道——那就去买一本语法书吧。

The Period . There’s not much to be said about the period except that most writers don’t reach it soon enough. If you find yourself hopelessly mired in a long sentence, it’s probably because you’re trying to make the sentence do more than it can reasonably do—perhaps express two dissimilar thoughts. The quickest way out is to break the long sentence into two short sentences, or even three. There is no minimum length for a sentence that’s acceptable in the eyes of God. Among good writers it is the short sentence that predominates, and don’t tell me about Norman Mailer—he’s a genius. If you want to write long sentences, be a genius. Or at least make sure that the sentence is under control from beginning to end, in syntax and punctuation, so that the reader knows where he is at every step of the winding trail.

句号。关于句号，其实没什么好说的，除了大多数作家都未能及时用到它。如果你发现自己深陷于一个冗长的句子中无法自拔，那很可能是因为你试图让句子承载超出其合理范围的内容——比如表达两个截然不同的想法。最快的解决办法是将长句拆分成两个短句，甚至三个。在上帝眼中，句子的长度并没有一个最低标准。优秀的作家大多使用短句，别跟我提诺曼·梅勒——他可是个天才。如果你想写长句，那就努力成为天才吧。或者至少要确保句子从头到尾都符合语法和标点规范，让读者在阅读过程中始终保持清晰的思路。

The Exclamation Point . Don’t use it unless you must to achieve a certain effect. It has a gushy aura, the breathless excitement of a debutante commenting on an event that was exciting only to her: “Daddy says I must have had too much champagne!” “But honestly, I could have danced all night!” We have all suffered more than our share of these sentences in which an exclamation point knocks us over the head with how cute or wonderful something was. Instead, construct your sentence so that the order of the words will put the emphasis where you want it. Also resist using an exclamation point to notify the reader that you are making a joke or being ironic. “It never occurred to me that the water pistol might be loaded!” Readers are annoyed by your reminder that this was a comical moment. They are also robbed of the pleasure of finding it funny on their own. Humor is best achieved by understatement, and there’s nothing subtle about an exclamation point.

感叹号。除非为了达到某种特定效果，否则不要使用。它给人一种矫揉造作的感觉，就像初次参加舞会的年轻女子兴奋地描述只有她自己才觉得激动的事情：“爸爸说我一定是香槟喝多了！”“但说真的，我真想跳一整晚！”我们都受够了这种句子，感叹号仿佛要把我们震晕，让我们觉得某件事多么可爱或多么精彩。相反，你应该组织句子，让词语的顺序自然地把重点放在你想要强调的地方。此外，也不要用感叹号来告诉读者你在开玩笑或讽刺。“我怎么没想到水枪里可能有子弹！”读者会因为你提醒他们这是一个滑稽的瞬间而感到恼火。他们也因此失去了自己发现幽默的乐趣。幽默的最佳方式是含蓄地表达，而感叹号恰恰与含蓄毫不沾边。

The Semicolon . There is a 19th-century mustiness that hangs over the semicolon.
