We associate it with the carefully balanced sentences, the judicious weighing of “on the one hand” and “on the other hand,” of Conrad and Thackeray and Hardy. Therefore it should be used sparingly by modern writers of nonfiction. Yet I notice that it turns up quite often in the passages I’ve quoted in this book and that I use it often myself—usually to add a related thought to the first half of a sentence. Still, the semicolon brings the reader, if not to a halt, at least to a pause. So use it with discretion, remembering that it will slow to a Victorian pace the early-21st-century momentum you’re striving for, and rely instead on the period and the dash.

分号。分号似乎总是带着一丝十九世纪的陈旧感。我们常常把它与康拉德、萨克雷和哈代笔下那些精心平衡的句子、对“一方面”和“另一方面”的巧妙权衡联系起来。因此，现代非虚构作家应该谨慎使用分号。然而，我注意到，在我本书引用的段落中，分号出现的频率相当高，我自己也经常使用它——通常是为了在句子的前半部分添加一个相关的想法。尽管如此，分号仍然会让读者停顿，即使不会完全停止阅读。所以，请谨慎使用分号，记住它会将你力求营造的二十一世纪初的流畅节奏放慢到维多利亚时代的水平，因此，最好还是使用句号和破折号。

The Dash . Somehow this invaluable tool is widely regarded as not quite proper—a bumpkin at the genteel dinner table of good English. But it has full membership and will get you out of many tight corners. The dash is used in two ways. One is to amplify or justify in the second part of the sentence a thought you stated in the first part. “We decided to keep going—it was only 100 miles more and we could get there in time for dinner.” By its very shape the dash pushes the sentence ahead and explains why they decided to keep going. The other use involves two dashes, which set apart a parenthetical thought within a longer sentence. “She told me to get in the car—she had been after me all summer to have a haircut—and we drove silently into town.” An explanatory detail that might otherwise have required a separate sentence is neatly dispatched along the way.

破折号。不知为何，这个无比重要的工具却被普遍认为不够正式——就像一个乡巴佬闯进了优雅的英语餐桌。但它其实拥有完整的语法规则，而且能帮你摆脱许多困境。破折号有两种用法。一种是在句末补充或解释句首表达的观点。“我们决定继续前进——只剩100英里了，我们肯定能赶上吃晚饭。”破折号本身就推动了句子的前进，并解释了他们为什么决定继续前进。另一种用法是使用两个破折号，将插入语与较长句子分开。“她叫我上车——整个夏天她都催着我去剪头发——然后我们默默地开车进了城。”一个原本可能需要单独成句的解释性细节，就这样巧妙地融入了句子之中。

The Colon . The colon has begun to look even more antique than the semicolon, and many of its functions have been taken over by the dash. But it still serves well its pure role of bringing your sentence to a brief halt before you plunge into, say, an itemized list. “The brochure said the ship would stop at the following ports: Oran, Algiers, Naples, Brindisi, Piraeus, Istanbul and Beirut.” You can’t beat the colon for work like that.

冒号。冒号如今看起来比分号还要古老，它的许多功能也被破折号取代了。但它仍然很好地履行着其纯粹的职责：在句子开始列举细节之前，短暂地停顿一下。“宣传册上说，这艘船将停靠以下港口：奥兰、阿尔及尔、那不勒斯、布林迪西、比雷埃夫斯、伊斯坦布尔和贝鲁特。” 在这种表达方式上，冒号的作用无可替代。

M OOD C HANGERS .

情绪调节剂。

Learn to alert the reader as soon as possible to any change in mood from the previous sentence. At least a dozen words will do this job for you: “but,” “yet,” “however,” “nevertheless,” “still,” “instead,” “thus,” “therefore,” “meanwhile,” “now,” “later,” “today,” “subsequently” and several more. I can’t overstate how much easier it is for readers to process a sentence if you start with “but” when you’re shifting direction. Or, conversely, how much harder it is if they must wait until the end to realize that you have shifted.

要学会尽早提醒读者句子语气与前一句有所不同。至少十几个词就能帮你做到这一点，例如：“但是”、“然而”、“不过”、“尽管如此”、“仍然”、“相反”、“因此”、“所以”、“同时”、“现在”、“稍后”、“今天”、“随后”等等。如果在转换语气时以“但是”开头，读者理解起来会容易得多。反之，如果读者必须等到文章结尾才能意识到语气的变化，理解起来就会困难得多。

Many of us were taught that no sentence should begin with “but.” If that’s what you learned, unlearn it—there’s no stronger word at the start. It announces total contrast with what has gone before, and the reader is thereby primed for the change. If you need relief from too many sentences beginning with “but,” switch to “however.” It is, however, a weaker word and needs careful placement. Don’t start a sentence with “however”—it hangs there like a wet dishrag. And don’t end with “however”—by that time it has lost its howeverness. Put it as early as you reasonably can, as I did three sentences ago. Its abruptness then becomes a virtue.

我们很多人都被教导过句子不应该以“但是”开头。如果你也这样认为，那就赶紧改掉这个习惯——没有比“但是”更强有力的词可以放在句首了。它与前面的内容形成鲜明的对比，让读者做好迎接变化的准备。如果你觉得“但是”开头的句子太多，不妨换成“然而”。不过，“然而”的语气较弱，需要谨慎使用。不要用“然而”开头——它就像一块湿抹布一样挂在那里。也不要用“然而”结尾——到那时，它就失去了原本的“然而”之感。尽可能把它放在句首，就像我三句话前那样。这样，它的突兀反而会成为一种优势。

“Yet” does almost the same job as “but,” though its meaning is closer to “nevertheless.” Either of those words at the beginning of a sentence—“Yet he decided to go” or “Nevertheless he decided to go”—can replace a whole long phrase that summarizes what the reader has just been told: “Despite the fact that all these dangers had been pointed out to him , he decided to go.” Look for all the places where one of these short words will instantly convey the same meaning as a long and dismal clause. “Instead I took the train.” “Still I had to admire him.” “Thus I learned how to smoke.” “It was therefore easy to meet him.” “Meanwhile I had talked to John.” What a vast amount of huffing and puffing these pivotal words save! (The exclamation point is to show that I really mean it.)

“yet”的作用几乎和“but”一样，尽管它的意思更接近“尽管如此”。这两个词放在句首——“yet he decided to go”或“Nevertheless he decided to go”——都可以代替一大段总结刚刚告诉读者的内容的短语：“尽管所有这些危险都被指出来，他还是决定去。” 留意一下，看看有多少地方，这两个词能瞬间表达出与冗长乏味的从句相同的意思。“我改乘火车了。”“我仍然不得不钦佩他。”“就这样，我学会了抽烟。”“因此，很容易就能见到他。”“与此同时，我和约翰聊了聊。” 这些关键的词语省去了多少冗长的赘述啊！（感叹号是为了表明我是真心这么认为的。）

As for “meanwhile,” “now,” “today” and “later,” what they also save is confusion, for careless writers often change their time frame without remembering to tip the reader off. “Now I know better.” “Today you can’t find such an item.” “Later I found out why.” Always make sure your readers are oriented. Always ask yourself where you left them in the previous sentence.

至于“与此同时”、“现在”、“今天”和“稍后”，它们还能避免读者感到困惑，因为粗心的作者经常会随意改变时间线，却忘记提醒读者。“现在我明白了。”“今天你找不到这样的东西了。”“后来我才知道为什么。”务必确保读者清楚自己在说什么。始终提醒自己，上一句话把他们带到了哪里。

C ONTRACTIONS .

缩写。

Your style will be warmer and truer to your personality if you use contractions like “I’ll” and “won’t” and “can’t” when they fit comfortably into what you’re writing. “I’ll be glad to see them if they don’t get mad” is less stiff than “I will be glad to see them if they do not get mad.” (Read that aloud and hear how stilted it sounds.) There’s no rule against such informality—trust your ear and your instincts. I only suggest avoiding one form—“I’d,” “he’d,” “we’d,” etc.—because “I’d” can mean both “I had” and “I would,” and readers can get well into a sentence before learning which meaning it is. Often it’s not the one they thought it was. Also, don’t invent contractions like “could’ve.” They cheapen your style. Stick with the ones you can find in the dictionary.

如果你在写作中恰当地使用“I’ll”、“won’t”和“can’t”等缩写，你的文风会更亲切，也更符合你的个性。“I’ll be glad to see them if they don’t get mad”比“I will be glad to see them if they do not get mad”更自然流畅。（不妨大声朗读一下，听听后者听起来多么生硬。）这种非正式的表达方式并没有什么硬性规定——相信你的耳朵和直觉。我建议你避免使用“I’d”、“he’d”、“we’d”等缩写形式，因为“I’d”既可以表示“I had”，也可以表示“I would”，读者可能要读到很后面才能弄明白它的意思。而且，它的意思往往和他们预想的不一样。另外，不要自创缩写，比如“could’ve”。它们会降低你的文风档次。坚持使用字典里能查到的缩写即可。

T HAT AND W HICH .

那个和哪个。

Anyone who tries to explain “that” and “which” in less than an hour is asking for trouble. Fowler, in his Modern English Usage , takes 25 columns of type. I’m going for two minutes, perhaps the world record. Here (I hope) is much of what you need to bear in mind:

任何试图在不到一小时内解释“that”和“which”用法的人都是在自找麻烦。福勒在他的《现代英语用法》中用了25栏的篇幅。我打算用两分钟，也许能打破世界纪录。以下（我希望）包含了你需要记住的大部分内容：

Always use “that” unless it makes your meaning ambiguous. Notice that in carefully edited magazines, such as The New Yorker , “that” is by far the predominant usage. I mention this because it is still widely believed—a residue from school and college—that “which” is more correct, more acceptable, more literary. It’s not. In most situations, “that” is what you would naturally say and therefore what you should write.

除非会使意思产生歧义，否则请始终使用“that”。请注意，在像《纽约客》这样经过精心编辑的杂志中，“that”的使用频率远高于其他语言。我之所以提到这一点，是因为很多人仍然普遍认为——这或许是学校教育的遗风——“which”更正确、更得体、更有文学性。事实并非如此。在大多数情况下，“that”才是你自然而然会说的话，因此也应该用来写作。

If your sentence needs a comma to achieve its precise meaning, it probably needs “which.” “Which” serves a particular identifying function, different from “that.” (A) “Take the shoes that are in the closet.” This means: take the shoes that are in the closet, not the ones under the bed. (B) “Take the shoes, which are in the closet.” Only one pair of shoes is under discussion; the “which” usage tells you where they are. Note that the comma is necessary in B, but not in A.

如果你的句子需要逗号才能准确表达意思，那很可能是因为需要用到“which”。“which”的作用是指明方向，与“that”不同。(A) “Take the shoes that are in the closet.” 这句话的意思是：拿走衣橱里的鞋子，而不是床底下的鞋子。(B) “Take the shoes, which are in the closet.” 这句话只讨论了一双鞋；“which”的用法告诉你鞋子在哪里。注意，句子B中需要逗号，而句子A中不需要。

A high proportion of “which” usages narrowly describe, or identify, or locate, or explain, or otherwise qualify the phrase that preceded the comma:

“which”的用法中，很大一部分是对逗号前面的短语进行狭义描述、识别、定位、解释或其他限定：

The house, which has a red roof,

那栋房子有着红色的屋顶，

The store, which is called Bob’s Hardware,

这家商店名叫鲍勃五金店。

The Rhine, which is in Germany,

莱茵河位于德国境内。

The monsoon, which is a seasonal wind,

季风，即季节性风，

The moon, which I saw from the porch,

我从门廊上看到的月亮，

That’s all I’m going to say that I think you initially need to know to write good nonfiction, which is a form that requires exact marshaling of information.

这就是我想说的，我认为要写出好的非虚构作品，首先需要了解的就是这些。非虚构作品是一种需要精确组织信息的文体。

C ONCEPT N OUNS .

概念名词。

Nouns that express a concept are commonly used in bad writing instead of verbs that tell what somebody did. Here are three typical dead sentences:

在糟糕的写作中，人们常常用表达概念的名词代替描述动作的动词。以下是三个典型的死句：

The common reaction is incredulous laughter.

人们普遍的反应是难以置信的笑声。

Bemused cynicism isn’t the only response to the old system.

困惑的愤世嫉俗并不是对旧制度的唯一反应。

The current campus hostility is a symptom of the change.

当前校园内的敌对情绪正是这种变化的征兆。

What is so eerie about these sentences is that they have no people in them. They also have no working verbs—only “is” or “isn’t.” The reader can’t visualize anybody performing some activity; all the meaning lies in impersonal nouns that embody a vague concept: “reaction,” “cynicism,” “response,” “hostility.” Turn these cold sentences around. Get people doing things:

这些句子令人毛骨悚然之处在于，它们没有人物。它们也没有动词——只有“是”或“不是”。读者无法想象任何人进行某种活动；所有的意义都体现在体现模糊概念的不带人称的名词上：“反应”、“愤世嫉俗”、“回应”、“敌意”。请改变这些冷冰冰的句子。让人物动起来：

Most people just laugh with disbelief.

大多数人只是难以置信地大笑。

Some people respond to the old system by turning cynical; others say …

有些人对旧体制感到愤世嫉俗；另一些人则说……

It’s easy to notice the change—you can see how angry all the students are.

变化显而易见——你可以看出所有学生都很生气。

My revised sentences aren’t jumping with vigor, partly because the material I’m trying to knead into shape is shapeless dough. But at least they have real people and real verbs. Don’t get caught holding a bag full of abstract nouns. You’ll sink to the bottom of the lake and never be seen again.

我修改后的句子不够生动有力，部分原因是，我试图塑造的素材就像一块没有形状的面团。但至少它们有真实的人物和动词。千万别让自己陷入满是抽象名词的陷阱，否则你会沉入湖底，永远消失不见。

C REEPING N OUNISM .

悄然蔓延的诺尼主义。

This is a new American disease that strings two or three nouns together where one noun—or, better yet, one verb—will do. Nobody goes broke now; we have money problem areas. It no longer rains; we have precipitation activity or a thunderstorm probability situation. Please, let it rain.

这是一种美国新出现的毛病，它把两三个名词串在一起，其实一个名词——或者更好的选择是，一个动词——就能表达清楚。现在没人会破产了；我们只是说存在资金问题。现在不再下雨了；我们只是说有降水活动或雷暴概率。拜托，下雨吧。

Today as many as four or five concept nouns will attach themselves to each other, like a molecule chain. Here’s a brilliant specimen I recently found: “Communication facilitation skills development intervention.” Not a person in sight, or a working verb. I think it’s a program to help students write better.

如今，多达四五个概念名词会像分子链一样连接在一起。我最近发现了一个绝妙的例子：“沟通促进技能发展干预”。里面既没有出现人名，也没有动词。我猜这应该是一个帮助学生提高写作能力的课程。

O VERSTATEMENT .

夸大其词。

“The living room looked as if an atomic bomb had gone off there,” writes the novice writer, describing what he saw on Sunday morning after a party that got out of hand. Well, we all know he’s exaggerating to make a droll point, but we also know that an atomic bomb didn’t go off there, or any other bomb except maybe a water bomb. “I felt as if ten 747 jets were flying through my brain,” he writes, “and I seriously considered jumping out the window and killing myself.” These verbal high jinks can get just so high—and this writer is already well over the limit—before the reader feels an overpowering drowsiness. It’s like being trapped with a man who can’t stop reciting limericks. Don’t overstate. You didn’t really consider jumping out the window. Life has more than enough truly horrible funny situations. Let the humor sneak up so we hardly hear it coming.

“客厅看起来就像被原子弹炸过一样，”这位新手作家写道，描述了周日早上一场失控的派对后他看到的景象。好吧，我们都知道他是在夸张地描述，为了博君一笑，但我们也知道那里并没有原子弹爆炸，或者说，除了水弹之外，什么炸弹都没炸。“我感觉好像有十架747客机在我脑子里飞来飞去，”他写道，“我认真地考虑过要不要跳窗自杀。”这种文字游戏玩笑玩到一定程度——而这位作家已经远远超过了限度——读者就会感到昏昏欲睡。这就像被困在一个不停背诵五行打油诗的人身边。别夸大其词。你根本没想过要跳窗。生活中已经有很多既可怕又好笑的场景了。让幽默悄悄地出现，让我们几乎察觉不到它的到来。

C REDIBILITY .

信誉度。

Credibility is just as fragile for a writer as for a President. Don’t inflate an incident to make it more outlandish than it actually was. If the reader catches you in just one bogus statement that you are trying to pass off as true, everything you write thereafter will be suspect. It’s too great a risk, and not worth taking.

对于作家而言，信誉与总统一样脆弱。不要夸大事件，使其显得比实际情况更加离奇。如果读者识破了你试图伪装成事实的虚假陈述，那么你之后写的一切都会受到怀疑。风险太大，得不偿失。

D ICTATION .

听写。

Much of the “writing” done in America is done by dictation. Administrators, executives, managers, educators and other officials think in terms of using their time efficiently. They think the quickest way of getting something “written” is to dictate it to a secretary and never look at it. This is false economy—they save a few hours and blow their whole personality. Dictated sentences tend to be pompous, sloppy and redundant. Executives who are so busy that they can’t avoid dictating should at least find time to edit what they have dictated, crossing words out and putting words in, making sure that what they finally write is a true reflection of who they are, especially if it’s a document that will go to customers who will judge their personality and their company on the basis of their style.

在美国，很多“写作”都是通过口述完成的。行政人员、高管、经理、教育工作者和其他官员都以高效利用时间为目标。他们认为最快捷的“写作”方式就是口述给秘书，然后自己再不看。这是一种得不偿失的做法——他们虽然节省了几个小时，却暴露了自身的个性。口述的句子往往矫揉造作、马虎冗赘。那些忙到不得不口述的高管至少应该抽出时间来编辑口述的内容，删改修改，确保最终写出来的东西能够真实反映他们的个人风格，尤其是在这份文件会交给客户的情况下，客户会根据他们的写作风格来评判他们的个性和公司。

W RITING I S N OT A C ONTEST .

写作不是比赛。

Every writer is starting from a different point and is bound for a different destination. Yet many writers are paralyzed by the thought that they are competing with everybody else who is trying to write and presumably doing it better. This can often happen in a writing class. Inexperienced students are chilled to find themselves in the same class with students whose byline has appeared in the college newspaper. But writing for the college paper is no great credential; I’ve often found that the hares who write for the paper are overtaken by the tortoises who move studiously toward the goal of mastering the craft. The same fear hobbles freelance writers, who see the work of other writers appearing in magazines while their own keeps returning in the mail. Forget the competition and go at your own pace. Your only contest is with yourself.

每个作家的起点都不同，最终的目的地也各不相同。然而，许多作家却因为觉得自己在和所有写作的人竞争，而且这些人可能比他们写得更好，而裹足不前。这种情况在写作课上尤为常见。缺乏经验的学生发现自己和那些已经在校报上发表过文章的同学同班，难免会感到紧张。但为校报撰稿并非什么了不起的成就；我经常发现，那些急于求成的“兔子”最终会被那些步履蹒跚、努力钻研写作技巧的“乌龟”超越。同样的恐惧也困扰着自由撰稿人，他们眼看着其他作家的作品频频出现在杂志上，而自己的稿件却不断被退回。忘掉竞争吧，按照自己的节奏来。你唯一的对手就是你自己。

T HE S UBCONSCIOUS M IND .

潜意识。

Your subconscious mind does more writing than you think. Often you’ll spend a whole day trying to fight your way out of some verbal thicket in which you seem to be tangled beyond salvation. Frequently a solution will occur to you the next morning when you plunge back in. While you slept, your writer’s mind didn’t. A writer is always working. Stay alert to the currents around you. Much of what you see and hear will come back, having percolated for days or months or even years through your subconscious mind, just when your conscious mind, laboring to write, needs it.

你的潜意识比你想象的更擅长写作。你常常会花上一整天的时间，试图从看似无解的文字困境中挣脱出来。但往往第二天早上，当你重新投入写作时，解决方案就会突然涌现。在你睡觉的时候，你的写作思维并没有停止运转。作家总是在工作。时刻留意周围的动静。你所见所闻的大部分内容，会在你潜意识中酝酿数日、数月甚至数年之久，在你努力写作的意识需要它们的时候，以某种形式重新出现。

T HE Q UICKEST F IX .

最快的解决方法。

Surprisingly often a difficult problem in a sentence can be solved by simply getting rid of it. Unfortunately, this solution is usually the last one that occurs to writers in a jam. First they will put the troublesome phrase through all kinds of exertions—moving it to some other part of the sentence, trying to rephrase it, adding new words to clarify the thought or to oil whatever is stuck. These efforts only make the situation worse, and the writer is left to conclude that there is no solution to the problem—not a comforting thought. When you find yourself at such an impasse, look at the troublesome element and ask, “Do I need it at all?” Probably you don’t. It was trying to do an unnecessary job all along—that’s why it was giving you so much grief. Remove it and watch the afflicted sentence spring to life and breathe normally. It’s the quickest cure and often the best.

令人惊讶的是，句子中一个棘手的问题往往只需将其删除即可解决。不幸的是，这种方法通常是陷入困境的作者最后才会想到的。他们首先会尝试各种方法来处理这个棘手的短语——把它移到句子的其他位置，尝试重新措辞，添加新词来阐明意思或润滑卡住的地方。这些努力只会让情况变得更糟，最终作者只能得出无解的结论——这可不是什么令人欣慰的消息。当你发现自己陷入这种困境时，不妨审视一下这个棘手的元素，问问自己：“我真的需要它吗？” 很可能你并不需要。它一直在做着不必要的工作——这就是它给你带来如此多麻烦的原因。把它删掉，你会发现这个饱受折磨的句子瞬间焕发生机，恢复了正常的呼吸。这是最快捷的解决方法，而且往往也是最好的。

P ARAGRAPHS .

段落。

Keep your paragraphs short. Writing is visual—it catches the eye before it has a chance to catch the brain. Short paragraphs put air around what you write and make it look inviting, whereas a long chunk of type can discourage a reader from even starting to read.

段落要简短。写作是一种视觉体验——它先吸引眼球，然后才有机会吸引大脑。短段落能让你的文字显得轻盈通透，更具吸引力；而冗长的段落则会让读者望而却步，甚至连阅读的念头都提不起。

Newspaper paragraphs should be only two or three sentences long; newspaper type is set in a narrow width, and the inches quickly add up. You may think such frequent paragraphing will damage the development of your point. Obviously The New Yorker is obsessed by this fear—a reader can go for miles without relief. Don’t worry; the gains far outweigh the hazards.

报纸段落最好只有两三句话；报纸的字体宽度较窄，积少成多。你或许会担心频繁分段会影响文章的展开。显然，《纽约客》杂志对此深有体会——读者可能会读上好几英里都找不到段落。别担心，这样做的好处远远大于弊端。

But don’t go berserk. A succession of tiny paragraphs is as annoying as a paragraph that’s too long. I’m thinking of all those midget paragraphs—verbless wonders—written by modern journalists to make their articles quick ’n’ easy. Actually they make the reader’s job harder by chopping up a natural train of thought. Compare the following two arrangements of the same article—how they look at a glance and how they read:

但别太过苛责。一连串的短小段落和过长的段落一样令人厌烦。我指的是现代记者为了让文章简洁易读而写的那些短小精悍的段落——简直是无语的奇迹。实际上，它们打断了读者自然的思路，反而增加了阅读难度。请比较同一篇文章的以下两种排版方式——乍一看和实际阅读体验：

The Associated Press version (left) , with its breezy paragraphing and verbless third and fourth sentences, is disruptive and condescending. “Yoo-hoo! Look how simple I’m making this for you!” the reporter is calling to us. My version (right) gives the reporter the dignity of writing good English and building three sentences into a logical unit.

美联社的版本（左图）段落划分轻松随意，第三句和第四句甚至没有动词，这种写法令人感到突兀和居高临下。“哇哦！瞧我把事情说得多简单！”记者仿佛在对我们喊道。我的版本（右图）则赋予了记者应有的尊严，让他能够用规范的英语写作，并将三个句子组织成一个逻辑完整的整体。

Paragraphing is a subtle but important element in writing nonfiction articles and books—a road map constantly telling your reader how you have organized your ideas. Study good nonfiction writers to see how they do it. You’ll find that almost all of them think in paragraph units, not in sentence units. Each paragraph has its own integrity of content and structure.

段落划分是非虚构类文章和书籍写作中一个微妙却至关重要的要素——它就像一张路线图，不断地向读者展示你是如何组织思路的。研究优秀的非虚构类作家是如何写作的，你会发现他们几乎都是以段落为单位进行思考，而不是以句子为单位。每个段落都有其自身的内容和结构完整性。

S EXISM .

性别歧视。

One of the most vexing new questions for writers is what to do about sexist language, especially the “he-she” pronoun. The feminist movement helpfully revealed how much sexism lurks in our language, not only in the offensive “he” but in the hundreds of words that carry an invidious meaning or some overtone of judgment. They are words that patronize (“gal”), or that imply second-class status (“poetess”), or a second-class role (“housewife”), or a certain kind of empty-headedness (“the girls”), or that demean the ability of a woman to do a certain kind of job (“lady lawyer”), or that are deliberately prurient (“divorcée,” “coed,” “blonde”) and are seldom applied to men. Men get mugged; a woman who gets mugged is a shapely stewardess or a pert brunette.

对于作家来说，最棘手的新问题之一是如何应对性别歧视语言，尤其是“他/她”代词。女权运动揭示了我们语言中潜藏的性别歧视，不仅体现在冒犯性的“他”这个代词上，还体现在数百个带有贬义或评判意味的词语中。这些词语带有居高临下的意味（“gal”），暗示女性的二等地位（“poetess”），或二等角色（“housewife”），或某种愚钝（“the girls”），或贬低女性从事特定工作的能力（“lady lawyer”），或故意带有淫秽色彩（“divorcée”、“coed”、“blonde”），而且很少用于男性。男性会被抢劫；而女性被抢劫时，人们会说她是身材曼妙的空姐或时髦的黑发女郎。

More damaging—and more subtle—are all the usages that treat women as possessions of the family male, not as people with their own identity who played an equal part in the family saga: “Early settlers pushed west with their wives and children.” Turn those settlers into pioneer families, or pioneer couples who went west with their sons and daughters, or men and women who settled the West. Today there are very few roles that aren’t open to both sexes. Don’t use constructions that suggest that only men can be settlers or farmers or cops or firefighters.

更具破坏性——也更隐蔽——的是那些将女性视为男性家庭附属品而非拥有独立身份、在家庭故事中扮演同等角色的用法：“早期定居者带着妻子和孩子向西迁徙。” 应该把这些定居者改成拓荒者家庭，或者带着儿女西行的拓荒者夫妇，或者定居西部的男女。如今，几乎所有职业都对男女开放。不要使用暗示只有男性才能成为定居者、农民、警察或消防员的表达方式。

A thornier problem is raised by the feminists’ annoyance with words that contain “man,” such as “chairman” and “spokesman.” Their point is that women can chair a committee as well as a man and are equally good at spoking. Hence the flurry of new words like “chairperson” and “spokeswoman.” Those makeshift words from the 1960s raised our consciousness about sex discrimination, both in words and in attitudes. But in the end they are makeshift words, sometimes hurting the cause more than helping it. One solution is to find another term: “chair” for “chairman,” “company representative” for “spokesman.” You can also convert the noun into a verb: “Speaking for the company, Ms. Jones said …” Where a certain occupation has both a masculine and a feminine form, look for a generic substitute. Actors and actresses can become performers.

更棘手的问题是，女权主义者对含有“man”（男性）的词语感到不满，例如“chairman”（主席）和“spokesman”（发言人）。她们认为，女性和男性一样可以担任委员会主席，而且同样擅长发言。因此，出现了“chairperson”（主席）和“spokeswoman”（女发言人）等新词。这些20世纪60年代的临时词汇提高了我们对性别歧视的意识，无论是在语言上还是在态度上。但归根结底，它们只是临时词汇，有时反而会损害事业。一个解决办法是寻找其他词语：用“chair”（主席）代替“chairman”（主席），用“company represent”（公司代表）代替“spokesman”（发言人）。你也可以将名词转化为动词：“琼斯女士代表公司发言……”。如果某个职业既有男性形式也有女性形式，那就寻找一个通用的替代词。演员可以变成表演者。

This still leaves the bothersome pronoun. “He” and “him” and “his” are words that rankle. “Every employee should decide what he thinks is best for him and his dependents.” What are we to do about these countless sentences? One solution is to turn them into the plural: “All employees should decide what they think is best for them and their dependents.” But this is good only in small doses. A style that converts every “he” into a “they” will quickly turn to mush.

这仍然留下了令人烦恼的代词问题。“他”、“他自己”和“他的”这些词让人感觉不舒服。“每位员工都应该决定什么对他自己和他的家属最有利。”我们该如何处理这些数不胜数的句子呢？一个解决办法是将它们改为复数形式：“所有员工都应该决定什么对他们自己和他们的家属最有利。”但这只能适度使用。如果把所有的“他”都变成“他们”，文章很快就会变得混乱不堪。

Another common solution is to use “or”: “Every employee should decide what he or she thinks is best for him or her.” But again, it should be used sparingly. Often a writer will find several situations in an article where he or she can use “he or she,” or “him or her,” if it seems natural. By “natural” I mean that the writer is serving notice that he (or she) has the problem in mind and is trying his (or her) best within reasonable limits. But let’s face it: the English language is stuck with the generic masculine (“Man shall not live by bread alone”). To turn every “he” into a “he or she,” and every “his” into a “his or her,” would clog the language.

另一种常见的解决方法是使用“或”：“每位员工都应该决定他或她认为最适合自己的方式。” 但同样，应该谨慎使用。通常，作者会在文章中找到一些可以使用“他或她”或“他/她”的情况，只要感觉自然即可。所谓“自然”，是指作者表明他/她已经考虑到了这个问题，并且正在合理范围内尽力而为。但我们必须承认：英语中普遍存在男性代词（“人活着不单靠面包”）。如果把所有的“他”都变成“他或她”，把所有的“他的”都变成“他或她”，语言就会变得臃肿不堪。

In early editions of On Writing Well I used “he” and “him” to refer to “the reader,” “the writer,” “the critic,” “the humorist,” etc. I felt that the book would be harder to read if I used “he or she” with every such mention. (I reject “he/she” altogether; the slant has no place in good English.) Over the years, however, many women wrote to nudge me about this. They said that as writers and readers themselves they resent always having to visualize a man doing the writing and reading, and they’re right; I stand nudged. Most of the nudgers urged me to adopt the plural: to use “readers” and “writers,” followed thereafter by “they.” I don’t like plurals; they weaken writing because they are less specific than the singular, less easy to visualize. I’d like every writer to visualize one reader struggling to read what he or she has written. Nevertheless I found three or four hundred places where I could eliminate “he,” “him,” “his,” “himself” or “man,” mainly by switching to the plural, with no harm done; the sky didn’t fall in. Where the male pronoun remains in this edition I felt it was the only solution that wasn’t cumbersome.

在《写作之道》的早期版本中，我用“他”和“他们”来指代“读者”、“作者”、“评论家”、“幽默作家”等等。我觉得如果每次都用“他或她”，这本书读起来会很费劲。（我完全反对使用“他/她”；这种主观臆断在优秀的英语中毫无立足之地。）然而，这些年来，很多女性写信来提醒我这一点。她们说，作为作家和读者，她们很反感总是要想象一个男人在写作和阅读，她们说得对；我接受了她们的提醒。大多数提醒者都敦促我采用复数形式：使用“读者”和“作家”，后面再接“他们”。我不喜欢复数；它们会削弱写作，因为它们不如单数具体，更难想象。我希望每位作家都能想象出一位读者正在努力阅读他或她写的东西。尽管如此，我还是找到了三四百处可以去掉“他”、“他自己”或“男人”的地方，主要是通过改用复数形式，而且没有任何问题；天也没塌下来。在这个版本中，凡是保留男性代词的地方，我都觉得这是唯一不显得繁琐的解决方案。

The best solutions simply eliminate “he” and its connotations of male ownership by using other pronouns or by altering some other component of the sentence. “We” is a handy replacement for “he.” “Our” and “the” can often replace “his.” (A) “First he notices what’s happening to his kids and he blames it on his neighborhood.” (B) “First we notice what’s happening to our kids and we blame it on the neighborhood.” General nouns can replace specific nouns. (A) “Doctors often neglect their wives and children.” (B) “Doctors often neglect their families.” Countless sins can be erased by such small changes.

最佳解决方案是直接消除“他”及其所蕴含的男性所有权含义，方法是使用其他代词或改变句子中的其他成分。“我们”可以方便地替代“他”。“我们的”和“这”通常可以替代“他的”。（A）“他首先注意到孩子们的遭遇，然后把责任归咎于邻居。”（B）“我们首先注意到孩子们的遭遇，然后把责任归咎于邻居。”一般名词可以替代特定名词。（A）“医生经常忽视他们的妻子和孩子。”（B）“医生经常忽视他们的家人。”无数的罪过都可以通过这些小小的改变而消除。

One other pronoun that helped me in my repairs was “you.” Instead of talking about what “the writer” does and the trouble he gets into, I found more places where I could address the writer directly (“You’ll often find …”). It doesn’t work for every kind of writing, but it’s a godsend to anyone writing an instructional book or a self-help book. The voice of a Dr. Spock talking to the mother of a child with a fever, or the voice of a Julia Child talking to the cook stalled in mid-recipe, is one of the most reassuring sounds a reader can hear. Always look for ways to make yourself available to the people you’re trying to reach.

另一个帮助我修改文章的代词是“你”。与其谈论“作者”做了什么以及他遇到了什么麻烦，我找到了更多可以直接与作者对话的地方（“你经常会发现……”）。这种方法并非适用于所有类型的写作，但对于撰写指导性书籍或自助书籍的人来说，它简直是天赐之物。想象一下，斯波克医生的声音在和一位发烧孩子的母亲交谈，或者茱莉亚·查尔德的声音在和一位烹饪卡壳的厨师交谈，这是读者能听到的最令人安心的声音之一。永远要想方设法让你的目标读者更容易联系到你。

R EWRITING .

重写。

Rewriting is the essence of writing well: it’s where the game is won or lost. That idea is hard to accept. We all have an emotional equity in our first draft; we can’t believe that it wasn’t born perfect. But the odds are close to 100 percent that it wasn’t. Most writers don’t initially say what they want to say, or say it as well as they could. The newly hatched sentence almost always has something wrong with it. It’s not clear. It’s not logical. It’s verbose. It’s klunky. It’s pretentious. It’s boring. It’s full of clutter. It’s full of clichés. It lacks rhythm. It can be read in several different ways. It doesn’t lead out of the previous sentence. It doesn’t … The point is that clear writing is the result of a lot of tinkering.

修改是写作的精髓：成败在此一举。这个观点很难接受。我们都对自己的初稿抱有情感上的依恋；我们难以相信它并非天生完美。但几乎可以肯定的是，它并非完美无缺。大多数作家最初都无法表达自己想表达的内容，或者无法将其表达得尽善尽美。初生的句子几乎总是存在一些问题。它不够清晰。它不够合乎逻辑。它冗长。它笨拙。它矫揉造作。它枯燥乏味。它杂乱无章。它充斥着陈词滥调。它缺乏节奏感。它可以有多种不同的解读方式。它与前一句缺乏衔接。它……关键在于，清晰的写作是反复修改的结果。

Many people assume that professional writers don’t need to rewrite; the words just fall into place. On the contrary, careful writers can’t stop fiddling. I’ve never thought of rewriting as an unfair burden; I’m grateful for every chance to keep improving my work. Writing is like a good watch—it should run smoothly and have no extra parts. Students don’t share my love of rewriting. They think of it as punishment: extra homework or extra infield practice. Please—if you’re such a student—think of it as a gift. You won’t write well until you understand that writing is an evolving process , not a finished product . Nobody expects you to get it right the first time, or even the second time.

许多人认为专业作家不需要修改，文字仿佛信手拈来。恰恰相反，精雕细琢的作家却总是反复修改。我从未觉得修改是一种不公平的负担；我感激每一次提升作品的机会。写作就像一块好表——它应该运转流畅，无需任何多余的部件。学生们并不像我一样热爱修改。他们把修改视为惩罚：额外的作业或额外的练习。如果你也是这样的学生，请把它看作一份礼物。只有当你明白写作是一个不断发展的过程，而不是一个最终成品时，你才能写出好文章。没有人期望你第一次就能写出完美之作，甚至第二次也不例外。

What do I mean by “rewriting”? I don’t mean writing one draft and then writing a different second version, and then a third. Most rewriting consists of reshaping and tightening and refining the raw material you wrote on your first try. Much of it consists of making sure you’ve given the reader a narrative flow he can follow with no trouble from beginning to end. Keep putting yourself in the reader’s place. Is there something he should have been told early in the sentence that you put near the end? Does he know when he starts sentence B that you’ve made a shift—of subject, tense, tone, emphasis—from sentence A?

我说的“重写”是什么意思？我指的不是写完一个草稿，再写一个不同的版本，然后再写第三个。大部分的重写都是对你最初写出的素材进行重塑、精简和润色。其中很大一部分是确保你为读者提供了一个流畅的叙事结构，让他们能够从头到尾轻松阅读。要时刻站在读者的角度思考。你是不是把一些原本应该在句子开头就告诉读者的信息放在了结尾附近？当他读到句子B时，他是否能意识到你对句子A进行了主语、时态、语气和强调等方面的调整？

Let’s look at a typical paragraph and imagine that it’s the writer’s first draft. There’s nothing really wrong with it; it’s clear and it’s grammatical. But it’s full of ragged edges: failures of the writer to keep the reader notified of changes in time, place and mood, or to vary and animate the style. What I’ve done is to add, in bracketed italics after each sentence, some of the thoughts that might occur to an editor taking a first look at this draft. After that you’ll find my revised paragraph, which incorporates those corrective thoughts.

让我们来看一个典型的段落，假设这是作者的初稿。它本身并没有什么大问题；表达清晰，语法正确。但它却处处显得粗糙：作者未能及时告知读者时间、地点和情绪的变化，也未能使文风更加生动活泼。我的做法是，在每个句子后面用斜体括号标注一些编辑初读此稿时可能会想到的想法。之后，你会看到我根据这些修改意见修改后的段落。

There used to be a time when neighbors took care of one another, he remembered. [Put “he remembered” first to establish reflective tone.] It no longer seemed to happen that way, however. [The contrast supplied by “however” must come first. Start with “But.” Also establish America locale.] He wondered if it was because everyone in the modern world was so busy. [All these sentences are the same length and have the same soporific rhythm; turn this one into a question?] It occurred to him that people today have so many things to do that they don’t have time for old-fashioned friendship. [Sentence essentially repeats previous sentence; kill it or warm it up with specific detail.] Things didn’t work that way in America in previous eras. [Reader is still in the present; reverse the sentence to tell him he’s now in the past. “America” no longer needed if inserted earlier.] And he knew that the situation was very different in other countries, as he recalled from the years when he lived in villages in Spain and Italy. [Reader is still in America. Use a negative transition word to get him to Europe. Sentence is also too flabby. Break it into two sentences?] It almost seemed to him that as people got richer and built their houses farther apart they isolated themselves from the essentials of life. [Irony deferred too long. Plant irony early. Sharpen the paradox about richness.] And there was another thought that troubled him. [This is the real point of the paragraph; signal the reader that it’s important. Avoid weak “there was” construction.] His friends had deserted him when he needed them most during his recent illness. [Reshape to end with “most”; the last word is the one that stays in the reader’s ear and gives the sentence its punch. Hold sickness for next sentence; it’s a separate thought.] It was almost as if they found him guilty of doing something shameful. [Introduce sickness here as the reason for the shame. Omit “guilty”; it’s implicit.] He recalled reading somewhere about societies in primitive parts of the world in which sick people were shunned, though he had never heard of any such ritual in America. [Sentence starts slowly and stays sluggish and dull. Break it into shorter units. Snap off the ironic point.]

他记得，以前邻里之间会互相照应。[将“他记得”放在句首，以营造反思的语气。] 然而，现在似乎不再是这样了。[“然而”带来的对比必须放在句首。以“但是”开头。同时表明故事发生在美国。] 他想，是不是因为现代社会的人都太忙了。[所有这些句子长度相同，节奏也同样催眠；把这句改成疑问句？] 他突然意识到，现在的人们有太多事情要做，以至于没有时间维系老式的友谊。[这句话基本上重复了前一句；要么删掉，要么用具体细节加以润色。] 在过去的美国，情况并非如此。[读者仍然处于现在时；将句子倒过来，告诉他现在处于过去。如果前面已经加上“美国”，则不再需要。] 他知道其他国家的情况截然不同，就像他回忆起在西班牙和意大利的乡村生活时那样。 [读者仍身处美国。使用否定过渡词将他引向欧洲。句子也过于冗长。是否应该将其拆分为两句？] 他几乎觉得，随着人们越来越富有，房屋也越建越远，他们似乎也与生活的必需品隔绝了。[讽刺出现得太晚了。应该更早地引入讽刺。强化关于财富的悖论。] 还有另一个想法困扰着他。[这是本段的重点；提醒读者这一点很重要。避免使用语气疲软的“there was”结构。] 在他最近生病期间，朋友们在他最需要他们的时候却离他而去。[修改句子结构，以“most”结尾；最后一个词最能留在读者的记忆中，赋予句子力量。将“sickness”（生病）留到下一句；这是一个独立的想法。] 他们似乎认定他做了什么可耻的事情。[在这里引入“sickness”（生病）作为羞耻的原因。省略“guilty”（有罪）；这是不言而喻的。他想起曾在某处读到过，在世界一些原始社会中，病人会被避而远之，但他从未听说过美国有类似的习俗。[句子开头缓慢，而且一直拖沓乏味。将其拆分成更短的句子。去掉反讽的语气。]

He remembered that neighbors used to take care of one another. But that no longer seemed to happen in America. Was it because everyone was so busy? Were people really so preoccupied with their television sets and their cars and their fitness programs that they had no time for friendship? In previous eras that was never true. Nor was it how families lived in other parts of the world. Even in the poorest villages of Spain and Italy, he recalled, people would drop in with a loaf of bread. An ironic idea struck him: as people got richer they cut themselves off from the richness of life. But what really troubled him was an even more shocking fact. The time when his friends deserted him was the time when he needed them most. By getting sick he almost seemed to have done something shameful. He knew that other societies had a custom of “shunning” people who were very ill. But that ritual only existed in primitive cultures. Or did it?

他记得以前邻里之间会互相照应。但在美国，这种事似乎已经不复存在了。是因为大家都太忙了吗？人们真的都沉迷于电视、汽车和健身计划，以至于无暇顾及友谊吗？在过去，这绝非事实。世界其他地方的家庭生活也并非如此。他回忆说，即使在西班牙和意大利最贫困的村庄，人们也会带着面包来串门。一个讽刺的想法突然涌上心头：人们越富有，就越是与生活的美好隔绝。但真正让他感到困扰的，是一个更加令人震惊的事实。在他最需要朋友的时候，朋友们却离他而去。生病似乎成了一件丢脸的事。他知道其他社会有“避病”的习俗。但这种习俗只存在于原始社会。真的是这样吗？

My revisions aren’t the best ones that could be made, or the only ones. They’re mainly matters of carpentry: altering the sequence, tightening the flow, sharpening the point. Much could still be done in such areas as cadence, detail and freshness of language. The total construction is equally important. Read your article aloud from beginning to end, always remembering where you left the reader in the previous sentence. You might find you had written two sentences like this:

我的修改并非最佳方案，也并非唯一方案。它们主要涉及细节：调整顺序、优化行文流畅度、突出重点。在节奏、细节和语言的新鲜感等方面，还有很多可以改进的地方。整体结构同样重要。请从头到尾大声朗读你的文章，始终牢记上一句给读者留下的印象。你可能会发现，你写过两句类似这样的句子：

The tragic hero of the play is Othello. Small and malevolent, Iago feeds his jealous suspicions.

剧中的悲剧英雄是奥赛罗。而心胸狭隘、阴险狡诈的伊阿古则助长了他的嫉妒和猜疑。

In itself there’s nothing wrong with the Iago sentence. But as a sequel to the previous sentence it’s very wrong. The name lingering in the reader’s ear is Othello; the reader naturally assumes that Othello is small and malevolent.

单独来看，伊阿古那句话本身并没有什么问题。但作为前一句的接续，它就大错特错了。读者脑海中挥之不去的名字是奥赛罗；读者自然而然地会认为奥赛罗身材矮小，心怀恶意。

When you read your writing aloud with these connecting links in mind you’ll hear a dismaying number of places where you lost the reader, or confused the reader, or failed to tell him the one fact he needed to know, or told him the same thing twice: the inevitable loose ends of every early draft. What you must do is make an arrangement—one that holds together from start to finish and that moves with economy and warmth.

当你带着这些衔接点朗读自己的文章时，你会惊讶地发现很多地方让读者感到困惑、不知所措，或者漏掉了他们需要知道的关键信息，又或者重复了相同的内容：这些都是初稿中不可避免的疏漏。你必须做的是进行结构调整——使文章从头到尾连贯流畅，既简洁又饱含情感。

Learn to enjoy this tidying process. I don’t like to write; I like to have written. But I love to rewrite. I especially like to cut: to press the DELETE key and see an unnecessary word or phrase or sentence vanish into the electricity. I like to replace a humdrum word with one that has more precision or color. I like to strengthen the transition between one sentence and another. I like to rephrase a drab sentence to give it a more pleasing rhythm or a more graceful musical line. With every small refinement I feel that I’m coming nearer to where I would like to arrive, and when I finally get there I know it was the rewriting, not the writing, that won the game.

学会享受这个润色的过程。我不喜欢写作，我喜欢的是写完之后的感觉。但我热爱修改。我尤其喜欢删减：按下删除键，看着那些不必要的词句消失得无影无踪。我喜欢用更精准、更生动的词语替换平淡无奇的词句。我喜欢加强句子之间的过渡。我喜欢改写枯燥乏味的句子，赋予它更悦耳的韵律或更优美的旋律。每一次细微的润色，都让我感觉离目标更近了一步，而当我最终抵达终点时，我知道，真正让我满意的不是写作本身，而是修改。

W RITING ON A C OMPUTER .

在电脑上写作。

The computer is God’s gift, or technology’s gift, to rewriting and reorganizing. It puts your words right in front of your eyes for your instant consideration—and reconsideration; you can play with your sentences until you get them right. The paragraphs and pages will keep rearranging themselves, no matter how much you cut and change, and then your printer will type everything neatly while you go and have a beer. Sweeter music could hardly be sung to writers than the sound of their article being retyped with all its improvements—but not by them.

电脑是上帝赐予的礼物，或者说是科技赐予的礼物，它让重写和重组文章变得轻而易举。它能将你的文字直接呈现在你眼前，供你即时审阅——并反复推敲；你可以反复修改句子，直到满意为止。无论你如何删改，段落和页面都会自动重新排列，然后你的打印机会在你喝啤酒的时候，将所有内容整齐地打印出来。对于作家来说，没有什么比看到自己的文章被重新打印出来，并经过所有改进更令人欣喜的了——而且并非由他们自己完成。

It’s no longer necessary for this book to explain, as earlier editions did, how to operate the wonderful new machine called a word processor that had come into our lives and how to put its wonders to use in writing, rewriting, and organizing. That’s now common knowledge. I’ll just remind you (if you’re still not a believer) that the savings in time and drudgery are enormous. With a computer I sit down to write more willingly than I did when I used a typewriter, especially if I’m facing a complex task of organization, and I finish the task sooner and with far less fatigue. These are crucial gains for a writer: time, output, energy, enjoyment and control.

本书无需像之前的版本那样，详细解释如何操作这台神奇的新机器——文字处理器，以及如何利用它的强大功能进行写作、修改和组织。这些如今已是常识。我只想提醒你（如果你仍然有所怀疑），它能节省大量的时间和精力。有了电脑，我比以前用打字机时更乐意坐下来写作，尤其是在面对复杂的组织工作时，而且我能更快完成任务，也更轻松。对于写作者来说，这些都是至关重要的优势：时间、效率、精力、乐趣和掌控感。

T RUST Y OUR M ATERIAL .

相信你的素材。

The longer I work at the craft of writing, the more I realize that there’s nothing more interesting than the truth. What people do—and what people say—continues to take me by surprise with its wonderfulness, or its quirkiness, or its drama, or its humor, or its pain. Who could invent all the astonishing things that really happen? I increasingly find myself saying to writers and students, “Trust your material.” It seems to be hard advice to follow.

我越是钻研写作，就越发意识到，没有什么比真相更引人入胜。人们的所作所为——以及他们所说的话——总是以其奇妙、古怪、戏剧性、幽默或痛苦让我感到惊喜。谁又能虚构出所有真实发生的惊人之事呢？我越来越频繁地对作家和学生说：“相信你的素材。” 但这似乎是一个难以做到的建议。

Recently I spent some time as a writing coach at a newspaper in a small American city. I noticed that many reporters had fallen into the habit of trying to make the news more palatable by writing in a feature style. Their leads consisted of a series of snippets that went something like this:

最近，我在美国一座小城市的报社担任了一段时间的写作指导。我注意到，许多记者都养成了用特稿风格来撰写新闻报道的习惯，试图让新闻更容易被读者接受。他们的导语通常由一系列片段组成，大致如下：

Whoosh!

嗖！

It was incredible.

真是太棒了。

Ed Barnes wondered if he was seeing things.

埃德·巴恩斯怀疑自己是不是眼花了。

Or maybe it was just spring fever. Funny how April can do that to a guy.

或许只是春季躁动吧。四月这几天，男人就是有这种魔力，真奇怪。

It wasn’t as if he hadn’t checked his car before leaving the house.

他出门前并非没有检查过自己的车。

But then again, he didn’t remember to tell Linda.

但是，他又忘了告诉琳达。

Which was odd, because he always remembered to tell Linda. Ever since they started going together back in junior high.

这很奇怪，因为他总是记得告诉琳达。自从他们初中开始交往以来，他就一直这样做。

Was that really 20 years ago?

那真的是20年前的事了吗？

And now there was also little Scooter to worry about.

现在家里还有个小Scooter要照顾。

Come to think of it, the dog was acting kind of suspicious.

仔细想想，那条狗的行为确实有点可疑。

The articles often began on page 1, and I would read as far as “Continued on page 9” and still have no idea of what they were about. Then I would dutifully turn to page 9 and find myself in an interesting story, full of specific details. I’d say to the reporter, “That was a good story when I finally got over here to page 9. Why didn’t you put that stuff in the lead?” The reporter would say, “Well, in the lead I was writing color.” The assumption is that fact and color are two separate ingredients. They’re not; color is organic to the fact. Your job is to present the colorful fact.

文章通常从第一页开始，我读到“请看第九页”仍然一头雾水。然后我乖乖地翻到第九页，发现自己读到一篇引人入胜、细节丰富的文章。我会问记者：“我好不容易翻到第九页，发现这篇报道写得真好。为什么不把这些放在头版呢？” 记者会说：“嗯，头版我写的是生动的细节。” 他们以为事实和细节是两个独立的部分。其实不然；细节是事实的有机组成部分。你的工作就是把生动的细节呈现出来。

In 1988 I wrote a baseball book called Spring Training . It combined my lifelong vocation with my lifelong addiction—which is one of the best things that can happen to a writer; people will write better and with more enjoyment if they write about what they care about. I chose spring training as my small corner of the large subject of baseball because it’s a time of renewal, both for the players and for the fans. The game is given back to us in its original purity: it’s played outside, in the sun, on grass, without organ music, by young men who are almost near enough to touch and whose salaries and grievances are mercifully put aside for six weeks. Above all, it’s a time of teaching and learning. I chose the Pittsburgh Pirates as the team I would cover because they trained in an old-time ballpark in Bradenton, Florida, and were a young club just starting to rebuild, with a manager, Jim Leyland, who was committed to teaching.

1988年，我写了一本棒球书，名为《春训》。这本书将我毕生的职业和我毕生的爱好结合起来——这对于一个作家来说，无疑是件好事；如果人们写自己真正关心的事情，他们就能写得更好，也更有乐趣。我选择春训作为棒球这个大主题中的一个小角落，因为对于球员和球迷来说，这都是一个焕然一新的时期。这项运动回归了它最初的纯粹：在阳光明媚的草地上，没有管风琴的伴奏，年轻的球员们彼此之间几乎触手可及，他们的薪水和不满都被暂时搁置，享受着这六周的时光。最重要的是，这是一个教学和学习的时期。我选择匹兹堡海盗队作为我报道的球队，因为他们在佛罗里达州布雷登顿一座古老的棒球场进行训练，而且是一支刚刚开始重建的年轻球队，他们的经理吉姆·莱兰德致力于教学。

I didn’t want to romanticize the game. I don’t like baseball movies that go into slow motion when the batter hits a home run, to notify me that it’s a pregnant moment. I know that about home runs, especially if they’re hit with two out in the bottom of the ninth to win the game. I resolved not to let my writing go into slow motion—not to nudge the reader with significance—or to claim baseball as a metaphor for life, death, middle age, lost youth or a more innocent America. My premise was that baseball is a job—honorable work—and I wanted to know how that job gets taught and learned.

我不想把比赛浪漫化。我不喜欢棒球电影里，击球手打出本垒打时镜头慢放，仿佛在提醒我这是一个意义非凡的时刻。我知道本垒打的意义，尤其是在九局下半两出局的情况下，一记制胜本垒打。我决心不让我的文字也陷入这种慢放——不去刻意强调意义——也不把棒球当作人生、死亡、中年、逝去的青春或更纯真的美国的隐喻。我的前提是，棒球是一份工作——一份光荣的工作——我想了解这份工作是如何被教授和学习的。

So I went to Jim Leyland and his coaches and I said, “You’re a teacher. I’m a teacher. Tell me: How do you teach hitting? How do you teach pitching? How do you teach fielding? How do you teach baserunning? How do you keep these young men up for such a brutally long schedule?” All of them responded generously and told me in detail how they do what they do. So did the players and all the other men and women who had information I wanted: umpires, scouts, ticket sellers, local boosters.

于是我去找了吉姆·莱兰德和他的教练们，我说：“你们是老师，我也是老师。请告诉我：你们是怎么教击球的？是怎么教投球的？是怎么教守备的？是怎么教跑垒的？你们是怎么让这些年轻人在如此漫长而残酷的赛程中保持状态的？”他们都慷慨地回答了我，详细地告诉我他们是如何做到的。球员们以及所有其他掌握我需要的信息的人也都提供了帮助：裁判、球探、售票员、当地的支持者等等。

One day I climbed up into the stands behind home plate to look for a scout. Spring training is baseball’s ultimate talent show, and the camps are infested with laconic men who have spent a lifetime appraising talent. I spotted an empty seat next to a weathered man in his sixties who was using a stopwatch and taking notes. When the inning was over I asked him what he was timing. He said he was Nick Kamzic, Northern Scouting Coordinator of the California Angels, and he was timing runners on the base paths. I asked him what kind of information he was looking for.

有一天，我爬上本垒板后面的看台，想找个球探。春训是棒球界的终极人才展示，训练营里到处都是沉默寡言、毕生致力于评估球员的男士。我发现一个空位，旁边坐着一位六十多岁、饱经风霜的男士，他正拿着秒表做笔记。一局结束后，我问他计时的是什么。他说他是尼克·卡姆齐克，加州天使队的北方球探协调员，正在计时跑垒员在垒上的跑动时间。我问他想了解什么信息。

“Well, it takes a right-handed batter 4.3 seconds to reach first base,” he said, “and a left-handed batter 4.1 or 4.2 seconds. Naturally that varies a little—you’ve got to take the human element into consideration.”

“嗯，右打者上到一垒需要4.3秒，”他说，“左打者需要4.1或4.2秒。当然，这会略有不同——你必须考虑到人的因素。”

“What do those numbers tell you?” I asked.

“这些数字说明了什么？”我问。

“Well, of course the average double play takes 4.3 seconds,” he said. He said it as if it was common knowledge. I had never given any thought to the elapsed time of a double play.

“嗯，当然，平均一次双杀需要4.3秒，”他说。他说的好像这是常识一样。我以前从来没想过一次双杀要花多长时间。

“So that means …”

“所以这意味着……”

“If you see a player who gets to first base in less than 4.3 seconds you’re interested in him.”

“如果你看到一名球员能在 4.3 秒内跑到一垒，你就会对他就感兴趣。”

As a fact that’s self-sufficient. There’s no need to add a sentence pointing out that 4.3 seconds is remarkably little time to execute a play that involves one batted ball, two thrown balls and three infielders. Given 4.3 seconds, readers can do their own marveling. They will also enjoy being allowed to think for themselves. The reader plays a major role in the act of writing and must be given room to play it. Don’t annoy your readers by over-explaining—by telling them something they already know or can figure out. Try not to use words like “surprisingly,” “predictably” and “of course,” which put a value on a fact before the reader encounters the fact. Trust your material.

作为一个不言自明的事实，无需赘述4.3秒对于完成一次击球、两次传球和三名内野手的进攻来说是多么短暂。读者只需4.3秒就能自行领悟其中的奥妙。他们也会乐于拥有独立思考的空间。读者在写作过程中扮演着重要角色，必须给予他们足够的发挥空间。不要过度解释，不要赘述读者已经知道或能够推断出的信息，以免惹恼他们。尽量避免使用“令人惊讶地”、“不出所料地”和“当然”之类的词语，这些词语会在读者接触到事实之前就赋予其价值。相信你的素材。

G O WITH Y OUR I NTERESTS .

去做你感兴趣的事情。

There’s no subject you don’t have permission to write about. Students often avoid subjects close to their heart—skateboarding, cheerleading, rock music, cars—because they assume that their teachers will regard those topics as “stupid.” No area of life is stupid to someone who takes it seriously. If you follow your affections you will write well and will engage your readers.

没有你不能写的主题。学生们常常会避开自己真正感兴趣的话题——滑板、啦啦队、摇滚乐、汽车——因为他们觉得老师会认为这些话题“愚蠢”。但对于认真对待生活的人来说，生活中没有哪个领域是愚蠢的。如果你追随自己的兴趣，你就能写出好文章，也能吸引读者。

I’ve read elegant books on fishing and poker, billiards and rodeos, mountain climbing and giant sea turtles and many other subjects I didn’t think I was interested in. Write about your hobbies: cooking, gardening, photography, knitting, antiques, jogging, sailing, scuba diving, tropical birds, tropical fish. Write about your work: teaching, nursing, running a business, running a store. Write about a field you enjoyed in college and always meant to get back to: history, biography, art, archaeology. No subject is too specialized or too quirky if you make an honest connection with it when you write about it.

我读过许多关于钓鱼、扑克、台球、牛仔竞技、登山、巨型海龟以及其他许多我以前从未想过会感兴趣的主题的精彩书籍。写写你的爱好：烹饪、园艺、摄影、编织、古董、慢跑、帆船、潜水、热带鸟类、热带鱼。写写你的工作：教书、护理、经营企业、经营店铺。写写你在大学时喜欢并且一直想重拾的领域：历史、传记、艺术、考古学。只要你在写作时与主题建立起真诚的联系，就没有哪个主题会显得过于小众或古怪。

#↩

PART III

第三部分

#↩

Forms

表格

#↩

11

Nonfiction as Literature

非虚构作品作为文学

One weekend a few years ago I went to Buffalo to talk at a writers’ conference that had been organized by a group of women writers in that city. The women were serious about their craft, and the books and articles they had written were solid and useful. They asked me if I would take part in a radio talk show earlier in the week to publicize the conference—they would be with the host in the studio and I would be on a telephone hookup from my apartment in New York.

几年前的一个周末，我去布法罗参加一个作家研讨会，研讨会是由当地一群女作家组织的。这些女作家对写作非常认真，她们写的书和文章都很有价值，也很有实用价值。她们问我是否愿意在研讨会开始前一周参加一个广播访谈节目，为研讨会做宣传——她们会在演播室和主持人一起录制节目，而我会在纽约的公寓里通过电话连线参与。

The appointed evening arrived, and my phone rang, and the host came on and greeted me with the strenuous joviality of his trade. He said he had three lovely ladies in the studio with him and he was eager to find out what we all thought of the present state of literature and what advice we had for all his listeners who were members of the literati and had literary ambitions themselves. This hearty introduction dropped like a stone in our midst, and none of the three lovely ladies said anything, which I thought was the proper response.

约定的夜晚终于到来，我的电话响了，主持人接起电话，用他那惯有的热情洋溢的语气跟我打招呼。他说演播室里有三位美丽的女士，他很想知道我们对当今文学界的看法，以及我们对那些身为文人墨客、怀揣文学梦想的听众有什么建议。这番热情洋溢的开场白像一块石头砸在我们面前，三位美丽的女士都沉默不语，我觉得这才是恰当的回应。

The silence lengthened, and finally I said, “I think we should banish all further mention of the words ‘literature’ and ‘literary’ and ‘literati.’” I knew that the host had been briefed about what kind of writers we were and what we wanted to discuss. But he had no other frame of reference. “Tell me,” he said, “what insights do you all have about the literary experience in America today?” Silence also greeted this question. Finally I said, “We’re here to talk about the craft of writing.”

沉默持续了很久，最后我开口说道：“我想我们应该彻底摒弃‘文学’、‘文艺的’和‘文人墨客’这些词。”我知道主人事先了解过我们是哪类作家，以及我们想讨论什么。但他似乎没有其他参照。“请告诉我，”他问道，“你们对当今美国的文学现状有什么见解？”这个问题同样引发了沉默。最后我说道：“我们今天来这里是为了探讨写作技巧。”

He didn’t know what to make of that, and he began to invoke the names of authors like Ernest Hemingway and Saul Bellow and William Styron, whom we surely regarded as literary giants. We said those writers didn’t happen to be our models, and we mentioned people like Lewis Thomas and Joan Didion and Gary Wills. He had never heard of them. One of the women mentioned Tom Wolfe’s The Right Stuff , and he hadn’t heard of that. We explained that these were writers we admired for their ability to harness the issues and concerns of the day.

他一时不知如何理解，开始提及欧内斯特·海明威、索尔·贝娄和威廉·斯泰伦等作家的名字，在我们看来，他们无疑是文学巨匠。我们解释说，这些作家并非我们的榜样，并提到了路易斯·托马斯、琼·迪迪恩和加里·威尔斯等人。他从未听说过这些人。一位女士提到了汤姆·沃尔夫的《太空先锋》，他也没听说过。我们解释说，我们欣赏这些作家，是因为他们能够把握时代的社会问题和关注点。

“But don’t you want to write anything literary?” our host said. The three women said they felt they were already doing satisfying work. That brought the program to another halt, and the host began to accept phone calls from his listeners, all of whom were interested in the craft of writing and wanted to know how we went about it. “And yet, in the stillness of the night,” the host said to several callers, “don’t you ever dream of writing the great American novel?” They didn’t. They had no such dreams—in the stillness of the night or at any other time. It was one of the all-time lousy radio talk shows.

“难道你们不想写点文学作品吗？”主持人问道。三位女士表示，她们觉得自己目前的工作已经很令人满意了。这让节目再次陷入停滞，主持人开始接听听众的电话，所有听众都对写作技巧很感兴趣，想知道我们是如何写作的。“然而，在寂静的夜里，”主持人对几位听众说道，“你们难道从未梦想过写出一部伟大的美国小说吗？”她们没有。她们从未有过这样的梦想——无论是在寂静的夜里，还是在任何其他时候。这绝对是有史以来最糟糕的广播脱口秀之一。

The story sums up a situation that any practitioner of nonfiction will recognize. Those of us who are trying to write well about the world we live in, or to teach students to write well about the world they live in, are caught in a time warp, where literature by definition still consists of forms that were certified as “literary” in the 19th century: novels and short stories and poems. But the great preponderance of what writers now write and sell, what book and magazine publishers publish and what readers demand is nonfiction.

这个故事概括了一种任何非虚构写作者都会认同的现状。我们这些努力写好我们所处世界，或者教学生写好他们所处世界的人，都陷入了一种时间停滞的状态，文学的定义仍然局限于19世纪被认定为“文学”的形式：小说、短篇小说和诗歌。然而，如今作家创作和销售的大部分作品，图书和杂志出版商出版的大部分作品，以及读者需求的大部分作品，都是非虚构作品。

The shift can be documented by all kinds of examples. One is the history of the Book-of-the-Month Club. When the club was founded in 1926 by Harry Scherman, Americans had little access to good new literature and were mainly reading junk like Ben-Hur . Scherman’s idea was that any town that had a post office had the equivalent of a bookstore, and he began sending the best new books to his newly recruited readers all over the country.

这种转变可以从各种各样的例子中得到印证。其中一个例子就是“每月一书俱乐部”的历史。该俱乐部由哈里·舍曼于1926年创立。当时，美国人很难接触到优秀的新文学作品，读的大多是像《宾虚》这样的庸俗之作。舍曼的想法是，任何设有邮局的城镇都相当于拥有一家书店，于是他开始向遍布全国的新读者寄送最好的新书。

Much of what he sent was fiction. The list of main selections chosen by the club from 1926 through 1941 is heavily laced with novelists: Ellen Glasgow, Sinclair Lewis, Virginia Woolf, John Galsworthy, Elinor Wylie, Ignazio Silone, Rosamond Lehmann, Edith Wharton, Somerset Maugham, Willa Cather, Booth Tarkington, Isak Dinesen, James Gould Cozzens, Thornton Wilder, Sigrid Undset, Ernest Hemingway, William Saroyan, John P. Marquand, John Steinbeck and many others. That was the high tide of “literature” in America. Members of the Book-of-the-Month Club hardly heard the approach of World War II. Not until 1940 was it brought home to them in a book, Mrs. Miniver , a stiff-upper-lip novel about the early days of the Battle of Britain.

他寄来的书大多是小说。从1926年到1941年，读书俱乐部的主要选书单上充斥着小说家的作品：艾伦·格拉斯哥、辛克莱·刘易斯、弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫、约翰·高尔斯华绥、埃莉诺·怀利、伊格纳齐奥·西洛内、罗莎蒙德·莱曼、伊迪丝·华顿、萨默塞特·毛姆、薇拉·凯瑟、布斯·塔金顿、伊萨克·迪内森、詹姆斯·古尔德·科曾斯、桑顿·怀尔德、西格丽德·温塞特、欧内斯特·海明威、威廉·萨洛扬、约翰·P·马昆德、约翰·斯坦贝克等等。那是美国“文学”的鼎盛时期。每月读书俱乐部的成员们几乎没有察觉到第二次世界大战的临近。直到1940年，他们才通过一本书——《米尼弗夫人》——真切地感受到战争的残酷。这是一部讲述不列颠空战初期，展现英国人坚忍不拔精神的小说。

All of this changed with Pearl Harbor. World War II sent seven million Americans overseas and opened their eyes to reality: to new places and issues and events. After the war that trend was reinforced by the advent of television. People who saw reality every evening in their living room lost patience with the slower rhythms and glancing allusions of the novelist. Overnight, America became a fact-minded nation. After 1946 the Book-of-the-Month Club’s members predominantly demanded—and therefore received—nonfiction.

珍珠港事件改变了这一切。二战将七百万美国人送往海外，让他们真正看清了现实：看到了新的地方、新的问题和新的事件。战后，电视的出现进一步强化了这一趋势。每天晚上在客厅里就能看到现实的人们，对小说家那种缓慢的节奏和含蓄的暗示失去了耐心。一夜之间，美国变成了一个注重事实的国家。1946年以后，“每月一书俱乐部”的成员们主要要求——也因此得到了——非虚构类书籍。

Magazines were swept along on the same tide. The Saturday Evening Post , which had long spoon-fed its readers a heavy diet of short stories by writers who all seemed to have three names—Clarence Budington Kelland, Octavus Roy Cohen—reversed the ratio in the early 1960s. Ninety percent of the magazine was now allotted to nonfiction articles, with just one short story by a three-named author to keep the faithful from feeling abandoned. It was the beginning of a golden era of nonfiction, especially in Life , which ran finely crafted articles every week; in The New Yorker , which elevated the form by originating such landmarks of modern American writing as Rachel Carson’s Silent Spring and Truman Capote’s In Cold Blood; and in Harper’s , which commissioned such remarkable pieces as Norman Mailer’s Armies of the Night . Nonfiction became the new American literature.

杂志也随之经历了同样的变革。《星期六晚邮报》长期以来以大量短篇小说为主打，而这些小说的作者似乎都只有三个名字——比如克拉伦斯·巴丁顿·凯兰、奥克塔维斯·罗伊·科恩——但在20世纪60年代初，该杂志彻底改变了这一局面。杂志90%的版面都用来刊登非虚构类文章，只保留一篇三字作家的短篇小说，以免忠实读者感到被冷落。这标志着非虚构类文学黄金时代的开始，尤其体现在《生活》杂志上，该杂志每周都刊登精心撰写的文章；《纽约客》杂志也提升了非虚构类文学的地位，推出了蕾切尔·卡森的《寂静的春天》和杜鲁门·卡波特的《冷血》等现代美国文学的里程碑之作；《哈珀斯》杂志则委托创作了诺曼·梅勒的《夜之军队》等杰出作品。非虚构类文学成为了新的美国文学。

Today there’s no area of life—present or past—that isn’t being made accessible to ordinary readers by men and women writing with high seriousness and grace. Add to this literature of fact all the disciplines that were once regarded as academic, like anthropology and economics and social history, that have become the domain of nonfiction writers and of broadly curious readers. Add all the books combining history and biography that have distinguished American letters in recent years: David McCullough’s Truman and The Path Between the Seas; Robert A. Caro’s The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York; Taylor Branch’s Parting the Waters: America in the King Years, 1954–63; Richard Kluger’s The Paper: The Life and Death of the New York Herald Tribune; Richard Rhodes’s The Making of the Atomic Bomb; Thomas L. Friedman’s From Beirut to Jerusalem; J. Anthony Lukas’s Common Ground: A Turbulent Decade in the Lives of American Families; Edmund Morris’s Theodore Rex; Nicholas Lemann’s The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America; Adam Hochschild’s King Leopold’s Ghost: A Story of Greed, Terror and Heroism in Colonial Africa; Ronald Steel’s Walter Lippmann and the American Century; Marion Elizabeth Rodgers’s Mencken: The American Iconoclast; David Remnick’s Lenin’s Tomb: The Last Days of the Soviet Empire; Andrew Delbanco’s Melville; Mark Stevens’s and Annalyn Swan’s de Kooning: An American Master . My roster of the new literature of nonfiction, in short, would include all the writers who come bearing information and who present it with vigor, clarity and humanity.

如今，无论是过去还是现在，生活中的方方面面，都有文笔严谨、文采斐然的作家们以通俗易懂的方式呈现给普通读者。此外，曾经被视为学院派的学科，如人类学、经济学和社会史，如今也成为了非虚构作家和广大读者的阅读领域。近年来，历史与传记相结合的著作也为美国文坛增添了浓墨重彩的一笔，例如：戴维·麦卡洛的《杜鲁门与跨海之路》；罗伯特·A·卡罗的《权力掮客：罗伯特·摩西与纽约的衰落》；泰勒·布兰奇的《分水岭：金博士时代的美国，1954-1963》；理查德·克鲁格的《报纸：纽约先驱论坛报的兴衰》；理查德·罗兹的《原子弹的制造》；托马斯·L·弗里德曼的《从贝鲁特到耶路撒冷》；J·安东尼·卢卡斯的《共同的土地：美国家庭动荡的十年》。埃德蒙·莫里斯的《西奥多·雷克斯》；尼古拉斯·莱曼的《应许之地：黑人大迁徙及其如何改变美国》；亚当·霍克希尔德的《利奥波德国王的幽灵：殖民地非洲的贪婪、恐怖与英雄主义的故事》；罗纳德·斯蒂尔的《沃尔特·李普曼与美国世纪》；玛丽昂·伊丽莎白·罗杰斯的《门肯：美国偶像破坏者》；大卫·雷姆尼克的《列宁墓：苏联帝国的末日》；安德鲁·德尔班科的《梅尔维尔》；马克·史蒂文斯和安娜琳·斯旺合著的《德·库宁：一位美国大师》。简而言之，我心目中的新非虚构文学作品，囊括了所有那些带着信息而来，并以饱满的热情、清晰的思路和人文关怀来呈现信息的作家。

I’m not saying that fiction is dead. Obviously the novelist can take us into places where no other writer can go: into the deep emotions and the interior life. What I’m saying is that I have no patience with the snobbery that says nonfiction is only journalism by another name and that journalism by any name is a dirty word. While we’re redefining literature, let’s also redefine journalism. Journalism is writing that first appears in any periodic journal, whatever its constituency. Lewis Thomas’s first two books, Lives of a Cell and The Medusa and the Snail , were first written as essays for the New England Journal of Medicine . Historically, in America, good journalism becomes good literature. H. L. Mencken, Ring Lardner, Joseph Mitchell, Edmund Wilson and dozens of other major American writers were working journalists before they were canonized in the church of literature. They just did what they did best and never worried about how it was defined.

我并非认为小说已死。显然，小说家能带领我们进入其他作家无法企及的领域：深入情感和内心世界。我的意思是，我无法容忍那种认为非虚构作品不过是换了个名字的新闻报道，以及认为新闻报道无论叫什么名字都是个贬义词的势利眼。既然我们在重新定义文学，那就也重新定义一下新闻报道吧。新闻报道指的是首次发表在任何期刊上的文章，无论其读者群体如何。路易斯·托马斯的前两部作品，《细胞的生命》和《美杜莎与蜗牛》，最初都是为《新英格兰医学杂志》撰写的文章。在美国历史上，优秀的新闻报道往往能成为优秀的文学作品。H·L·门肯、林·拉德纳、约瑟夫·米切尔、埃德蒙·威尔逊以及其他数十位美国文学巨匠，在被奉为文学殿堂的圣人之前，都曾是新闻工作者。他们只是做自己最擅长的事，从不关心别人如何定义他们。

Ultimately every writer must follow the path that feels most comfortable. For most people learning to write, that path is nonfiction. It enables them to write about what they know or can observe or can find out. This is especially true of young people and students. They will write far more willingly about subjects that touch their own lives or that they have an aptitude for. Motivation is at the heart of writing. If nonfiction is where you do your best writing, or your best teaching of writing, don’t be buffaloed into the idea that it’s an inferior species. The only important distinction is between good writing and bad writing. Good writing is good writing, whatever form it takes and whatever we call it.

最终，每个写作者都必须选择最适合自己的道路。对于大多数学习写作的人来说，这条路就是非虚构写作。它让他们能够写自己了解、观察到或了解到的内容。这一点对年轻人和学生尤其如此。他们会更乐意写那些与自身生活息息相关或自己擅长的主题。写作的动力是其核心。如果你在非虚构写作方面写得最好，或者在写作教学方面做得最好，不要被非虚构写作低人一等的观念所蒙蔽。唯一重要的区别在于好文章和坏文章。好的写作就是好的写作，无论它采取何种形式，无论我们如何称呼它。

#↩

12

Writing About People

关于人的写作

The Interview

采访

Get people talking. Learn to ask questions that will elicit answers about what is most interesting or vivid in their lives. Nothing so animates writing as someone telling what he thinks or what he does—in his own words.

引导人们开口说话。学会提出问题，引导他们讲述生活中最有趣或最生动的事情。没有什么比一个人用自己的语言讲述自己的想法或经历更能让文字鲜活起来了。

His own words will always be better than your words, even if you are the most elegant stylist in the land. They carry the inflection of his speaking voice and the idiosyncrasies of how he puts a sentence together. They contain the regionalisms of his conversation and the lingo of his trade. They convey his enthusiasms. This is a person talking to the reader directly, not through the filter of a writer. As soon as a writer steps in, everyone else’s experience becomes secondhand.

他自己的文字永远胜过你的文字，即便你是世上最文采斐然的作家。他的文字承载着他说话的语调，保留着他独特的句式结构，蕴含着他谈话中的地域特色和行业术语，传递着他的热情。这是他直接与读者对话，而非通过作家的过滤。一旦作家介入，其他人的经验就都成了二手信息。

Therefore learn how to conduct an interview. Whatever form of nonfiction you write, it will come alive in proportion to the number of “quotes” you can weave into it as you go along. Often you’ll find yourself embarking on an article so apparently lifeless—the history of an institution, or some local issue such as storm sewers—that you will quail at the prospect of keeping your readers, or even yourself, awake.

因此，要学会如何进行采访。无论你写的是哪种类型的非虚构作品，你穿插其中的“引语”越多，作品就越生动。你常常会发现自己着手撰写一篇看似枯燥乏味的文章——比如某个机构的历史，或者像雨水排水系统这样的本地议题——以至于你会担心如何才能让读者，甚至你自己，保持清醒。

Take heart. You’ll find the solution if you look for the human element. Somewhere in every drab institution are men and women who have a fierce attachment to what they are doing and are rich repositories of lore. Somewhere behind every storm sewer is a politician whose future hangs on getting it installed and a widow who has always lived on the block and is outraged that some damn-fool legislator thinks it will wash away. Find these people to tell your story and it won’t be drab.

别灰心。只要你用心寻找人性，就能找到答案。在每个看似平淡无奇的机构里，都藏着一些对自己的工作充满热情、且经验丰富的人。每条雨水管道背后，都站着一位政客，他的前途就系于它的安装；还有一位寡妇，她一直住在附近，对某个愚蠢的立法者竟然认为雨水会被冲走而感到愤怒。找到这些人，让他们来讲述你的故事，你的故事就不会那么枯燥乏味了。

I’ve proved this to myself often. Many years ago I was invited to write a small book for the New York Public Library to celebrate the 50th anniversary of its main building on Fifth Avenue. On the surface it seemed to be just the story of a marble building and millions of musty volumes. But behind the facade I found that the library had 19 research divisions, each with a curator supervising a hoard of treasures and oddities, from Washington’s handwritten Farewell Address to 750,000 movie stills. I decided to interview all those curators to learn what was in their collections, what they were adding to keep up with new areas of knowledge, and how their rooms were being used.

我曾多次亲身验证过这一点。多年前，我受邀为纽约公共图书馆撰写一本小册子，以庆祝其位于第五大道的主馆落成五十周年。表面上看，这似乎只是关于一座大理石建筑和数百万册尘封已久的书籍的故事。但我发现，在这光鲜亮丽的外表之下，图书馆设有19个研究部门，每个部门都有一位馆长负责管理大量珍宝和奇珍异宝，从华盛顿的手写告别演说到75万张电影剧照，应有尽有。我决定采访所有这些馆长，了解他们的馆藏，他们为了跟上知识发展的步伐而不断扩充馆藏，以及他们的办公室是如何运作的。

I found that the Science & Technology division had a collection of patents second only to that of the United States Patent Office and was therefore a second home to the city’s patent lawyers. But it also had a daily stream of men and women who thought they were on the verge of discovering perpetual motion. “Everybody’s got something to invent,” the curator explained, “but they won’t tell us what they’re looking for—maybe because they think we’ll patent it ourselves.” The whole building turned out to be just such a mixture of scholars and searchers and crackpots, and my story, though ostensibly the chronicle of an institution, was really a story about people.

我发现，科技部拥有的专利数量仅次于美国专利局，因此成了这座城市专利律师的第二个家。但同时，这里也每天都挤满了自认为即将发现永动机的男男女女。“每个人都想发明点什么，”馆长解释说，“但他们不肯告诉我们他们在寻找什么——也许是因为他们觉得我们会抢先申请专利。”整栋大楼里果然是学者、研究者和一些奇思妙想者的大杂烩，而我的故事，虽然表面上是一个机构的编年史，但实际上却是关于人的故事。

I used the same approach in a long article about Sotheby’s, the London auction firm. Sotheby’s was also divided into various domains, such as silver and porcelain and art, each with an expert in charge, and, like the Library, it subsisted on the whims of a capricious public. The experts were like department heads in a small college, and all of them had anecdotes that were unique both in substance and in the manner of telling:

我在一篇关于伦敦拍卖行苏富比的长文中也采用了同样的方法。苏富比也分为多个领域，例如银器、瓷器和艺术品，每个领域都由一位专家负责，而且和图书馆一样，它的生存依赖于喜怒无常的公众。这些专家就像小型学院的系主任，他们每个人都有一段段轶事，无论内容还是讲述方式都独具特色：

“We just sit here like Micawber waiting for things to come in,” said R. S. Timewell, head of the furniture department. “Recently an old lady near Cambridge wrote that she wanted to raise two thousand pounds and asked if I would go through her house and see if her furniture would fetch that much. I did, and there was absolutely nothing of value. As I was about to leave I said, ‘Have I seen every thing?’ She said I had, except for a maid’s room that she hadn’t bothered to show me. The room had a very fine 18th-century chest that the old lady was using to store blankets in. ‘Your worries are over,’ I told her, ‘if you sell that chest.’ She said, ‘But that’s quite impossible—where will I store my blankets?’”

“我们就像米考伯一样坐在这里，等着东西送来，”家具部主管R·S·蒂姆韦尔说道。“最近，剑桥附近的一位老太太来信说她想筹两千英镑，问我能不能去她家看看，她的家具能不能卖到这个价钱。我去了，结果发现里面根本没什么值钱的东西。我正要离开的时候问她：‘我都看过了吗？’她说都看过了，除了一个佣人房，她懒得让我去看。房间里有一个非常精美的18世纪的箱子，老太太用它来存放毯子。‘如果你把那个箱子卖了，你的烦恼就都解决了，’我对她说。她说：‘可是这根本不可能——我的毯子放哪儿呢？’”

My worries were over, too. By listening to the quizzical scholars who ran the business and to the men and women who flocked there every morning bearing unloved objects found in British attics (“I’m afraid it isn’t Queen Anne, madam—much nearer Queen Victoria, unfortunately”), I got as much human detail as a writer could want.

我的担忧也随之消除了。通过聆听经营这家店的那些爱刨根问底的学者，以及每天早上蜂拥而至、带着在英国阁楼里找到的无人问津的物品前来摆摊的男男女女们的谈话（“恐怕这不是安妮女王的，夫人——很遗憾，它更接近维多利亚女王的风格”），我获得了作家所能获得的所有人文细节。

Again, when I was asked in 1966 to write a history of the Book-of-the-Month Club to mark its 40th birthday, I thought I might encounter nothing but inert matter. But I found a peppery human element on both sides of the fence, for the books had always been selected by a panel of strong-minded judges and sent to equally stubborn subscribers, who never hesitated to wrap up a book they didn’t like and send it right back. I was given more than a thousand pages of transcribed interviews with the five original judges (Heywood Broun, Henry Seidel Canby, Dorothy Canfield, Christopher Morley and William Allen White), to which I added my own interviews with the club’s founder, Harry Scherman, and with the judges who were then active. The result was four decades’ worth of personal memories on how America’s reading tastes had changed, and even the books took on a life of their own and became characters in my story:

1966年，我受邀为“每月一书俱乐部”撰写历史，以纪念其成立40周年。当时，我以为会遇到一些枯燥乏味的资料。然而，我却发现俱乐部内外都充满了鲜活的人性。因为这些书籍一直以来都由一群个性鲜明的评委挑选，并寄送给同样固执的订户。而订户们也从不犹豫，一旦发现不喜欢的书，就会毫不犹豫地将其退回。我收到了超过一千页的访谈记录，采访对象是五位创始评委（海伍德·布朗、亨利·塞德尔·坎比、多萝西·坎菲尔德、克里斯托弗·莫利和威廉·艾伦·怀特）。此外，我还采访了俱乐部的创始人哈里·舍曼以及当时的几位评委。最终，我得以记录下这四十年来美国人阅读口味的变迁，甚至连书籍本身也仿佛有了生命，成为了我故事中的角色。

“Probably it’s difficult for anyone who remembers the prodigious success of Gone With the Wind ,” Dorothy Canfield said, “to think how it would have seemed to people who encountered it simply as a very, very long and detailed book about the Civil War and its aftermath. We had never heard of the author and didn’t have anybody else’s opinion on it. It was chosen with a little difficulty, because some of the characterization was not very authentic or convincing. But as a narrative it had the quality which the French call attention: it made you want to turn over the page to see what happens next. I remember that someone commented, ‘Well, people may not like it very much, but nobody can deny that it gives a lot of reading for your money.’ Its tremendous success was, I must say, about as surprising to us as to anybody else.”

“对于任何记得《飘》巨大成功的人来说，”多萝西·坎菲尔德说道，“恐怕很难想象，当初人们仅仅把它当作一本篇幅很长、内容详尽的关于美国内战及其后果的书来读时，会作何感想。我们之前从未听说过这位作者，也没有其他人对这本书的评价。选择这本书的过程颇为艰难，因为书中一些人物的刻画并不十分真实可信。但作为一部叙事作品，它具备法国人所说的‘引人入胜’的特质：它让你忍不住一页接一页地读下去，看看接下来会发生什么。我记得有人评论说：‘嗯，人们或许不太喜欢这本书，但不可否认的是，它绝对物超所值。’说实话，它的巨大成功对我们来说，和对其他人一样，都感到十分意外。”

Those three examples are typical of the kind of information that is locked inside people’s heads, which a good nonfiction writer must unlock. The best way to practice is to go out and interview people. The interview itself is one of the most popular nonfiction forms, so you should master it early.

这三个例子典型地展现了人们头脑中隐藏的信息类型，而优秀的非虚构作家必须能够将其挖掘出来。最好的练习方法就是走出去采访他人。采访本身就是最受欢迎的非虚构写作形式之一，所以你应该尽早掌握它。

How should you start? First, decide what person you want to interview. If you are a college student, don’t interview your roommate. With all due respect for what terrific roommates you’ve got, they probably don’t have much to say that the rest of us want to hear. To learn the craft of nonfiction you must push yourself out into the real world—your town or your city or your county—and pretend that you’re writing for a real publication. If it helps, decide which publication you are hypothetically writing for. Choose as your subject someone whose job is so important, or so interesting, or so unusual that the average reader would want to read about that person.

如何开始呢？首先，决定你想采访谁。如果你是大学生，千万别采访你的室友。虽然我很尊重你的室友，但他们可能没什么我们想听的内容。要想学习非虚构写作，你必须走出舒适区，走进现实世界——你的城镇、城市或县——并假装自己在为一家真正的出版物撰稿。如果需要，可以先设想一下你假设要为哪家出版物撰稿。选择一位工作非常重要、非常有趣或非常独特的人作为你的采访对象，这样普通读者才会想了解他的故事。

That doesn’t mean he or she has to be president of the bank. It can be the owner of the local pizza parlor or supermarket or hairdressing academy. It can be the fisherman who puts out to sea every morning, or the Little League manager, or the nurse. It can be the butcher, the baker or—better yet, if you can find him—the candlestick maker. Look for the women in your community who are unraveling the old myths about what the two sexes were foreordained to do. Choose, in short, someone who touches some corner of the reader’s life.

这并不意味着他或她必须是银行行长。可以是当地披萨店、超市或美发学院的老板。可以是每天清晨出海的渔夫，也可以是少棒联盟的经理，或者护士。可以是屠夫、面包师，或者——如果你能找到的话——蜡烛匠。在你的社区里寻找那些正在打破关于两性职责的旧观念的女性。简而言之，选择一个能触动读者生活某个角落的人。

Interviewing is one of those skills you can only get better at. You will never again feel so ill at ease as when you try it for the first time, and probably you’ll never feel entirely comfortable prodding another person for answers he or she may be too shy or too inarticulate to reveal. But much of the skill is mechanical. The rest is instinct—knowing how to make the other person relax, when to push, when to listen, when to stop. This can all be learned with experience.

面试是一项可以不断精进的技能。你永远不会再像第一次尝试时那样感到那么不自在，而且你可能永远也无法完全自如地去追问那些因为害羞或表达能力不足而难以启齿的问题。但这项技能很大程度上是机械性的，其余部分则是一种直觉——知道如何让对方放松，何时该追问，何时该倾听，何时该适可而止。这些都可以通过经验积累。

The basic tools for an interview are paper and some well-sharpened pencils. Is that insultingly obvious advice? You’d be surprised how many writers venture forth to stalk their quarry with no pencil, or with one that breaks, or with a pen that doesn’t work, and with nothing to write on. “Be prepared” is as apt a motto for the nonfiction writer on his rounds as it is for the Boy Scout.

采访的基本工具是纸和几支削好的铅笔。这建议是不是太显而易见了？你会惊讶地发现，有多少作家出门采访时，要么没带铅笔，要么铅笔断了，要么钢笔坏了，甚至连纸笔都没有。“做好准备”这句格言，对于四处奔波的非虚构作家来说，和对于童子军来说一样适用。

But keep your notebook out of sight until you need it. There’s nothing less likely to relax a person than the arrival of a stranger with a stenographer’s pad. Both of you need time to get to know each other. Take a while just to chat, gauging what sort of person you’re dealing with, getting him or her to trust you.

但除非需要，否则别轻易拿出笔记本。没有什么比陌生人拿着速记本出现更让人紧张的了。你们都需要时间来互相了解。花点时间聊聊天，观察对方是什么样的人，赢得他的信任。

Never go into an interview without doing whatever homework you can. If you are interviewing a town official, know his or her voting record. If it’s an actress, know what plays or movies she has been in. You will be resented if you inquire about facts you could have learned in advance.

面试前务必做好充分的准备工作。如果面试对象是市政官员，要了解其投票记录；如果是演员，要知道她参演过哪些戏剧或电影。如果你询问一些本可以事先了解的信息，对方会感到不满。

Make a list of likely questions—it will save you the vast embarrassment of going dry in mid-interview. Perhaps you won’t need the list; better questions will occur to you, or the people being interviewed will veer off at an angle you couldn’t have foreseen. Here you can only go by intuition. If they stray hopelessly off the subject, drag them back. If you like the new direction, follow along and forget the questions you intended to ask.

列一张可能要问的问题清单——这能避免你在面试中途哑口无言的尴尬。当然，也许你根本不需要这份清单；你会突然想到更好的问题，或者受访者会朝着你意想不到的方向发展。这时，你只能依靠直觉了。如果他们彻底跑题，那就想办法把话题拉回来。如果你喜欢这个新的方向，那就顺着他们的思路走下去，忘掉你原本打算问的问题吧。

Many beginning interviewers are inhibited by the fear that they are imposing on other people and have no right to invade their privacy. This fear is almost wholly unfounded. The so-called man in the street is delighted that somebody wants to interview him. Most men and women lead lives, if not of quiet desperation, at least of desperate quietness, and they jump at a chance to talk about their work to an outsider who seems eager to listen.

许多新手采访者都害怕打扰他人，担心自己无权侵犯他人隐私。这种担忧几乎完全没有根据。普通人其实很乐意接受采访。大多数人的生活即便不是默默无闻的绝望，至少也是令人窒息的平静，因此他们非常乐意向一个似乎愿意倾听的外人讲述自己的工作。

This doesn’t necessarily mean it will go well. Often you will be talking to people who have never been interviewed before, and they will warm to the process awkwardly, self-consciously, perhaps not giving you anything you can use. Come back another day; it will go better. You will both even begin to enjoy it—proof that you aren’t forcing your victims to do something they really don’t want to do.

但这并不意味着采访一定会顺利。通常情况下，你会遇到一些从未接受过采访的人，他们会显得笨拙、拘谨，可能根本无法提供任何有用的信息。不妨改天再来，情况会好转。你们双方甚至会开始享受这个过程——这证明你并没有强迫受访者做他们真正不想做的事情。

Speaking of tools, is it all right (you ask) to use a tape recorder? Why not just take one along, start it going, and forget all that business of pencil and paper?

说到工具，你可能会问，用录音机可以吗？为什么不带一台，开始录音，然后把纸笔之类的东西都忘掉呢？

Obviously the tape recorder is a superb machine for capturing what people have to say—especially people who, for reasons of their culture or temperament, would never get around to writing it down. In such areas as social history and anthropology it’s invaluable. I admire the books of Studs Terkel, such as Hard Times: An Oral History of the Great Depression , which he “wrote” by recording interviews with ordinary people and patching the results into coherent shape. I also like the question-and-answer interviews, obtained by tape recorder, that are published in certain magazines. They have the sound of spontaneity, the refreshing absence of a writer hovering over the product and burnishing it to a high gloss.

显然，录音机是记录人们所说的话的绝佳工具——尤其适合那些由于文化或性格原因而从未想过要写下来的人。在社会史和人类学等领域，它的价值更是无可估量。我非常欣赏斯塔兹·特克尔（Studs Terkel）的著作，例如《艰难岁月：大萧条口述史》（Hard Times: An Oral History of the Great Depression），他通过录制普通人的访谈，并将这些录音整理成一部连贯的作品。我也喜欢某些杂志上刊登的、用录音机录制的问答式访谈。这些访谈听起来自然流畅，没有作者的过度修饰和润色，令人耳目一新。

Strictly, however, this isn’t writing. It’s a process of asking questions and then pruning and splicing and editing the transcribed answers, and it takes a tremendous amount of time and labor. Educated people who you think have been talking into your tape recorder with linear precision turn out to have been stumbling so aimlessly over the sands of language that they haven’t completed a single decent sentence. The ear makes allowances for missing grammar, syntax and transitions that the eye wouldn’t tolerate in print. The seemingly simple use of a tape recorder isn’t simple; infinite stitchery is required.

严格来说，这并非写作。这是一个提出问题，然后对转录的答案进行删减、拼接和编辑的过程，需要耗费大量的时间和精力。你以为那些受过良好教育的人对着你的录音机侃侃而谈，结果却发现他们只是漫无目的地在语言的沙海中跌跌撞撞，甚至连一句像样的句子都没说完。耳朵能够容忍语法、句法和过渡的缺失，而眼睛在印刷品中却无法容忍。看似简单的录音机使用起来并不简单；它需要无休止的拼接。

But my main reasons for warning you off it are practical. One hazard is that you don’t usually have a tape recorder with you; you are more likely to have a pencil. Another is that tape recorders malfunction. Few moments in journalism are as glum as the return of a reporter with “a really great story,” followed by his pushing of the PLAY button and silence. But above all, a writer should be able to see his materials. If your interview is on tape you become a listener, forever fussing with the machine, running it backward to find the brilliant remark you can never quite find, running it forward, stopping, starting, driving yourself crazy. Be a writer. Write things down.

但我劝你别这么做的主要原因还是出于实际考虑。首先，你通常不会随身携带录音机；你更有可能带的是铅笔。其次，录音机容易出故障。新闻工作中，最令人沮丧的时刻莫过于记者带着“一个绝妙的故事”回来，然后按下播放键，一切归于沉寂。但最重要的是，作家应该能够看到自己的素材。如果你的采访被录音，你就只能听，不停地摆弄机器，倒放着试图找到那句永远也找不到的精彩评论，正放着，停停停，反复播放，把自己逼疯。做个作家吧。把东西写下来。

I do my interviewing by hand, with a sharp No. 1 pencil. I like the transaction with another person. I like the fact that that person can see me working —doing a job, not just sitting there letting a machine do it for me. Only once did I use a tape recorder extensively: for my book, Mitchell & Ruff , about the jazz musicians Willie Ruff and Dwike Mitchell. Although I knew both men well, I felt that a white writer who presumes to write about the black experience has an obligation to get the tonalities right. It’s not that Ruff and Mitchell speak a different kind of English; they speak good and often eloquent English. But as Southern blacks they use certain words and idioms that are distinctive to their heritage, adding richness and humor to what they say. I didn’t want to miss any of those usages. My tape recorder caught them all, and readers of the book can hear that I got the two men right. Consider using a tape recorder in situations where you might violate the cultural integrity of the people you’re interviewing.

我的采访都是手工进行的，用的是一支削尖的1号铅笔。我喜欢与人交流的感觉。我喜欢对方能看到我工作——在做事，而不是坐在那里让机器代劳。我只在一次采访中大量使用过录音机：那就是为我的书《米切尔与拉夫》——关于爵士音乐家威利·拉夫和德威克·米切尔——录制录音的时候。虽然我和他们都很熟，但我认为，一个自认为有资格描写黑人经历的白人作家，有责任准确地把握语调。这并不是说拉夫和米切尔说的英语不一样；他们的英语很好，而且常常很流畅优美。但作为南方黑人，他们会使用一些独特的词汇和习语，这些词汇和习语体现了他们的文化传承，为他们的谈话增添了丰富性和幽默感。我不想错过任何一个这样的用法。我的录音机把它们全都录了下来，读者可以从书中感受到，我对这两位音乐家的描述是准确的。在可能会侵犯被采访者文化完整性的情况下，请考虑使用录音机。

Taking notes, however, has one big problem: the person you’re interviewing often starts talking faster than you can write. You are still scribbling Sentence A when he zooms into Sentence B. You drop Sentence A and pursue him into Sentence B, meanwhile trying to hold the rest of Sentence A in your inner ear and hoping Sentence C will be a dud that you can skip altogether, using the time to catch up. Unfortunately, you now have your subject going at high speed. He is finally saying all the things you have been trying to cajole out of him for an hour, and saying them with what seems to be Churchillian eloquence. Your inner ear is clogging up with sentences you want to grab before they slip away.

然而，记笔记有个大问题：被采访者说话的速度往往比你记笔记的速度快。你还在奋笔疾书地记着A句，他就已经滔滔不绝地讲起B句了。你只好放下A句，追着他讲B句，同时努力把A句剩下的内容记在心里，希望C句是个无关紧要的小问题，可以跳过，好利用这段时间跟上他的思路。不幸的是，现在采访对象语速飞快。他终于把那些你费尽心思哄骗了一个小时才问出来的问题都说了出来，而且说得好像丘吉尔一样雄辩滔滔。你的耳朵里塞满了想要抓住的句子，生怕它们溜走。

Tell him to stop. Just say, “Hold it a minute, please,” and write until you catch up. What you are trying to do with your feverish scribbling is to quote him correctly, and nobody wants to be misquoted.

让他停下来。就说：“请稍等片刻”，然后继续写，直到你跟上他。你拼命记下他的话是为了准确引用，谁也不想被曲解。

With practice you will write faster and develop some form of shorthand. You’ll find yourself devising abbreviations for often-used words and also omitting the small connective syntax.
