I am 15 and am considered pretty in my group. I wear baby pink rollers, jumbo size. I have been going steady with a certain boy for 2½ years and he has never seen me without my rollers. The other night I took them off and we had a terrible fight. “Your head looks small,” he told me. He called me a dwarf and said I had misled him. How can I win him back?

我今年15岁，在同龄人中算是长得好看的。我戴着粉红色的大号发卷。我和一个男生交往两年半了，他从来没见过我不戴发卷的样子。前几天晚上我摘掉了发卷，结果我们大吵了一架。“你的头看起来好小，”他骂我，还说我是个侏儒，骗了他。我该怎么挽回他呢？

H EARTSICK
心碎
Speonk, N.Y .
纽约州斯皮昂克

Dear Heartsick:

亲爱的心碎者：

You have only yourself to blame for doing something so stupid. The latest “Haircurl” survey shows that 94% of American girls now wear rollers in their hair 21.6 hours a day and 359 days a year. You tried to be different and you lost your fella. Take our advice and get some super-jumbo rollers (they come in your favorite baby pink shade, too) and your head will look bigger than ever and twice as lovely. Don’t ever take them off again.

你做这么蠢的事，只能怪自己。最新的“Haircurl”调查显示，94%的美国女孩现在每天戴21.6小时、每年戴359天的卷发棒。你想标新立异，结果却失去了你的男朋友。听我们的劝告，买几个超大号的卷发棒（还有你最爱的婴儿粉色哦），你的头看起来会比以往任何时候都更大更可爱。以后就别摘下来了。

Dear Haircurl:

亲爱的卷发：

My boyfriend likes to run his fingers through my hair. The trouble is he keeps getting them pinched in my rollers. The other night a terribly embarrassing episode happened. We were at the movies and somehow my boyfriend got two of his fingers caught (it was right where the medium roller meets the clipcurl) and couldn’t get them out. I felt very conspicuous leaving the theater with his hand still in my hair, and going home on the bus several people gave us “funny looks.” Fortunately I was able to reach my stylist at home and he came right over with his tools and got poor Jerry loose. Jerry was very mad and said he’s not going to date me again until I get some rollers that don’t have this particular habit. I think he is being unfair, but he “means business.” Can you help me?

我男朋友喜欢用手指梳我的头发。问题是，他的手指总是会被我的卷发器夹住。前几天晚上发生了一件特别尴尬的事。我们去看电影，不知怎么的，我男朋友的两根手指被卷进去了（就在中号卷发器和夹子连接的地方），怎么也拔不出来。我走出电影院的时候，他的手还夹在我的头发里，感觉特别显眼。回家的路上，好几个人都用异样的眼光看我们。幸好我联系上了我的发型师，他立刻带着工具过来，帮可怜的杰瑞把手指解开了。杰瑞非常生气，说除非我换一套不会夹手指的卷发器，否则他不会再跟我约会了。我觉得他有点不公平，但他是认真的。你能帮帮我吗？

F RANTIC
Buffalo

疯狂的布法罗

Dear Frantic Buffalo:

亲爱的疯狂水牛：

We’re sorry to have to tell you that no rollers have yet been developed that do not occasionally catch the fingers of boys who tousle. The roller industry, however, is working very hard on the problem, as this complaint frequently comes up. Meanwhile why not ask Jerry to wear mittens? That way you’ll be happy and he’ll be safe.

很遗憾地告诉您，目前还没有研发出完全不会夹到男孩玩耍时手指的滚筒。不过，滚筒行业正在努力解决这个问题，因为这类问题经常被提及。与此同时，不妨让杰瑞戴上连指手套？这样您既放心，他也安全了。

There were many more, and perhaps I even made a small contribution to Lady Bird Johnson’s “beautification” program. But the point is this: once you’ve read that article you can never look at hair curlers in the same way again. You’ve been jolted by humor into looking with a fresh eye at something bizarre in our daily environment that was previously taken for granted. The subject here isn’t important—hair curlers won’t be the ruin of our society. But the method will work for subjects that are important, or for almost any subject, if you can find the right comic frame.

还有很多其他例子，或许我也为“伯德·约翰逊夫人”的“美化”计划贡献了一份力量。但重点是：读完那篇文章后，你对卷发器的看法将彻底改变。幽默让你以一种全新的视角审视日常生活中那些习以为常却又显得怪异的事物。这里讨论的话题并不重要——卷发器不会毁掉我们的社会。但这种方法适用于重要的话题，或者几乎任何话题，只要你能找到合适的幽默切入点。

Over the last five years of the old Life , 1968–1972, I used humor to get at a number of unlikely subjects, such as the excesses of military power and nuclear testing. One column was on the petty squabbling over the shape of the table at the Vietnam peace conference in Paris. The situation had become so outrageous after nine weeks that it could be approached only through ridicule, and I described various efforts to get peace at my own dinner table by changing its shape every night, or by lowering the chairs of different people to give them less “status,” or by turning their chairs around so the rest of us wouldn’t have to “recognize” them. It was exactly what was happening in Paris.

在《生活》杂志1968年至1972年这五年间，我曾用幽默的方式探讨过许多看似无关的话题，例如军事力量的过度扩张和核试验。其中一篇专栏文章就描写了巴黎越南和平会议上因餐桌形状而引发的琐碎争吵。九周的会议结束后，事态已经变得如此荒唐，以至于只能用嘲讽来应对。我描述了自己为了在餐桌上实现和平而做出的各种尝试：比如每晚改变餐桌的形状，或者把某些人的椅子放低以降低他们的“地位”，又或者把他们的椅子转个方向，这样其他人就不用“认出”他们了。而这，恰恰就是当时在巴黎发生的事情。

What made those pieces work was that they stuck close to the form they were parodying. Humor may seem to be an act of gross exaggeration. But the hair curler letters wouldn’t succeed if we didn’t recognize them as a specific journalistic form, both in their style and in their mentality. Control is vital to humor. Don’t use comical names like Throttlebottom. Don’t make the same kind of joke two or three times—readers will enjoy themselves more if you make it only once. Trust the sophistication of readers who do know what you’re doing, and don’t worry about the rest.

这些作品之所以成功，是因为它们忠实地模仿了被戏仿的形式。幽默看似夸张，但如果我们不把卷发器信件视为一种特定的新闻形式——无论从风格还是思维方式上——它们就不会成功。控制是幽默的关键。不要使用像“Throttlebottom”（油门到底）这样滑稽的名字。不要重复同样的笑话两三次——读者只听一次就足够了。相信那些了解你意图的读者的鉴赏力，至于其他人，就别担心了。

The columns that I wrote for Life made people laugh. But they had a serious purpose, which was to say: “Something crazy is going on here—some erosion in the quality of life, or some threat to life itself, and yet everyone assumes it’s normal.” Today the outlandish becomes routine overnight. The humorist is trying to say that it’s still outlandish.

我为《生活》杂志写的专栏文章逗人发笑，但它们背后却有着严肃的目的，那就是要指出：“这里正在发生一些匪夷所思的事情——生活质量在下降，或者生命本身受到了威胁，然而每个人都习以为常。”如今，荒诞之事一夜之间就变成了司空见惯。而幽默作家试图表达的是，这一切依然荒诞不经。

I remember a cartoon by Bill Mauldin during the student turmoil of the late 1960s, when infantrymen and tanks were summoned to keep peace at a college in North Carolina and undergraduates at Berkeley were dispersed by a helicopter spraying them with Mace. The cartoon showed a mother pleading with her son’s draft board: “He’s an only child—please get him off the campus.” It was Mauldin’s way of pinning down this particular lunacy, and he was right on target—in fact, at the center of the bull’s-eye, as the killing of four students at Kent State University proved not long after his cartoon appeared.

我记得比尔·莫尔丁在20世纪60年代末学生骚乱期间画过一幅漫画。当时，北卡罗来纳州一所大学动用步兵和坦克维持秩序，而加州大学伯克利分校的本科生则被直升机喷洒胡椒喷雾驱散。漫画中，一位母亲恳求征兵委员会：“他是独生子——求求你们让他离开校园。”莫尔丁用这幅漫画精准地讽刺了当时的荒谬行径，而且他一针见血——事实上，他正中靶心，因为肯特州立大学四名学生被杀的事件就证明了这一点，而这幅漫画发表后不久就发生了。

The targets will change from week to week, but there will never be a dearth of new lunacies and dangers for the humorist to fight. Lyndon Johnson, in the years of his disastrous war in Vietnam, was brought down partly by Jules Feiffer and Art Buchwald. Senator Joseph McCarthy and Vice-President Spiro Agnew were brought down partly by Walt Kelly in the comic strip Pogo . H. L. Mencken brought down a whole galaxy of hypocrites in high places, and “Boss” Tweed of Tammany Hall was partly toppled by the cartoons of Thomas Nast. Mort Sahl, a comic, was the only person who stayed awake during the Eisenhower years, when America was under sedation and didn’t want to be disturbed. Many people regarded Sahl as a cynic, but he thought of himself as an idealist. “If I criticize somebody,” he said, “it’s because I have higher hopes for the world, something good to replace the bad. I’m not saying what the Beat Generation says: ‘Go away because I’m not involved.’ I’m here and I’m involved.”

每周的讽刺对象都会有所不同，但幽默作家永远不会缺少新的荒诞和危险需要应对。林登·约翰逊在越南战争灾难性的那些年里，部分败北要归功于朱尔斯·费弗和阿特·布赫瓦尔德的讽刺。参议员约瑟夫·麦卡锡和副总统斯皮罗·阿格纽的垮台，部分要归功于沃尔特·凯利在漫画《波戈》中的创作。H·L·门肯揭露了一大批身居高位的伪君子，而坦慕尼协会的“老板”特威德的垮台，部分要归功于托马斯·纳斯特的漫画。莫特·萨尔是一位漫画家，在艾森豪威尔执政时期，当美国处于麻木状态，不愿被打扰时，他是唯一一个保持清醒的人。许多人认为萨尔是个愤世嫉俗的人，但他自认为是个理想主义者。 “如果我批评某人，”他说，“那是因为我对世界抱有更高的期望，希望美好的事物能够取代糟糕的事物。我不是在说垮掉的一代会说的话：‘滚开，因为我不参与。’我在这里，我参与其中。”

“I’m here and I’m involved”: make that your creed if you want to write serious humor. Humorists operate on a deeper current than most people suspect. They must be willing to go against the grain, to say what the populace and the President may not want to hear. Art Buchwald and Garry Trudeau perform an act of courage every week. They say things that need to be said that a regular columnist couldn’t get away with. What saves them is that politicians are not known for humor and are therefore even more befuddled by it than the general public.

“我在这里，我参与其中”：如果你想写严肃的幽默作品，就把这当作你的信条。幽默作家的创作背后蕴藏着比大多数人想象的更深层次的思考。他们必须敢于逆潮流而行，说出民众和总统可能不想听的话。阿特·布赫瓦尔德和加里·特鲁多每周都在展现勇气。他们说出那些普通专栏作家不敢说的话。而他们之所以能成功，是因为政客们并不以幽默著称，因此比普通民众更难理解幽默的含义。

But humor has many uses besides the topical. They aren’t as urgent, but they help us to look at far older problems of the heart, the home, the family, the job and all the other frustrations of just getting from morning to night. I once interviewed Chic Young, creator of Blondie , when he had been writing and drawing that daily and Sunday comic strip for 40 years, or 14,500 strips. It was the most popular of all strips, reaching 60 million readers in every corner of the world, and I asked Young why it was so durable.

但幽默除了切合时事之外，还有许多其他用途。它们或许不那么紧迫，但却能帮助我们审视那些更为古老的问题，比如心灵、家庭、工作，以及从早到晚生活中种种令人沮丧的琐事。我曾采访过《金发女郎》（Blondie）的创作者奇克·杨（Chic Young），当时他已经创作这部每日和周日连载漫画长达40年，共创作了14500幅。它是所有漫画中最受欢迎的，拥有遍布全球的6000万读者。我问杨，这部漫画为何如此经久不衰。

“It’s durable because it’s simple,” he said. “It’s built on four things that everybody does: sleeping, eating, raising a family and making money.” The comic variations on those four themes are as numerous in the strip as they are in life. Dagwood’s efforts to get money from his boss, Mr. Dithers, have their perpetual counterweight in Blondie’s efforts to spend it. “I try to keep Dagwood in a world that people are used to,” Young told me. “He never does anything as special as playing golf, and the people who come to the door are just the people that an average family has to deal with.”

“它经久不衰是因为它简单，”他说。“它建立在每个人都会做的四件事之上：睡觉、吃饭、养家糊口和赚钱。”这四个主题在漫画中衍生出的滑稽变化，在现实生活中也同样层出不穷。达格伍德想方设法从老板迪瑟斯先生那里弄钱，而布隆迪则想方设法把钱花掉，两者之间始终存在着一种微妙的平衡。“我努力让达格伍德生活在一个人们习以为常的世界里，”杨告诉我。“他从来不会做像打高尔夫球这样特别的事情，来敲他家门的人也只是普通家庭每天都要面对的那些人。”

I cite Young’s four themes to remind you that most humor, however freakish it may seem, is based on fundamental truths. Humor is not a separate organism that can survive on its own frail metabolism. It’s a special angle of vision granted to certain writers who already write good English. They aren’t writing about life that’s essentially ludicrous; they are writing about life that’s essentially serious, but their eye falls on areas where serious hopes are mocked by some ironic turn of fate—“the strange incongruity,” as Stephen Leacock put it, “between our aspiration and our achievement.” E. B. White made the same point. “I don’t like the word ‘humorist,’” he said. “It seems to me misleading. Humor is a by-product that occurs in the serious work of some and not others. I was more influenced by Don Marquis than by Ernest Hemingway, by Perelman than by Dreiser.”

我引用杨格的四个主题，是为了提醒大家，大多数幽默，无论看起来多么怪诞，都建立在基本真理之上。幽默并非一个可以依靠自身脆弱的新陈代谢而独立存在的有机体。它是一种特殊的视角，赋予某些已经能写出优秀英文作品的作家。他们描写的并非本质上荒诞的生活；他们描写的是本质上严肃的生活，但他们的目光聚焦于那些严肃的希望被命运的某种讽刺性转折所嘲弄的领域——正如斯蒂芬·利科克所说，“我们的理想与现实之间的奇特不协调”。E·B·怀特也表达了同样的观点。“我不喜欢‘幽默作家’这个词，”他说，“在我看来，它具有误导性。幽默是某些作家严肃作品中的副产品，而另一些作家则没有。我受唐·马奎斯的影响比欧内斯特·海明威更大，受佩雷尔曼的影响比德莱塞更大。”

Therefore I suggest several principles for the writer of humor. Master the craft of writing good “straight” English; humorists from Mark Twain to Russell Baker are, first of all, superb writers. Don’t search for the outlandish and scorn what seems too ordinary; you will touch more chords by finding what’s funny in what you know to be true. Finally, don’t strain for laughs; humor is built on surprise, and you can surprise the reader only so often.

因此，我建议幽默作家遵循以下几条原则。首先，要掌握流畅、简洁的英语写作技巧；从马克·吐温到罗素·贝克，所有幽默作家首先都是杰出的作家。其次，不要刻意追求怪诞离奇，也不要轻视平凡琐碎；在真实生活中发现幽默，才能真正触动人心。最后，不要刻意制造笑点；幽默建立在惊喜之上，而惊喜的次数终究有限。

Unfortunately for writers, humor is elusive and subjective. No two people think the same things are funny, and a piece that one magazine will reject as a dud is often published by another that finds it a jewel. The reasons for rejection are equally elusive. “It just doesn’t work,” editors say, and there’s not much they can add. Occasionally such a piece can be made to work—it has some flaw that can be repaired. Mortality, however, is high. “Humor can be dissected, as a frog can,” E. B. White once wrote, “but the thing dies in the process and the innards are discouraging to any but the pure scientific mind.”

对作家来说，不幸的是，幽默既难以捉摸又主观。没有两个人觉得同样的东西好笑，一篇被一家杂志拒稿的文章，往往会被另一家杂志奉为瑰宝。拒稿的原因同样难以捉摸。“就是不行，”编辑们会这么说，而且他们也说不出什么别的办法。偶尔，这样的文章也能被改写——它存在一些可以弥补的缺陷。然而，失败的几率却很高。“幽默可以像解剖青蛙一样被剖析，”E·B·怀特曾写道，“但在这个过程中，幽默本身就死了，而除了纯粹的科学思维之外，任何人都无法理解其中的奥秘。”

I’m no fancier of dead frogs, but I wanted to see if at least a few lessons could be learned by poking about in the innards, and when I was teaching at Yale I decided, one year, to teach a course in humor writing. I warned my students that possibly it couldn’t be done and that we might end up killing the thing we loved. Luckily, humor not only didn’t die; it bloomed in the desert of solemn term papers, and I repeated the course the following year. Let me briefly reconstruct our journey.

我并不喜欢死青蛙，但我还是想看看，从它们的内脏里能不能学到点什么。在耶鲁大学教书的时候，我曾决定开设一门幽默写作课。我事先警告过我的学生，这门课可能根本行不通，我们甚至可能会扼杀我们所热爱的东西。幸运的是，幽默不仅没有消亡，反而在严肃的学期论文荒漠中绽放光彩。第二年，我又重新开设了这门课。让我简要地回顾一下我们的这段旅程。

“I hope to point out that American humor has an honorable literature,” I wrote in a memo for prospective students, “and to consider the influence of certain pioneers on their successors.... Although the line between ‘fiction’ and ‘nonfiction’ is fuzzy in humor, I see this as a nonfiction course: what you write will be based on external events. I’m not interested in ‘creative writing,’ flights of pure imagination and pointless whimsy.”

“我希望指出美国幽默拥有可贵的文学底蕴，”我在给未来学生的备忘录中写道，“并探讨某些先驱对后人的影响……尽管幽默中‘虚构’与‘非虚构’的界限模糊不清，但我认为这是一门非虚构写作课程：你们的写作将基于外部事件。我对‘创意写作’、纯粹的想象和毫无意义的奇思妙想不感兴趣。”

I began by reading excerpts from early writers to show that a humorist can employ a wide range of literary forms, or invent new ones. We started with George Ade’s “Fables in Slang,” the first of which appeared in 1897 in the Chicago Record , where Ade was a reporter. “He was just sitting unsuspectingly in front of a sheet of paper,” Jean Shepherd writes in a fine introduction to his anthology, The America of George Ade , “when the innocent idea came to him to write something in fable form, using the language and the clichés of the moment. In other words, slang. To let people know that he knew better than to use slang in writing, he decided to capitalize all suspicious words and phrases. He was mortally afraid people would think he was illiterate.”

我首先阅读了一些早期作家的作品节选，以此说明幽默作家可以运用多种文学形式，甚至创造新的形式。我们从乔治·阿德的《俚语寓言》开始，该系列的第一篇发表于1897年的《芝加哥记录报》，当时阿德是该报的记者。让·谢泼德在他的文集《乔治·阿德的美国》的精彩导言中写道：“他当时只是毫无防备地坐在纸前，突然萌生了一个天真的想法：用当时流行的语言和陈词滥调，写一些寓言故事。换句话说，就是俚语。为了让人们知道他不会在写作中使用俚语，他决定把所有可疑的词语和短语都大写。他非常害怕人们会认为他是个文盲。”

He needn’t have worried; by 1900 the Fables were so popular that he was earning $1,000 a week. Here’s “The Fable of the Subordinate Who Saw a Great Light”:

他完全不必担心；到了1900年，这些寓言故事非常受欢迎，他每周能赚到1000美元。以下是《下属看到一道大光的寓言》：

Once there was an Employé who was getting the Nub End of the Deal. He kicked on the long Hours and the small Salary, and helped to organize a Clerks’ Protective Association. He was for the Toiler as against the Main Squeeze.

从前有个员工，他觉得自己待遇很差。他抱怨工时长、薪水低，于是帮忙组织了一个职员保护协会。他站在劳动者一边，反对老板的剥削。

To keep him simmered down, the Owners gave him an Interest. After that he began to perspire when he looked at the Pay-Roll, and it did seem to him that a lot of big, lazy Lummixes were standing around the shop doing the Soldier Act. He learned to snap his Fingers every time the Office Boy giggled. As for the faithful old Book-Keeper who wanted an increase to $9 and a week’s Vacation in the Summer, the best he got was a little Talk about Contentment being a Jewel.

为了让他安静下来，老板给了他一份利息。之后，他每次看到工资单就开始冒冷汗，而且在他看来，店里确实有很多又高又懒的卢米克斯人站在那里装模作样地扮演士兵。他学会了每次办公室小弟咯咯笑的时候就打个响指。至于那位忠诚的老记账员，他想要涨到9美元的工资，还要在夏天休一周假，结果得到的只是老板跟他讲了一句“知足常乐”之类的话。

The saddest moment of the Day for him was when the whole Bunch knocked off at 6 o’clock in the Evening. It seemed a Shame to call 10 Hours a Full Day. As for the Saturday Half-Holiday Movement, that was little better than Highway Robbery. Those who formerly slaved alongside of him in the Galleys had to address him as Mister, and he had them numbered the same as Convicts.

对他来说，一天中最悲伤的时刻莫过于傍晚六点整，所有工友都下班的那一刻。十个小时的工作时间，竟被称作“一整天”，实在是一种耻辱。至于所谓的“周六半天假期”，那简直就是明抢。那些曾经和他一起在划桨船上苦苦挣扎的人，现在都得称呼他“先生”，而且他还让他们像囚犯一样被编号。

One day an Underling ventured to remind the Slave-Driver that once he had been the Friend of the Salaried Minion.

有一天，一个下属冒昧地提醒奴隶主，他曾经是领薪水的仆人的朋友。

“Right you are,” said the Boss. “But when I plugged for the lowly Wage-Earner I never had been in the Directors’ Office to see the beautiful Tableau entitled ‘Virtue copping out the Annual Dividend.’ I don’t know that I can make the situation clear to you, so I will merely remark that all those who get on our side of the Fence are enabled to catch a new Angle on this Salary Question.”

“你说得对，”老板说。“但我当初为基层员工争取权益时，从未去过董事会办公室，看到过那幅题为‘美德逃避年度分红’的精美画卷。我不知道该如何向你解释清楚，所以我只想说，所有站在我们这边的人都能从新的角度看待薪酬问题。”

Moral: For Educational Purposes, every Employé should be taken into the Firm .

寓意：为了教育目的，应该让每位员工都进入公司学习。

The universal truth in that hundred-year-old gem is still true today, as it is in almost all the Fables. “Ade was my first influence as a humorist,” S. J. Perelman told me. “He had a social sense of history. His pictures of Hoosier life at the turn of the century are more documentary than any of those studies on how much people paid for their coal. His humor was rooted in a perception of people and places. He had a cutting edge and an acerbic wit that no earlier American humorist had.”

那本百年老书蕴含的普世真理，至今依然适用，正如几乎所有寓言故事一样。“阿德是我幽默创作的启蒙者，”S·J·佩雷尔曼告诉我，“他具有社会历史感。他对世纪之交印第安纳州生活景象的描绘，比那些研究煤炭价格的著作更具纪实性。他的幽默根植于对人物和地域的深刻洞察。他拥有前人所不具备的犀利洞察力和尖刻的智慧。”

From Ade I proceeded to Ring Lardner, author of the classic line “Shut up, he explained,” partly to demonstrate that dramatic dialogue is another form that can serve the humorist. I’m a pushover for Lardner’s nonsense plays, which he presumably wrote just to amuse himself. But he was also lampooning the holy conventions of playwriting, in which yards of italic type are used to establish what’s happening onstage. Act I of Lardner’s I Gaspiri (The Upholsterers) consists of ten lines of dialogue, none of it involving the listed characters, and nine lines of irrelevant italic, concluding with “The curtain is lowered for seven days to denote the lapse of a week.” In his career Lardner would put humor to powerful use in many literary forms, such as the baseball novel, You Know Me, Al . His ear was perfectly tuned to American piety and self-delusion.

从阿德（Ade）之后，我转向了林·拉德纳（Ring Lardner），他创作了经典台词“闭嘴，”他解释道。我之所以选择拉德纳，部分原因是为了说明戏剧对话也是幽默的另一种表达方式。我非常喜欢拉德纳的荒诞剧，他大概只是为了自娱自乐而创作。但他同时也讽刺了戏剧创作中那些神圣的传统——用大量的斜体字来交代舞台上发生的事情。拉德纳的《我，加斯皮里》（I Gaspiri，又名《室内装潢师》）第一幕只有十行对话，没有一行涉及剧中列出的角色，其余九行都是无关的斜体字，最后以“幕布落下七天，象征一周的结束”作结。在拉德纳的创作生涯中，他将幽默巧妙地运用到多种文学形式中，例如棒球小说《你认识我，阿尔》（You Know Me, Al）。他对美国人的虔诚和自欺欺人有着敏锐的洞察力。

Next I resurrected Archy and Mehitabel , by Don Marquis, to show that this influential humorist also used an unorthodox medium—doggerel—for his message. Marquis, a columnist for the New York Sun , stumbled on a novel solution to the newspaperman’s brutal problem of meeting a deadline and presenting his material in orderly prose, just as Ade stumbled on the fable. In 1916 he created the cockroach Archy, who banged out free verse on Marquis’s typewriter at night, minus capital letters because he wasn’t strong enough to press the shift key. Archy’s poems, describing his friendship with a cat named Mehitabel, are of a philosophical bent that one wouldn’t guess from their ragged appearance. No formal essay could more thoroughly deflate the aging actors who bemoan the current state of the theater than Marquis does in “The Old Trouper,” a long poem in which Archy describes Mehitabel’s meeting with an old theater cat named Tom:

接下来，我重提了唐·马奎斯的《阿奇和梅希塔贝尔》，以此表明这位颇具影响力的幽默作家也曾运用一种非传统的媒介——打油诗——来传达他的信息。马奎斯是《纽约太阳报》的专栏作家，他偶然间找到了一种新颖的办法，解决了报社记者面临的既要赶稿又要保持文章条理清晰的难题，正如阿德偶然发现了这则寓言一样。1916年，他创造了蟑螂阿奇，这只蟑螂会在夜里用马奎斯的打字机敲出自由诗，由于力气不够，按不动Shift键，所以诗中没有大写字母。阿奇的诗描述了他与一只名叫梅希塔贝尔的猫之间的友谊，这些诗句虽然看起来有些粗糙，但却蕴含着深刻的哲学意味。没有任何一篇正式的文章能比马奎斯在长诗《老演员》中对那些哀叹剧院现状的老演员们的批评得更彻底。在《老演员》中，阿奇描述了梅希塔贝尔与一只名叫汤姆的老剧院猫的相遇：

i come of a long line

我出身于一个长家族。

of theatre cats

剧院猫

my grandfather

我的祖父

was with forrest

和森林在一起

he had it he was a real trouper …

他有这个能力，他真是个敬业的战士……

Marquis was using the cat to leaven his impatience with a type of bore he knew well. It’s a universal impatience, whatever the category of old-timer, just as it’s a universal trait of old-timers to complain that their field has gone to the dogs. Marquis achieves one of the classic functions of humor: to deflect anger into a channel where we can laugh at frailty instead of railing against it.

马奎斯用猫来缓和自己对某种老顽固的不耐烦。这种不耐烦是所有老人的通病，无论他们属于哪个阶层，就像抱怨田地荒芜是所有老人的共同特征一样。马奎斯做到了幽默的经典功能之一：将愤怒转移到一种可以让我们嘲笑自身弱点而不是抨击弱点的途径上。

The next writers on my tour were Donald Ogden Stewart, Robert Benchley and Frank Sullivan, who greatly broadened the possibilities of “free association” humor. Benchley added a dimension of warmth and vulnerability that wasn’t present in humorists like Ade and Marquis, who ducked into impersonal forms like fable and doggerel, where they could hide. Nobody is better than Benchley at diving headlong into his subject:

我巡回演讲的下一批作家是唐纳德·奥格登·斯图尔特、罗伯特·本奇利和弗兰克·沙利文，他们极大地拓展了“自由联想”幽默的可能性。本奇利的作品增添了一种温暖和脆弱的维度，这是像阿德和马奎斯这样的幽默作家所不具备的，他们躲进了寓言和打油诗等非个人化的形式中，在那里他们可以隐藏自己。没有人比本奇利更擅长全身心地投入到他的主题中：

St. Francis of Assisi (unless I am getting him mixed up with St. Simeon Stylites, which might be very easy to do as both their names begin with “St.”) was very fond of birds, and often had his picture taken with them sitting on his shoulders and pecking at his wrists. That was all right, if St. Francis liked it. We all have our likes and dislikes, and I have more of a feeling for dogs.

圣方济·亚西西（除非我把他和圣西蒙·斯泰莱特搞混了，这很容易，因为他们的名字都以“圣”开头）非常喜欢鸟，经常有人拍他和鸟儿的合影，鸟儿会停在他的肩膀上，啄他的手腕。如果圣方济喜欢，那当然没问题。我们每个人都有自己的喜好，而我更喜欢狗。

Perhaps they were all just paving the way for S. J. Perelman. If so, Perelman gratefully acknowledged the debt. “You must learn by imitation,” he said. “I could have been arrested for imitating Lardner in my pieces in the late 1920s—not the content, but the manner. These influences gradually fall away.”

或许他们都在为S·J·佩雷尔曼铺路。如果是这样，佩雷尔曼欣然承认了这份恩情。“你必须通过模仿来学习，”他说。“在20世纪20年代末，我的作品模仿拉德纳的风格，而不是内容，差点被逮捕。这些影响会逐渐消失。”

His own influence hasn’t been so easily shed. At his death in 1979 he had been writing steadily for more than half a century, putting the language through breathtaking loops, and the woods are still full of writers and comics who were drawn into the gravitational pull of his style and never quite got back out. It doesn’t take a detective to see Perelman’s hand not only in writers like Woody Allen but in the BBC’s Goon Show and Monty Python , in the radio skits of Bob and Ray, and in the glancing wit of Groucho Marx—an influence more easily traceable because Perelman wrote several of the Marx Brothers’ early movies.

他的影响并非轻易就能消散。1979年去世时，他笔耕不辍超过半个世纪，将语言运用得炉火纯青，令人叹为观止。时至今日，仍有许多作家和喜剧演员被他的风格所吸引，从此无法自拔。无需费心思，就能看出佩雷尔曼的影子不仅体现在伍迪·艾伦这样的作家身上，也体现在BBC的《傻瓜秀》（Goon Show）和《巨蟒剧团》（Monty Python）中，体现在鲍勃和雷的广播小品中，也体现在格劳乔·马克斯的妙语连珠中——这种影响更容易被追溯，因为佩雷尔曼曾为马克斯兄弟的几部早期电影撰写剧本。

What he created was an awareness that when the writer’s mind works by free association it can ricochet from the normal to the absurd and, by the unexpectedness of its angle, demolish whatever trite idea had been there before. Onto this element of constant surprise he grafted the dazzling wordplay that was his trademark, a rich and recondite vocabulary, and an erudition based on reading and travel.

他创造了一种意识：当作家的思维自由联想时，它便能在寻常与荒诞之间跳跃，并以其出人意料的角度，摧毁先前一切陈腐的观念。他将自己标志性的炫目文字游戏、丰富而深奥的词汇以及源于阅读和旅行的博学，嫁接到了这种不断带来惊喜的元素之上。

But even that mixture wouldn’t have sustained him if he hadn’t had a target. “All humor must be about something—it must touch concretely on life,” he said, and although readers savoring his style may lose sight of his motive, some form of pomposity lies in ruins at the end of a Perelman piece, just as grand opera never quite recovered from the Marx Brothers’ A Night at the Opera or banking from W. C. Fields’s The Bank Dick . He was seldom at a loss for charlatans and knaves, especially in the worlds of Broadway, Hollywood, advertising and merchandising.

但即便如此，如果没有一个明确的目标，他的幽默也无法支撑下去。“所有的幽默都必须有其意义——它必须具体地触及生活，”他说。尽管读者在欣赏他的文风时可能会忽略他的创作动机，但在佩雷尔曼的作品结尾，某种形式的浮夸终将化为乌有，正如宏伟的歌剧从此无法从马克斯兄弟的《歌剧之夜》中恢复过来，银行业也从W·C·菲尔兹的《银行大盗》中彻底垮台一样。他从不缺少江湖骗子和无赖，尤其是在百老汇、好莱坞、广告和商品销售界。

I still remember the teenage moment when I first got hit by one of Perelman’s sentences. His sentences were unlike any I had ever seen, and they fractured me:

我至今仍记得十几岁时第一次被佩雷尔曼的句子深深震撼的情景。他的句子与我以往见过的任何句子都截然不同，它们彻底击垮了我：

The whistle shrilled and in a moment I was chugging out of Grand Central’s dreaming spires. I had chugged only a few feet when I realized that I had left without the train, so I had to run back and wait for it to start.... With only two hours in Chicago I would be unable to see the city, and the thought drew me into a state of composure. I noted with pleasure that a fresh coat of grime had been given to the Dearborn Street station, though I was hardly vain enough to believe that it had anything to do with my visit.

汽笛尖啸一声，转眼间，我便驶出了中央车站那令人神往的尖顶。刚走了几步，我才意识到自己没赶上火车，只好跑回去等它启动……在芝加哥只有两个小时，根本没时间好好游览这座城市，想到这里，我反而平静了下来。我欣喜地发现迪尔伯恩街车站又蒙上了一层新的污垢，虽然我并不自负到认为这与我的到访有什么关系。

Women loved this impetual Irish adventurer who would rather fight than eat and vice-versa. One night he was chafing at The Bit, a tavern in Portsmouth, when he overheard a chance remark from a brawny gunner’s mate in his cups.... The following morning the “Maid of Hull,” a frigate of the line mounting 36 guns, out of Bath and into bed in a twinkling, dropped downstream on the tide, bound for Bombay, object matrimony. On her as passenger went my great-grandfather.... Fifty-three days later, living almost entirely on cameo brooches and the ptarmigan which fell to the ptrigger of his pfowling piece, he at last sighted the towers of Ishpeming, the Holy City of the Surds and Cosines, fanatical Mohammedan warrior sects.

女人们都喜欢这位性情冲动的爱尔兰冒险家，他宁愿打仗也不愿吃饭，反之亦然。一天晚上，他在朴茨茅斯一家名为“The Bit”的酒馆里闲逛，无意间听到一个喝得酩酊大醉的壮硕炮手助手的一句闲话……第二天早上，“赫尔少女号”（Maid of Hull）——一艘装备36门火炮的战列舰——从巴斯港出发，瞬间驶入港口，顺流而下，前往孟买，此行的目的是为了促成一桩婚事。我的曾祖父作为乘客搭乘了这艘船……五十三天后，他几乎完全靠浮雕胸针和被他的猎枪击落的雷鸟为生，终于看到了伊什佩明的塔楼，那是苏尔德派和科西内斯派的圣城，这两个派别都是狂热的穆斯林武士。

My classroom survey ended with Woody Allen, the most cerebral practitioner of the trade. Allen’s magazine pieces, now collected in three books, constitute a body of written humor unique for being both intellectual and hilarious, probing not only his well-known themes of death and anxiety but such overbearing academic disciplines and literary forms as philosophy, psychology, drama, Irish poetry and the explication of texts (“Hasidic Tales”). “A Look at Organized Crime,” a parody of all the articles ever written explaining the Mafia, is one of the funniest pieces I know, and “The Schmeed Memoirs”—the recollections of Hitler’s barber—is the ultimate jab at the “good German” who was just doing his job:

我的课堂调查以伍迪·艾伦告终，他是这个行业中最具智慧的从业者。艾伦的杂志文章如今已汇集成三本书，构成了一部独特的幽默作品，兼具思想性和滑稽性，探讨的主题不仅包括他为人熟知的死亡和焦虑，还包括哲学、心理学、戏剧、爱尔兰诗歌以及文本解读等晦涩难懂的学术学科和文学形式（例如《哈西德故事集》）。《有组织犯罪面面观》是对所有解释黑手党的文章的戏仿，是我读过的最搞笑的作品之一；而《施密德回忆录》（希特勒理发师的回忆录）则是对这位“尽职尽责的德国好人”的终极讽刺。

I have been asked if I was aware of the moral implications of what I was doing. As I told the tribunal at Nuremberg, I did not know that Hitler was a Nazi. The truth was that for years I thought he worked for the phone company. When I finally did find out what a monster he was, it was too late to do anything, as I had made a down payment on some furniture. Once, toward the end of the war, I did contemplate loosening the Führer’s neck-napkin and allowing some tiny hairs to get down his back, but at the last minute my nerve failed me.

有人问我是否意识到自己行为的道德后果。正如我在纽伦堡法庭上所说，我当时并不知道希特勒是纳粹分子。事实上，多年来我一直以为他在电话公司工作。当我最终发现他是个多么可怕的怪物时，一切都为时已晚，因为我已经付了家具的定金。战争末期，我曾一度想过解开元首的颈巾，让几根细小的头发顺着他的背脊滑落，但最后一刻我还是没能鼓起勇气。

The brief excerpts in this chapter can convey only a glimmer of the vast output and artistry of these giants. But I wanted my students to know that they were working within a long tradition of serious intent and considerable nerve, one that is still alive in the work of such writers as Ian Frazier, Garrison Keillor, Fran Lebowitz, Nora Ephron, Calvin Trillin and Mark Singer. Singer is the current star in a long lineage of New Yorker writers—St. Clair McKelway, Robert Lewis Taylor, Lillian Ross, Wolcott Gibbs—who used deadpan humor to assassinate such public nuisances as Walter Winchell, leaving hardly a mark where their stiletto broke the skin.

本章的简短摘录只能展现这些巨匠浩瀚作品和精湛艺术的冰山一角。但我希望我的学生们明白，他们所从事的是一项严肃而又充满胆识的悠久传统，这一传统至今仍体现在伊恩·弗雷泽、加里森·凯勒、弗兰·勒博维茨、诺拉·艾芙隆、卡尔文·特里林和马克·辛格等作家的作品中。辛格是《纽约客》作家长河中的一颗耀眼新星——其他作家包括圣克莱尔·麦克尔韦、罗伯特·路易斯·泰勒、莉莲·罗斯和沃尔科特·吉布斯——他们都以冷幽默的方式讽刺沃尔特·温切尔等公众眼中的“害群之马”，而且讽刺得滴水不漏。

Singer’s lethal potion is concocted of hundreds of outlandish facts and quotes—he is a tenacious reporter—and a style that barely suppresses his own amusement. It works particularly well on the buccaneers who continue to try the patience of the citizenry, as proved by his profile in The New Yorker of the developer Donald Trump. Noting that Trump “had aspired to and achieved the ultimate luxury, an existence unmolested by the rumbling of a soul,” Singer describes a visit to Mar-a-Lago, the Palm Beach spa converted by Trump from the 118-room Hispano-Moorish-Venetian mansion built in the 1920s by Marjorie Merriweather Post and E. F. Hutton:

辛格的致命毒药是由数百个离奇的事实和引语调制而成——他是一位锲而不舍的记者——其文风几乎难以掩饰他自身的愉悦。这种毒药对那些不断挑战民众耐心的“海盗”尤其有效，他在《纽约客》上发表的关于房地产开发商唐纳德·特朗普的报道就证明了这一点。辛格指出，特朗普“渴望并实现了极致的奢华，一种不受灵魂躁动干扰的生活”，并描述了他参观海湖庄园的经历。海湖庄园是特朗普将一座拥有118个房间的西班牙-摩尔-威尼斯风格的豪宅改建而成的棕榈滩水疗中心，这座豪宅由玛乔丽·梅里韦瑟·波斯特和E·F·赫顿于20世纪20年代建造。

Evidently, Trump’s philosophy of wellness is rooted in a belief that prolonged exposure to exceptionally attractive young spa attendants will instill in the male clientele a will to live. Accordingly, he limits his role to a pocket veto of key hiring decisions. While giving me a tour of the main exercise room, where Tony Bennett, who does a couple of gigs at Mar-a-Lago each season and had been designated an “artist-in-residence,” was taking a brisk walk on a treadmill, Trump introduced me to “our resident physician, Dr. Ginger Lee Southall”—a recent chiropractic-college graduate. As Dr. Ginger, out of earshot, manipulated the sore back of a grateful member, I asked Trump where she had done her training. “I’m not sure,” he said. “Baywatch Medical School? Does that sound right? I’ll tell you the truth. Once I saw Dr. Ginger’s photograph, I didn’t really need to look at her résumé or anyone else’s. Are you asking, ‘Did we hire her because she trained at Mount Sinai for fifteen years?’ The answer is no. And I’ll tell you why: because by the time she’s spent fifteen years at Mount Sinai, we don’t want to look at her.”

显然，特朗普的健康理念根植于这样一种信念：让男性顾客长时间接触魅力四射的年轻水疗女郎，就能激发他们强烈的求生欲望。因此，他只对关键的招聘决策拥有否决权。在带我参观主健身房时，我见到了“我们的驻场医生，金杰·李·索索尔博士”，她是一位刚从脊椎按摩学院毕业的医生。托尼·贝内特每个季度都会在海湖庄园演出几场，并被指定为“驻场艺术家”。特朗普向我介绍了“我们的驻场医生，金杰·李·索索尔博士”。索索尔博士在我听不到的地方为一位感激涕零的会员按摩酸痛的背部，我问特朗普，她是在哪里接受的培训。“我不确定，”他说。 “《海滩救护队》医学院？听起来是不是很耳熟？说实话，我看到金杰医生的照片后，根本不需要看她的简历，也不需要看其他人的。你是不是想问，‘我们聘用她是因为她在西奈山医院接受了十五年的培训吗？’答案是否定的。原因很简单：因为等她在西奈山医院待了十五年，我们根本不想再看她一眼。”

Of all the current humorists, Garrison Keillor has the surest eye for social change and the most inventive mind for making his point obliquely. Again and again he gives us the pleasure of encountering an old genre dressed up in new clothes. America’s current hostility to cigarette smokers is a trend that any alert writer might have noticed and written about with due sobriety. This approach, however, is pure Keillor:

在所有当代幽默作家中，加里森·凯勒对社会变迁的洞察力最为敏锐，表达观点的方式也最为巧妙。他一次又一次地让我们惊喜地发现，一种古老的文学体裁披上了新的外衣。美国目前对吸烟者的敌意，任何一位敏锐的作家都可能注意到，并以应有的冷静态度进行写作。然而，这种处理方式却完全是凯勒的风格：

The last cigarette smokers in America were located in a box canyon south of Donner Pass in the High Sierra by two federal tobacco agents in a helicopter who spotted the little smoke puffs just before noon. One of them, the district chief, called in the ground team by air-to-ground radio. Six men in camouflage outfits, members of a crack anti-smoking joggers unit, moved quickly across the rugged terrain, surrounded the bunch in their hideout, subdued them with tear gas, and made them lie face down on the gravel in the hot August sun. There were three females and two males, all in their mid-forties. They had been on the run since the adoption of the Twenty-eighth Amendment.

美国最后一批吸烟者被两名联邦烟草特工在内华达山脉唐纳山口以南的一个峡谷中抓获。当时正值中午前，他们乘坐直升机发现了这群人身上冒出的缕缕青烟。其中一名特工是地区主管，他立即通过空对地无线电呼叫了地面小组。六名身穿迷彩服的精锐反吸烟慢跑队员迅速穿越崎岖的地形，包围了这群人的藏身之处，用催泪瓦斯制服了他们，并让他们面朝下趴在八月烈日下的碎石地上。这群人有三名女性和两名男性，年龄都在四十多岁。自第二十八修正案通过以来，他们就一直在逃亡。

The genre that’s in Keillor’s head has been a staple of American newspapers since the Dillinger era of the 1930s, and his enjoyment of that form, with its echoes of gangsters and G-men, of stakeouts and shootouts, is obvious in his writing.

基勒脑海中的这种体裁自 20 世纪 30 年代迪林格时代以来一直是美国报纸的主要体裁，他对这种体裁的喜爱，以及其中流露出的黑帮、联邦探员、监视和枪战的痕迹，在他的作品中显而易见。

Another situation that Keillor obviously enjoyed having found a perfect framework for was the first Bush administration’s bailout of the savings-and-loan industry. This is how his piece “How the Savings and Loans Were Saved” begins:

凯勒显然很乐于找到一个完美的切入点来分析另一个案例，那就是老布什政府对储贷行业的救助。他的文章《储贷行业是如何得救的》就是这样开头的：

The President was playing badminton in Aspen the day vast hordes of barbaric Huns invaded Chicago, and a reporter whose aunt lives in Evanston shouted to him as he headed for the clubhouse, “The Huns are wreaking carnage in Chicago, Mr. President! Any comment?”

就在大批野蛮的匈奴人入侵芝加哥的那天，总统正在阿斯彭打羽毛球。一位姑妈住在埃文斯顿的记者在他走向俱乐部时向他喊道：“总统先生，匈奴人在芝加哥大开杀戒！您有什么评论吗？”

Mr. Bush, though caught off guard by news of the invasion, said, “We’re following that whole Hun situation very closely, and right now it looks encouraging, but I’m hoping we can get back to you in a few hours with something more definite.” The President appeared concerned but relaxed and definitely chin-up and in charge.

尽管布什先生对入侵的消息感到措手不及，但他表示：“我们正在密切关注匈奴局势，目前看来情况令人鼓舞，但我希望几个小时后能给您带来更确切的消息。”总统看起来既担忧又放松，显然精神抖擞，一切尽在掌握。

The piece goes on to describe how rapacious barbarians swarmed into the city, “burned churches and performing-arts centers and historic restorations, and dragged away monks, virgins and associate professors … to be sold into slavery” and seized the savings-and-loan offices, provoking no action by President Bush, however, because “exit polling at shopping malls showed that people thought he was handling it O.K.”

文章继续描述了贪婪的野蛮人如何涌入这座城市，“烧毁教堂、表演艺术中心和历史修复工程，并拖走僧侣、处女和副教授……将他们卖为奴隶”，还占领了储蓄贷款机构，然而，布什总统却没有采取任何行动，因为“购物中心的出口民调显示，人们认为他处理得还不错”。

The President decided not to interfere with the takeover attempts in the savings-and-loan industry and to pay the hundred and sixty-six billion dollars, not as a ransom of any type but as ordinary government support, plain and simple, nothing irregular about it, and the Huns and the Vandals rode away, carrying their treasure with them, and the Goths sailed away up Lake Michigan.

总统决定不干预对储贷行业的接管企图，并支付一千六百六十亿美元，这笔钱不是任何形式的赎金，而是普通的政府支持，简单明了，没有任何不合规之处。匈奴人和汪达尔人带着他们的财宝扬长而去，哥特人则乘船驶入密歇根湖。

Keillor’s satire left me full of admiration—first for an act of humor so original, but also for expressing the citizen outrage I hadn’t found a way to express. All I had been able to muster was helpless anger that my grandchildren in their old age would still be paying for Bush’s rescue of the industry that the greedy hordes had plundered.

凯勒的讽刺作品让我无比钦佩——首先是因为它如此独具匠心的幽默，其次是因为它表达了我一直无法言说的民众愤慨。我所能感受到的，只是无力的愤怒：我的孙辈们年老时，还要为布什拯救这个被贪婪之徒掠夺一空的行业买单。

But there’s no law that says humor has to make a point. Pure nonsense is a joy forever, as Keats didn’t quite say. I love to see a writer flying high, just for the hell of it. The following two excerpts, from recent pieces by Ian Frazier and John Updike, are 100 percent off-the-wall; nothing written during America’s earlier golden ages was any funnier. Frazier’s piece is called “Dating Your Mom,” and it begins like this:

但并没有哪条法律规定幽默必须有意义。纯粹的无厘头永远令人愉悦，正如济慈没有明说的那样。我喜欢看到作家们尽情发挥，纯粹为了好玩。以下两段摘自伊恩·弗雷泽和约翰·厄普代克的近期作品，绝对天马行空；美国早期黄金时代的作品也比不上它们有趣。弗雷泽的作品名为《和你妈约会》，开头是这样的：

In today’s fast-moving, transient, rootless society, where people meet and make love and part without ever really touching, the relationship every guy already has with his own mother is too valuable to ignore. Here is a grown, experienced, loving woman—one you do not have to go to a party or a singles bar to meet, one you do not have to go to great lengths to get to know. There are hundreds of times when you and your mother are thrown together naturally, without the tension that usually accompanies courtship—just the two of you, alone. All you need is a little presence of mind to take advantage of these situations. Say your mom is driving you downtown in the car to buy you a new pair of slacks. First, find a nice station on the car radio, one that she likes. Get into the pleasant lull of freeway driving—tires humming along the pavement, air conditioner on max. Then turn to look at her across the front seat and say something like, “You know, you’ve really kept your shape, Mom, and don’t think I haven’t noticed.” Or suppose she comes into your room to bring you some clean socks. Take her by the wrist, pull her close, and say, “Mom, you’re the most fascinating woman I’ve ever met.” Probably she’ll tell you to cut out the foolishness, but I can guarantee you one thing: she will never tell your dad. Possibly she would find it hard to say, “Dear, Piper just made a pass at me,” or possibly she is secretly flattered, but whatever the reason, she will keep it to herself until the day comes when she is no longer ashamed to tell the world of your love.

在如今这个快节奏、流动性强、居无定所的社会里，人们相遇、相爱、离别，却从未真正触碰过彼此，因此，每个男人与自己母亲之间与生俱来的关系弥足珍贵，不容忽视。母亲是一位成熟、阅历丰富、充满爱心的女性——你无需去参加派对或去酒吧才能结识她，也无需费尽心思去了解她。你和母亲之间自然而然地相处了无数次，没有恋爱中常见的紧张感——只有你们两个人，独处。你只需要稍加留意，就能把握住这些机会。比如说，你妈妈开车带你去市中心给你买条新裤子。首先，在车载收音机里找一个她喜欢的频道。享受高速公路行驶的惬意——轮胎在路面上发出嗡嗡声，空调开到最大。然后转过身，看着坐在前排的她，说些类似这样的话：“妈，你知道吗，你身材保持得真好，别以为我没注意到。”或者假设她走进你的房间给你拿干净的袜子。抓住她的手腕，把她拉近，说：“妈，你是我见过的最迷人的女人。”她可能会让你别胡闹，但我可以保证一件事：她绝对不会告诉你爸爸。或许她不好意思说：“亲爱的，Piper刚才勾引我了。”或许她心里暗暗高兴，但不管怎样，她都会把这件事藏在心里，直到有一天她不再羞于向全世界宣告你的爱。

Updike’s piece, “Glad Rags,” though no less an act of bungee-jumping, bringing him within inches of the rocks at the bottom of the gorge, has a disturbing core of reality. Not only does it flirt with some of the nation’s darker suppositions about J. Edgar Hoover; it deals with high-ranking Americans of recent memory—a sainted President and his cabinet. What makes it work, for all its seeming frivolity, is Updike’s meticulous research. You can bet that all the details—names, dates and fashion terminology—are correct:

厄普代克的短篇小说《华丽的衣裳》虽然情节惊险刺激，几乎触及峡谷底部的岩石，但其核心却蕴含着令人不安的现实意义。它不仅触及了美国民众对埃德加·胡佛的一些阴暗猜想，还涉及了近代美国政要——一位备受尊崇的总统及其内阁成员。尽管小说看似轻松诙谐，但其成功之处在于厄普代克严谨细致的考证。可以肯定的是，所有细节——人名、日期和时尚术语——都准确无误。

To those of us who were alive and sartorially active at the time, it was saddening to read in the Boston Globe recently the allegation, by “New York socialite” Susan Rosenstiel, that in 1958 J. Edgar Hoover was parading around in a Plaza Hotel suite wearing women’s clothes: “He was wearing a fluffy black dress, very fluffy, with flounces, and lace stockings and high heels, and a black curly wig.” I was saddened to think that future generations, trying to grasp the peculiar splendor and excitement of high-echelon cross-dressing during Eisenhower’s second term, will imagine that dowdy bit of black fluff, with its fussy flounces and matching wig, to have been très à la mode , when the truth is we all considered J. Edgar something of a frump.

对于我们这些当时还活着并且对时尚颇有研究的人来说，最近在《波士顿环球报》上读到“纽约社交名媛”苏珊·罗森斯蒂尔的爆料，令人感到悲哀。罗森斯蒂尔声称，1958年，J·埃德加·胡佛在广场酒店的套房里穿着女装招摇过市：“他穿着一件蓬松的黑色连衣裙，非常蓬松，带有荷叶边，搭配蕾丝长袜和高跟鞋，还戴着一顶黑色卷发假发。”想到后世的人们在试图理解艾森豪威尔第二任期内上流社会异装癖的独特魅力时，可能会把那件老土的黑色蓬松连衣裙，配上繁复的荷叶边和配套的假发，想象成当时的“非常时髦”，而事实上，我们都认为J·埃德加是个老土的人。

Ike, for instance, dear Ike with his infallible instincts, would never have let himself be caught in lace stockings, even though he did have the legs for them. I remember, within a month of Saint Laurent’s 1958 collection for Dior, Ike coming out in a stunning cobalt-blue wool trapeze, with white open-backed heels and a false chignon. That very day, if memory serves, he had sent five thousand marines to Lebanon, and not a hair out of place. It was with this outfit—or was it a belted A-line from the previous year?—that he sported a flowered silk neck cloth, when scarves were still thought to be strictly for babushkas. He was very conservative as to hemlines, however; when Saint Laurent lifted skirts to the knee in 1959, the President waited three months for Congress to decide the issue, and then, losing all patience, switched to Balenciaga with a stroke of his pen. Thenceforth, to the very end of his administration, he stuck with long-waisted day dresses in neutral duns and beiges.

例如，亲爱的艾克，他那精准的直觉，即使拥有一双适合蕾丝长袜的美腿，也绝不会让自己陷入蕾丝长袜的陷阱。我记得，在圣罗兰为迪奥发布1958年系列后不到一个月，艾克就穿着一件惊艳的钴蓝色羊毛梯形连衣裙亮相，搭配白色露跟高跟鞋和假发髻。如果我没记错的话，就在同一天，他派遣了五千名海军陆战队员前往黎巴嫩，而且仪容整洁，一丝不苟。他穿着这身行头——或者说是前一年的束腰A字裙？——搭配了一条印花丝绸领巾，要知道在当时，围巾还被认为是老奶奶的专属。然而，他在裙摆长度方面却非常保守；1959年，当圣罗兰将裙子的长度提升到膝盖时，总统等了三个月国会对此问题做出决定，然后，在失去耐心后，他一纸命令就转而支持巴伦西亚加。从那时起，直到他执政的最后阶段，他都一直穿着中性色调的灰褐色和米色长腰连衣裙。

John Foster Dulles, on the other hand, favored a slinky-pajama look and pastel pants suits with a touch of glimmer in the fabric. Oodles of bangles, upswept blond wigs, and pom-pommed mules. Despite his staunch anti-Communism, he was oddly partial to red, though I believe on good authority that Sherman Adams at least once took Foster aside and made the point that bright colors did not become a big-boned frame. Sherman, though he was undone by vicuña, lingers in my mind’s eye as a creature of whimsical ostrich-feather boas and enchantments in lightly starched lemon voile....

约翰·福斯特·杜勒斯则截然不同，他偏爱紧身睡衣风和带有闪光面料的粉彩色裤装。他总是佩戴大量的镯子，戴着高高盘起的金色假发，穿着带绒球的拖鞋。尽管他坚定地反对共产主义，但他却对红色情有独钟。不过，我相信有可靠消息来源称，谢尔曼·亚当斯至少有一次把福斯特拉到一边，指出鲜艳的颜色并不会让他显得骨架大。谢尔曼虽然最终败给了羊驼，但他在我脑海中的形象却依然是：一个戴着异想天开的鸵鸟毛围巾，穿着略微浆过的柠檬色薄纱裙的迷人人物……

Enjoyment, finally, is what all humorists must convey—the idea that they are having a terrific time, and this notion of cranked-up audacity is what I wanted my Yale students to grapple with. At first I told them to write in one of the existing humor forms—satire, parody, lampoon, etc.—and not to use “I” or to write from their own experience. I assigned the same topic to the whole class, bringing in some absurdity I had noticed in the newspaper. The students jumped boldly into free association, surrealism and nonsense. They found that it was possible to slip off the chains of logic and to have fun making a serious point within a given humor form. They were heavily under the influence of Woody Allen’s non sequiturs (“For this the Rabbi bashes his head in, which, according to the Torah, is one of the most subtle methods of showing concern”).

归根结底，所有幽默作家都必须传达的是愉悦感——他们乐在其中，而这种大胆无畏的精神正是我希望耶鲁大学的学生们去思考的。起初，我让他们用现有的幽默形式——讽刺、戏仿、讽刺画等等——来写作，并且不要使用“我”或从自身经历出发。我给全班布置了同一个主题，并融入了一些我在报纸上看到的荒诞内容。学生们大胆地投入到自由联想、超现实主义和无厘头的创作中。他们发现，即使摆脱了逻辑的束缚，也能在既定的幽默形式中，以轻松有趣的方式表达严肃的观点。他们深受伍迪·艾伦式的无厘头幽默的影响（“为此，拉比捶胸顿足，而根据《托拉》，这是表达关切最微妙的方式之一”）。

After about four weeks, fatigue set in. The students learned that they were capable of writing humor. But they also learned how tiring it is to sustain a weekly act of comic invention, writing in other voices. It was time to slow down their metabolism—to start them writing in their own voice, about their own lives. I declared a moratorium on Woody Allen and said I would tell them when they could read him again. That day never came.

大约四周后，疲惫感袭来。学生们发现自己有能力写幽默作品，但也体会到每周都要进行这种喜剧创作，还要用不同的口吻写作，是多么令人疲惫。是时候让他们放慢节奏，开始用自己的声音，写自己的生活了。我宣布暂停阅读伍迪·艾伦的作品，并告诉他们什么时候可以再读。但那一天始终没有到来。

I adopted the Chic Young principle—stick to what you know—and began to read from writers who use humor as a vein that runs quietly through their work. One piece was E. B. White’s “The Eye of Edna,” in which White recalls waiting on his Maine farm for the arrival of Hurricane Edna while listening for several days to inane radio reports of its progress. It’s a perfect essay, full of wisdom and gentle wit.

我采纳了奇克·杨的原则——坚持做自己擅长的事——开始阅读那些将幽默巧妙地融入作品的作家的作品。其中一篇是E·B·怀特的《埃德娜之眼》，怀特在文中回忆了自己在缅因州农场等待埃德娜飓风到来的情景，连续几天收听着广播里关于飓风行进路线的无聊报道。这是一篇完美的散文，充满了智慧和温和的幽默。

Another writer whose work I excavated was Stephen Leacock, a Canadian. I recalled him from my boyhood as hilarious but was afraid that, as often happens in looking up old friends, he would turn out to be merely “comical.” His pieces, however, had survived the erosion of time, and one that I particularly remembered—“My Financial Career,” in which he tries to open a bank account with $56—still seems the model piece of humor on how rattled we all become when dealing with banks, libraries and other uptight institutions. Rereading Leacock reminded me that another function of the humorist is to represent himself or herself as the victim or dunce, helpless in most situations. It’s therapy for readers, enabling them to feel superior to the writer, or at least to identify with a fellow victim. A humorist who deals with ordinary life never runs out of material, as Erma Bombeck enjoyably proved over many decades.

我挖掘的另一位作家是加拿大作家斯蒂芬·利科克。我小时候就记得他的作品，觉得非常幽默，但又担心，就像重温老朋友时常遇到的情况一样，他可能只是“滑稽”而已。然而，他的作品经受住了时间的考验，其中一篇我印象尤为深刻——《我的理财生涯》，讲述他试图用56美元开银行账户的故事——至今仍是我读过的幽默典范，它生动地描绘了我们在与银行、图书馆和其他繁琐的机构打交道时那种慌乱无措的心情。重读利科克的作品让我意识到，幽默作家的另一个功能是把自己塑造成受害者或笨蛋，在大多数情况下都无能为力。这对读者来说是一种疗愈，让他们感觉自己比作家优越，或者至少能与另一位受害者产生共鸣。正如厄玛·邦贝克在几十年间用她的作品所证明的那样，描写日常生活的幽默作家永远不会缺乏素材。

So that was the direction in which our Yale humor class began to move. Many of the students wrote about their families. We ran into problems, mainly of exaggeration, and gradually solved them, trying to achieve control, cutting the extra sentence that explains a funny point that is already implicit. A hard decision was to know how much exaggeration was allowable and how much was too much. One student wrote a funny piece about what a terrible cook his grandmother was. When I praised it he said she was really a very good cook. I said I was sorry to hear it—somehow the piece now seemed less funny. He asked if that made a difference. I said it didn’t make a difference in this piece, since I had enjoyed it without knowing it was untrue, but that I thought he would last longer if he started from the truth rather than from invention—surely one secret of James Thurber’s longevity as a major American humorist. In Thurber’s “The Night the Bed Fell” we know that he has slightly enlarged the facts. But we also know that something happened to the bed that night in the attic.

于是，我们的耶鲁幽默课就朝着这个方向发展了。许多学生都写了关于他们家庭的文章。我们遇到了一些问题，主要是夸张，我们逐渐解决了这些问题，努力控制用词，删掉那些解释原本就隐含的笑点的赘述。一个艰难的决定是，如何把握夸张的尺度，既要适可而止，又要避免过度。有个学生写了一篇关于他奶奶厨艺糟糕的幽默文章。我称赞他的文章时，他却说奶奶其实厨艺很好。我说我很遗憾听到这个消息——不知怎的，这篇文章现在听起来没那么好笑了。他问我这有什么影响。我说在这篇文章里没什么影响，因为我之前并不知道它是虚构的，但我觉得如果他能从真实经历出发，而不是凭空捏造，他的作品会更经得起时间的考验——这无疑是詹姆斯·瑟伯作为美国著名幽默作家长盛不衰的秘诀之一。在瑟伯的《床倒了的那晚》中，我们知道他稍微夸大了事实。但我们也知道，那天晚上阁楼里的床确实发生了一些事。

In short, our class began by striving first for humor and hoping to wing a few truths along the way. We ended by striving for truth and hoping to add humor along the way. Ultimately we realized that the two are intertwined.

简而言之，我们这门课一开始追求的是幽默，希望能顺便提炼出一些真理。最后，我们追求的是真理，希望能在过程中融入一些幽默。最终我们意识到，这两者是密不可分的。

#↩

PART IV

第四部分

#↩

Attitudes

态度

#↩

20

The Sound of Your Voice

你的声音

I wrote one book about baseball and one about jazz. But it never occurred to me to write one of them in sports English and the other in jazz English. I tried to write them both in the best English I could, in my usual style. Though the books were widely different in subject, I wanted readers to know that they were hearing from the same person. It was my book about baseball and my book about jazz. Other writers would write their book. My commodity as a writer, whatever I’m writing about, is me. And your commodity is you. Don’t alter your voice to fit your subject. Develop one voice that readers will recognize when they hear it on the page, a voice that’s enjoyable not only in its musical line but in its avoidance of sounds that would cheapen its tone: breeziness and condescension and clichés.

我写了一本关于棒球的书，一本关于爵士乐的书。但我从未想过要一本用体育英语写，另一本用爵士乐英语写。我尽力用我一贯的风格，用我所能达到的最佳英语水平来写作。尽管两本书的主题截然不同，但我希望读者知道他们读到的是同一个人写的。这是我写的棒球书，也是我的爵士乐书。其他作家会写他们的书。作为一名作家，无论我写什么，我的核心价值就是我自己。你的核心价值也是你自己。不要为了迎合主题而改变你的声音。要发展出一种读者一读就能认出的声音，这种声音不仅悦耳动听，而且避免了那些会降低其格调的音节：轻浮、居高临下和陈词滥调。

Let’s start with breeziness.

让我们先从轻松惬意开始。

There is a kind of writing that sounds so relaxed that you think you hear the author talking to you. E. B. White was probably its best practitioner, though many other masters of the style—James Thurber, V. S. Pritchett, Lewis Thomas—come to mind. I’m partial to it because it’s a style I’ve always tried to write. The common assumption is that the style is effortless. In fact the opposite is true: the effortless style is achieved by strenuous effort and constant refining. The nails of grammar and syntax are in place and the English is as good as the writer can make it.

有一种写作风格，读起来轻松自在，仿佛作者就在你耳边轻声细语。E·B·怀特或许是这种风格的最佳诠释者，当然，詹姆斯·瑟伯、V·S·普里切特、路易斯·托马斯等其他大师也同样擅长。我偏爱这种风格，因为我一直努力尝试用这种风格写作。人们通常认为这种风格毫不费力。但事实恰恰相反：这种看似毫不费力的风格，实则是通过艰苦卓绝的努力和不断的精雕细琢才得以实现的。语法和句法严谨到位，英语表达也达到了作者的巅峰水平。

Here’s how a typical piece by E. B. White begins:

以下是E·B·怀特的一篇典型文章的开头：

I spent several days and nights in mid-September with an ailing pig and I feel driven to account for this stretch of time, more particularly since the pig died at last, and I lived, and things might easily have gone the other way round and none left to do the accounting.

九月中旬，我花了几天几夜的时间照顾一头生病的猪，我觉得有必要对这段时间做出解释，尤其是因为这头猪最终死了，而我活了下来，事情很容易就会反过来，那样就没有人来解释这一切了。

The sentence is so folksy that we imagine ourselves sitting on the porch of White’s house in Maine. White is in a rocking chair, puffing on a pipe, and the words just tumble out in his storyteller’s voice. But look at the sentence again. Nothing about it is accidental. It’s a disciplined act of writing. The grammar is formal, the words are plain and precise, and the cadences are those of a poet. That’s the effortless style at its best: a methodical act of composition that disarms us with its generated warmth. The writer sounds confident; he’s not trying to ingratiate himself with the reader.

这句话如此亲切，仿佛让我们置身于缅因州怀特家门廊，坐在摇椅上，嘴里叼着烟斗，他娓娓道来，娓娓道来。但请再仔细看看这句话。它的每一个细节都并非偶然，而是精心雕琢的产物。语法严谨，用词简洁明了，节奏韵律优美如诗。这正是浑然天成的风格：一种条理清晰的创作，却以其流露出的温暖打动了我们。作者的语气自信满满，丝毫没有刻意讨好读者的意思。

Inexperienced writers miss this point. They think that all they have to do to achieve a casual effect is to be “just folks”—good old Betty or Bob chatting over the back fence. They want to be a pal to the reader. They’re so eager not to appear formal that they don’t even try to write good English. What they write is the breezy style.

经验不足的写作者往往忽略了这一点。他们认为，只要像“普通人”一样——就像和蔼可亲的贝蒂或鲍勃在后院篱笆边闲聊——就能营造出轻松随意的氛围。他们想成为读者的朋友，却又急于摆脱正式感，甚至懒得打理英语。他们写的只是轻松随意的风格。

How would a breezy writer handle E. B. White’s vigil with the pig? He might sound like this:

一位文风轻松的作家会如何描述E·B·怀特与猪的守夜故事呢？他可能会这样写：

Ever stay up late babysitting for a sick porker? Believe you me, a guy can lose a heckuva lot of shut-eye. I did that gig for three nights back in September and my better half thought I’d lost my marbles. (Just kidding, Pam!) Frankly, the whole deal kind of bummed me out. Because, you see, the pig up and died on me. To tell you the truth, I wasn’t feeling in the pink myself, so I suppose it could have been yours truly and not old Porky who kicked the bucket. And you can bet your bottom dollar Mr. Pig wasn’t going to write a book about it!

你有没有熬夜照顾过一头生病的猪？相信我，那可真是要熬出好多觉。九月份的时候我连续三个晚上都这么做，我老婆都觉得我疯了。（开玩笑啦，帕姆！）说实话，这事儿让我挺郁闷的。因为，你知道，那头猪突然就死了。老实说，我当时自己也不太舒服，所以说不定死的不是老猪，而是我呢。而且你肯定猜不到，猪先生肯定不会把这事儿写成书！

There’s no need to labor all the reasons why this stuff is so terrible. It’s crude. It’s corny. It’s verbose. It’s contemptuous of the English language. It’s condescending. (I stop reading writers who say “You see.”) But the most pathetic thing about the breezy style is that it’s harder to read than good English. In the writer’s attempt to ease the reader’s journey he has littered the path with obstacles: cheap slang, shoddy sentences, windy philosophizing. E. B. White’s style is much easier to read. He knows that the tools of grammar haven’t survived for so many centuries by chance; they are props the reader needs and subconsciously wants. Nobody ever stopped reading E. B. White or V. S. Pritchett because the writing was too good. But readers will stop reading you if they think you are talking down to them. Nobody wants to be patronized.

无需赘述这种文风为何如此糟糕。它粗俗、老套、冗长，是对英语语言的蔑视，而且居高临下。（我一旦读到作者用“你看”这样的词，就会直接放弃。）但这种轻松随意的文风最可悲的地方在于，它比优美的英语更难读。作者为了让读者更容易理解，反而设置了重重障碍：廉价的俚语、蹩脚的句子、空洞的哲学说教。E·B·怀特的文风则要好读得多。他深知语法工具能够流传数百年绝非偶然；它们是读者需要且潜意识里渴望的辅助工具。没有人会因为E·B·怀特或V·S·普里切特的文笔太好了而放弃阅读。但如果读者觉得你在居高临下地跟他们说话，他们就会停止阅读。没有人喜欢被轻视。

Write with respect for the English language at its best—and for readers at their best. If you’re smitten by the urge to try the breezy style, read what you’ve written aloud and see if you like the sound of your voice.

写作时要尊重英语语言的最高境界，也要尊重读者的最高境界。如果你实在忍不住想尝试轻松流畅的文风，不妨大声朗读自己写的内容，看看是否喜欢这种风格。

Finding a voice that your readers will enjoy is largely a matter of taste. Saying that isn’t much help—taste is a quality so intangible that it can’t even be defined. But we know it when we meet it. A woman with taste in clothes delights us with her ability to turn herself out in a combination that’s not only stylish and surprising, but exactly right. She knows what works and what doesn’t.

找到读者喜欢的写作风格，很大程度上取决于个人品味。这么说其实意义不大——品味是一种如此难以捉摸的特质，甚至无法定义。但我们一旦遇到，便能立刻感受到。一位品味出众的女士，总能以时尚、别致且恰到好处的搭配让我们眼前一亮。她深谙穿搭之道，知道什么合适，什么不合适。

For writers and other creative artists, knowing what not to do is a major component of taste. Two jazz pianists may be equally proficient. The one with taste will put every note to useful work in telling his or her story; the one without taste will drench us in ripples and other unnecessary ornaments. Painters with taste will trust their eye to tell them what needs to be on the canvas and what doesn’t; a painter without taste will give us a landscape that’s too pretty, or too cluttered, or too gaudy—anyway, too something. A graphic designer with taste knows that less is more: that design is the servant of the written word. A designer without taste will smother the writing in background tints and swirls and decorative frills.

对于作家和其他创意艺术家而言，懂得什么不该做是品味的重要组成部分。两位爵士钢琴家的技艺或许不相上下。有品味的那位会巧妙地运用每一个音符来讲述自己的故事；而缺乏品味的那位则会用繁复的音符和其他不必要的装饰来掩盖作品的本质。有品味的画家会相信自己的眼睛，知道画布上应该呈现什么，不应该呈现什么；而缺乏品味的画家则会画出过于漂亮、过于杂乱或过于艳俗的风景——总之，总是“过犹不及”。有品味的平面设计师深谙“少即是多”的道理：设计是文字的仆人。而缺乏品味的平面设计师则会用繁复的背景色调、漩涡和装饰性花边来掩盖文字本身。

I realize I’m trying to pin down a matter that’s subjective; one person’s beautiful object is somebody else’s kitsch. Taste can also change from one decade to another—yesterday’s charm is derided today as junk, but it will be back in vogue tomorrow, certified again as charming. So why do I even raise the issue? Just to remind you that it exists. Taste is an invisible current that runs through writing, and you should be aware of it.

我意识到我试图探讨的是一个主观问题；一个人眼中的美物，在另一个人眼中可能只是庸俗之物。品味也会随着时代变迁——昨天的魅力如今可能被人嗤之以鼻，但明天它又会重新流行，再次被奉为经典。那么，我为什么要提出这个问题呢？只是想提醒你它的存在。品味就像一股无形的暗流，贯穿于写作之中，你应该意识到它的存在。

Sometimes, in fact, it’s visible. Every art form has a core of verities that survive the fickleness of time. There must be something innately pleasing in the proportions of the Parthenon; Western man continues to let the Greeks of two thousand years ago design his public buildings, as anyone walking around Washington, D.C., soon discovers. The fugues of Bach have a timeless elegance that’s rooted in the timeless laws of mathematics.

事实上，有时这种永恒性是显而易见的。每一种艺术形式都蕴含着经受住时间变迁考验的真理核心。帕特农神庙的比例必然具有某种内在的美感；西方人至今仍在沿用两千年前希腊人的设计理念来建造公共建筑，任何在华盛顿特区漫步的人都会很快发现这一点。巴赫的赋格曲拥有永恒的优雅，而这种优雅根植于永恒的数学法则。

Does writing have any such guideposts for us? Not many; writing is the expression of every person’s individuality, and we know what we like when it comes along. Again, however, much can be gained by knowing what to omit. Clichés, for instance. If a writer lives in blissful ignorance that clichés are the kiss of death, if in the final analysis he leaves no stone unturned to use them, we can infer that he lacks an instinct for what gives language its freshness. Faced with a choice between the novel and the banal, he goes unerringly for the banal. His voice is the voice of a hack.

写作有这样的指导原则吗？不多；写作是每个人个性的表达，我们自然而然地知道自己喜欢什么。然而，懂得取舍却能带来诸多益处。例如，陈词滥调。如果一个作家对陈词滥调是写作的致命伤浑然不觉，最终却不遗余力地使用它们，那么我们可以推断，他缺乏对语言新鲜感的敏锐感知。面对新颖与平庸的选择，他毫不犹豫地选择了平庸。他的声音也沦为拙劣的模仿。

Not that clichés are easy to stamp out. They are everywhere in the air around us, familiar friends just waiting to be helpful, ready to express complex ideas for us in the shorthand form of metaphor. That’s how they became clichés in the first place, and even careful writers use quite a few on their first draft. But after that we are given a chance to clean them out. Clichés are one of the things you should keep listening for when you rewrite and read your successive drafts aloud. Notice how incriminating they sound, convicting you of being satisfied to use the same old chestnuts instead of making an effort to replace them with fresh phrases of your own. Clichés are the enemy of taste.

并非说陈词滥调很容易根除。它们无处不在，就像熟悉的老朋友一样，随时准备为我们提供帮助，用简洁的比喻形式表达复杂的思想。它们最初就是这样变成陈词滥调的，即使是谨慎的作家，在初稿中也难免会用到不少。但之后，我们就有机会清除它们。在反复修改和朗读的过程中，你应该时刻留意陈词滥调。注意它们听起来有多么令人不安，仿佛在责备你满足于使用那些老掉牙的词句，而不是努力用自己新鲜的语言来替换它们。陈词滥调是品味的敌人。

Extend the point beyond individual clichés to your larger use of language. Again, freshness is crucial. Taste chooses words that have surprise, strength and precision. Non-taste slips into the breezy vernacular of the alumni magazine’s class notes—a world where people in authority are the top brass or the powers that be. What exactly is wrong with “the top brass”? Nothing—and everything. Taste knows that it’s better to call people in authority what they are: officials, executives, chairmen, presidents, directors, managers. Non-taste reaches for the corny synonym, which has the further disadvantage of being imprecise; exactly which company officers are the top brass? Non-taste uses “umpteenth.” And “zillions.” Non-taste uses “period”: “She said she didn’t want to hear any more about it. Period.”

将重点从个别陈词滥调扩展到你更广泛的语言运用。再次强调，新鲜感至关重要。品味高雅的人会选择那些充满惊喜、铿锵有力且精准的词语。而缺乏品味的人则会使用校友杂志班级通讯里那种轻松随意的俚语——在这个世界里，掌权者被称为“高层领导”或“当权者”。“高层领导”到底有什么问题？没有，但又错得离谱。品味高雅的人知道，称呼掌权者时最好使用他们应有的称谓：官员、高管、董事长、总裁、董事、经理。缺乏品味的人则会使用老套的同义词，而这些同义词还有一个缺点，那就是不够精准；究竟哪些公司高管才是真正的高层领导？缺乏品味的人会使用“第N个”。还会使用“数不清”。缺乏品味的人甚至会使用“句号”：“她说她不想再听任何关于这件事的事情了。句号。”

But finally taste is a mixture of qualities that are beyond analyzing: an ear that can hear the difference between a sentence that limps and a sentence that lilts, an intuition that knows when a casual or a vernacular phrase dropped into a formal sentence will not only sound right but will seem to be the inevitable choice. (E. B. White was a master of that balancing act.) Does this mean that taste can be learned? Yes and no. Perfect taste, like perfect pitch, is a gift from God. But a certain amount can be acquired. The trick is to study writers who have it.

但归根结底，品味是一种无法分析的特质的混合体：它需要一双能听出句子生硬与流畅区别的耳朵，以及一种直觉，能够判断在正式的句子中插入一句随意或口语化的短语，不仅听起来自然，而且似乎是必然之选。（E·B·怀特正是这种平衡的高手。）这是否意味着品味可以习得？答案是既是又不是。完美的品味，如同绝对音感，是上帝的恩赐。但一定程度的品味是可以培养的。诀窍在于研究那些拥有这种品味的作家。

Never hesitate to imitate another writer. Imitation is part of the creative process for anyone learning an art or a craft. Bach and Picasso didn’t spring full-blown as Bach and Picasso; they needed models. This is especially true of writing. Find the best writers in the fields that interest you and read their work aloud. Get their voice and their taste into your ear—their attitude toward language. Don’t worry that by imitating them you’ll lose your own voice and your own identity. Soon enough you will shed those skins and become who you are supposed to become.

永远不要犹豫去模仿其他作家。模仿是任何学习艺术或技艺的人创作过程的一部分。巴赫和毕加索并非一蹴而就，他们也需要榜样。写作尤其如此。找到你感兴趣领域中最优秀的作家，大声朗读他们的作品。将他们的声音和风格——他们对语言的态度——铭记于心。不要担心模仿会让你失去自己的声音和个性。很快，你就会蜕去旧皮囊，成为你注定要成为的人。

By reading other writers you also plug yourself into a longer tradition that enriches you. Sometimes you will tap a vein of eloquence or racial memory that gives your writing a depth it could never attain on its own. Let me illustrate what I mean by a roundabout route.

通过阅读其他作家的作品，你也能融入更悠久的传统，从而丰富自身。有时，你会从中挖掘出雄辩的文采或种族记忆，赋予你的写作以自身无法企及的深度。让我举例说明一下我所说的迂回之路。

Ordinarily I don’t read the proclamations issued by state officials to designate important days of the year as important days of the year. But in 1976, when I was teaching at Yale, the governor of Connecticut, Ella Grasso, had the pleasant idea of reissuing the Thanksgiving Proclamation written 40 years earlier by Governor Wilbur Cross, which she called “a masterpiece of eloquence.” I often wonder whether eloquence has vanished from American life, or whether we even still consider it a goal worth striving for. So I studied Governor Cross’s words to see how they had weathered the passage of time, that cruel judge of the rhetoric of earlier generations. I was delighted to find that I agreed with Governor Grasso. It was a piece written by a master:

通常情况下，我不会去阅读州政府官员发布的、用来宣布一年中重要日子的公告。但在1976年，当我还在耶鲁大学任教时，康涅狄格州州长埃拉·格拉索（Ella Grasso）突发奇想，重新发布了40年前由威尔伯·克罗斯（Wilbur Cross）州长撰写的感恩节公告，她称之为“雄辩的杰作”。我常常思考，雄辩是否已经从美国人的生活中消失，或者我们是否仍然认为它值得追求。于是，我仔细研读了克罗斯州长的文字，看看它们是如何经受住时间的考验——时间对前人的修辞格外残酷。我欣喜地发现，我同意格拉索州长的看法。这的确是一位大师之作：

Time out of mind at this turn of the seasons when the hardy oak leaves rustle in the wind and the frost gives a tang to the air and the dusk falls early and the friendly evenings lengthen under the heel of Orion, it has seemed good to our people to join together in praising the Creator and Preserver, who has brought us by a way that we did not know to the end of another year. In observance of this custom, I appoint Thursday, the 26th of November, as a day of Public Thanksgiving for the blessings that have been our common lot and have placed our beloved state with the favored regions of earth—for all the creature comforts: the yield of the soil that has fed us and the richer yield from labor of every kind that has sustained our lives—and for all those things, as dear as breath to the body, that quicken man’s faith in his manhood, that nourish and strengthen his word and act; for honor held above price; for steadfast courage and zeal in the long, long search after truth; for liberty and for justice freely granted by each to his fellow and so as freely enjoyed; and for the crowning glory and mercy of peace upon our land—that we may humbly take heart of these blessings as we gather once again with solemn and festive rites to keep our Harvest Home.

在这季节更迭之际，时间仿佛静止，坚韧的橡树叶在风中沙沙作响，霜冻为空气增添了一丝清凉，暮色早早降临，在猎户座的脚下，宜人的夜晚也渐渐延长。此时此刻，我们的人民觉得应该齐聚一堂，赞美造物主和守护者，感谢祂引领我们走过一条我们原本并不熟悉的道路，又走过了一年。为了遵循这一传统，我特此宣布11月26日星期四为公众感恩日，感谢祂赐予我们共同的福祉，使我们挚爱的州成为地球上最富饶的地区之一——感谢祂赐予我们的一切物质享受：土地的丰收养育了我们，各种劳动的丰收滋养了我们的生活——感谢祂赐予我们的一切，如同呼吸般珍贵，它增强了人们对自身价值的信念，滋养并强化了我们的言行；感谢祂无价的荣誉；感谢祂在漫长而艰辛的真理探索中展现出的坚定勇气和热忱；为了自由和正义，每个人都自由地给予他人，并自由地享受；为了和平的荣耀和恩典降临我们的土地——愿我们谦卑地接受这些祝福，再次聚集在一起，举行庄严而喜庆的仪式，庆祝我们的丰收节。

Governor Grasso added a postscript urging the citizens of Connecticut “to renew their dedication to the spirit of sacrifice and commitment which the Pilgrims invoked during their first harsh winter in the New World,” and I made a mental note to look at Orion that night. I was glad to be reminded that I was living in one of the favored regions of earth. I was also glad to be reminded that peace is not the only crowning glory to be thankful for. So is the English language when it is gracefully used for the public good. The cadences of Jefferson, Lincoln, Churchill, Roosevelt and Adlai Stevenson came rolling down to me. (The cadences of Eisenhower, Nixon and the two Bushes did not.)

格拉索州长在后记中敦促康涅狄格州的居民“重拾清教徒在新大陆第一个严冬中所展现的牺牲和奉献精神”，我暗暗记下当晚要看看猎户座。我很高兴自己生活在地球上最受眷顾的地区之一。我也很高兴自己意识到，和平并非唯一值得感恩的荣耀。当英语被优雅地用于公共福祉时，它也同样值得感恩。杰斐逊、林肯、丘吉尔、罗斯福和阿德莱·史蒂文森的语调仿佛在我耳边响起。（艾森豪威尔、尼克松和两位布什的语调则没有。）

I posted the Thanksgiving Proclamation on a bulletin board for my students to enjoy. From their comments I realized that several of them thought I was being facetious. Knowing my obsession with simplicity, they assumed that I regarded Governor Cross’s message as florid excess.

我把感恩节公告贴在公告栏上，让学生们欣赏。从他们的评论来看，我发现有好几个学生觉得我是在开玩笑。他们知道我崇尚简洁，所以以为我认为克罗斯州长的公告过于华丽繁复。

The incident left me with several questions. Had I sprung Wilbur Cross’s prose on a generation that had never been exposed to nobility of language as a means of addressing the populace? I couldn’t recall a single attempt since John F. Kennedy’s inaugural speech in 1961. (Mario Cuomo and Jesse Jackson would partly restore my faith.) This was a generation reared on television, where the picture is valued more than the word—where the word, in fact, is devalued, used as mere chatter and often misused and mispronounced. It was also a generation reared on music—songs and rhythms meant primarily to be heard and felt. With so much noise in the air, was any American child being trained to listen? Was anyone calling attention to the majesty of a well-constructed sentence?

这件事让我产生了诸多疑问。我是否让威尔伯·克罗斯的散文突兀地出现在一代人面前，而他们从未接触过以语言高雅之美来与民众沟通的理念？自1961年约翰·F·肯尼迪就职演说以来，我几乎想不起有人尝试过这种做法。（马里奥·科莫和杰西·杰克逊的演讲在一定程度上让我重拾信心。）这一代人成长于电视时代，画面比文字更重要——事实上，文字本身被贬低，沦为闲聊，常常被误用和发音错误。他们也是在音乐中成长起来的一代——歌曲和节奏主要是为了被聆听和感受。在如此嘈杂的环境中，美国的孩子是否接受过聆听的训练？是否有人关注过结构精良的句子的庄严之美？

My other question raised a more subtle mystery: what is the line that separates eloquence from bombast? Why are we exalted by the words of Wilbur Cross and anesthetized by the speeches of most politicians and public officials who ply us with oratorical ruffles and flourishes?

我的另一个问题引出了一个更为微妙的谜团：雄辩与夸夸其谈之间的界限是什么？为什么我们会被威尔伯·克罗斯的言辞所折服，却对大多数政客和公职人员用花言巧语和华丽辞藻敷衍我们的演讲感到麻木？

Part of the answer takes us back to taste. A writer with an ear for language will reach for fresh imagery and avoid phrases that are trite. The hack will reach for those very clichés, thinking he will enrich his thoughts with currency that is, as he would put it, tried and true. Another part of the answer lies in simplicity. Writing that will endure tends to consist of words that are short and strong; words that sedate are words of three, four and five syllables, mostly of Latin origin, many of them ending in “ion” and embodying a vague concept. In Wilbur Cross’s Thanksgiving Proclamation there are no four-syllable words and only ten three-syllable words, three of which are proper nouns he was stuck with. Notice how many of the governor’s words are anything but vague: leaves, wind, frost, air, evening, earth, comforts, soil, labor, breath, body, justice, courage, peace, land, rites, home. They are homely words in the best sense—they catch the rhythm of the seasons and the dailiness of life. Also notice that all of them are nouns. After verbs, plain nouns are your strongest tools; they resonate with emotion.

答案的一部分在于品味。一位对语言有敏锐感知的作家会追求新鲜的意象，避免陈词滥调。而庸才则会沉迷于这些老生常谈，以为这样就能用所谓的“久经考验”的词汇来丰富自己的思想。答案的另一部分在于简洁。经得起时间考验的文字往往由简短有力的词语构成；而那些平淡无奇的词语则多为三、四、五音节，大多源自拉丁语，许多以“ion”结尾，且含义模糊。在威尔伯·克罗斯的感恩节宣言中，没有一个四音节的词，只有十个三音节的词，其中三个还是他不得不使用的专有名词。请注意，州长使用的词语中有多少是清晰明确的：树叶、风、霜、空气、傍晚、大地、舒适、土壤、劳动、呼吸、身体、正义、勇气、和平、土地、仪式、家园。这些词语朴实无华，却又饱含真情——它们捕捉到了季节的韵律和生活的日常点滴。还要注意的是，它们都是名词。除了动词之外，普通的名词是你最强大的表达工具；它们能引起情感共鸣。

But ultimately eloquence runs on a deeper current. It moves us with what it leaves unsaid, touching off echoes in what we already know from our reading, our religion and our heritage. Eloquence invites us to bring some part of ourselves to the transaction. It was no accident that Lincoln’s speeches resounded with echoes of the King James Bible; he knew it almost by heart from his boyhood, and he had so soaked himself in its sonorities that his formal English was more Elizabethan than American. The Second Inaugural Address reverberates with Biblical phrases and paraphrases: “It may seem strange that any men should dare to ask a just God’s assistance in wringing their bread from the sweat of other men’s faces, but let us judge not, that we be not judged.” The first half of the sentence borrows a metaphor from Genesis, the second half reshapes a famous command in Matthew, and “a just God” is from Isaiah.

但归根结底，雄辩的源泉更为深远。它以未言明的言辞打动人心，唤起我们阅读、宗教和文化传承中已有的认知。雄辩邀请我们融入自身的某些特质。林肯的演讲中回荡着《钦定版圣经》的回响并非偶然；他自幼便对圣经耳熟能详，并深深沉浸于其韵律之中，以至于他的正式英语更接近伊丽莎白时代的风格而非美式英语。他的第二次就职演说中充满了圣经的词句和释义：“有人竟敢祈求公正的上帝帮助自己从他人的汗水中榨取面包，这或许令人匪夷所思，但我们不要论断人，免得我们被论断。”这句话的前半部分借用了《创世记》中的一个比喻，后半部分改编自《马太福音》中的一条著名诫命，“公正的上帝”则出自《以赛亚书》。

If this speech affects me more than any other American document, it’s not only because I know that Lincoln was killed five weeks later, or because I’m moved by all the pain that culminated in his plea for a reconciliation that would have malice toward none and charity for all. It’s also because Lincoln tapped some of Western man’s oldest teachings about slavery, clemency and judgment. His words carried stern overtones for the men and women who heard him in 1865, reared, as he was, on the Bible. But even in the 21st century it’s hard not to feel a wrath almost too ancient to grasp in Lincoln’s notion that God might will the Civil War to continue “until all the wealth piled by the bondsman’s two hundred and fifty years of unrequited toil shall be sunk, and until every drop of blood drawn with the lash shall be paid by another drawn with the sword, as was said three thousand years ago, so still it must be said ‘the judgments of the Lord are true and righteous altogether.’”

如果说这篇演讲比其他任何美国文献都更触动我，那不仅仅是因为我知道林肯在五周后遇刺身亡，也不仅仅是因为我被他那充满痛苦的呼吁所深深打动——他呼吁和解，不怀恶意，博爱众生。更重要的是，林肯触及了西方人类关于奴隶制、宽恕和审判的一些最古老的教义。对于1865年聆听他演讲的男男女女来说，他的话语中蕴含着严厉的意味，因为他们和他一样，都是在《圣经》的熏陶下长大的。但即使在 21 世纪，也很难不感受到林肯那种几乎古老到难以理解的愤怒，他认为上帝可能会让内战继续下去，“直到奴隶们两百五十年无偿劳动所积累的所有财富都化为乌有，直到每一滴鞭笞下流出的鲜血都由另一滴刀剑下流出的鲜血来偿还，正如三千年前所说，现在仍然要说‘主的审判完全真实公正’。”

Wilbur Cross’s Thanksgiving Proclamation also echoes with truths that we know in our bones. To such mysteries as the changing of the seasons and the bounty of the earth we bring strong emotions of our own. Who hasn’t looked with awe at Orion? To such democratic processes as “the long search after truth” and “liberty and justice freely granted” we bring fragments of our own searches after truth, our own grantings and receivings, in a nation where so many human rights have been won and so many still elude us. Governor Cross doesn’t take our time to explain these processes, and I’m grateful to him for that. I hate to think how many clichés a hack orator would marshal to tell us far more—and nourish us far less.

威尔伯·克罗斯的感恩节宣言也与我们骨子里早已熟知的真理产生了共鸣。对于四季更迭和大地馈赠等奥秘，我们怀着强烈的情感。谁不曾敬畏地仰望过猎户座？对于“对真理的漫长探索”和“自由与正义的自由授予”等民主进程，我们融入了自身对真理的探索、自身的给予与接受的片段，在这个国家，许多人权已经获得，但仍有许多权利与我们擦肩而过。克罗斯州长没有浪费时间去解释这些进程，我为此感激他。我不敢想象，一个蹩脚的演说家会堆砌多少陈词滥调，试图告诉我们更多——却无法真正滋养我们。

Therefore remember the uses of the past when you tell your story. What moves us in writing that has regional or ethnic roots—Southern writing, African-American writing, Jewish-American writing—is the sound of voices far older than the narrator’s, talking in cadences that are more than ordinarily rich. Toni Morrison, one of the most eloquent of black writers, once said: “I remember the language of the people I grew up with. Language was so important to them. All that power was in it. And grace and metaphor. Some of it was very formal and Biblical, because the habit is that when you have something important to say you go into parable, if you’re from Africa, or you go into another level of language. I wanted to use language that way, because my feeling was that a black novel was not black because I wrote it, or because there were black people in it, or because it was about black things. It was the style. It had a certain style. It was inevitable. I couldn’t describe it, but I could produce it.”

因此，在讲述你的故事时，要记住过去是如何被运用的。那些具有地域或民族根源的作品——南方文学、非裔美国人文学、犹太裔美国人文学——之所以能打动我们，是因为其中蕴含着远比叙述者更古老的声音，以及格外丰富而富有韵律的语言。托妮·莫里森，这位最具雄辩的黑人作家之一，曾说过：“我记得我成长过程中所接触的人们的语言。语言对他们来说如此重要。所有的力量都蕴藏其中。还有优雅和隐喻。有些语言非常正式，甚至带有圣经色彩，因为人们习惯于在有重要的事情要表达时，就使用寓言，如果你来自非洲，就会使用另一种语言形式。我想以这种方式运用语言，因为我觉得一部黑人小说之所以是黑人小说，并非因为我写了它，也并非因为里面有黑人，或者因为它讲述的是黑人的故事。而是因为它的风格。它有一种独特的风格。这是必然的。我无法描述它，但我可以创作它。”

Go with what seems inevitable in your own heritage. Embrace it and it may lead you to eloquence.

顺应你自身文化传承中那些看似不可避免的部分。拥抱它，它或许能引领你走向雄辩。

#↩

21

Enjoyment, Fear and Confidence

愉悦、恐惧与自信

As a boy I never wanted to grow up to be a writer, or—God forbid—an author. I wanted to be a newspaperman, and the newspaper I wanted to be a man on was the New York Herald Tribune . Reading it every morning, I loved the sense of enjoyment it conveyed. Everyone who worked on the paper—editors, writers, photographers, make-up men—was having a wonderful time. The articles usually had an extra touch of gracefulness, or humanity, or humor—some gift of themselves that the writers and editors enjoyed making to their readers. I thought they were putting out the paper just for me. To be one of those editors and writers was my idea of the ultimate American dream.

小时候，我从没想过长大后当作家，更别提——天哪——当个作者了。我只想当个报人，而我最想去的报社是《纽约先驱论坛报》。每天早上读这份报纸，我都喜欢它传递出的那种愉悦感。报社里的每个人——编辑、撰稿人、摄影师、化妆师——都乐在其中。文章里总是带着一丝优雅、一丝人情味，或者一丝幽默——那是作者和编辑们乐于献给读者的礼物。我觉得他们办这份报纸就是为了我。成为他们中的一员，就是我心目中美国梦的终极目标。

That dream came true when I returned home from World War II and got a job on the Herald Tribune staff. I brought with me my belief that a sense of enjoyment is a priceless attribute for a writer or for a publication, and I was now in the same room with the men and women who had first put that idea in my head. The great reporters wrote with warmth and gusto, and the great critics and columnists like Virgil Thomson and Red Smith wrote with elegance and with a mirthful confidence in their opinions. On the “split page”—as the first page of the second section was called, when papers only had two sections—the political column of Walter Lippmann, America’s most venerated pundit, ran above the one-panel cartoon by H. T. Webster, creator of “The Timid Soul,” who was also an American institution. I liked the insouciance that presented on the same page two features so different in gravity. Nobody thought of hustling Webster off to the comics section. Both men were giants, part of the same equation.

二战结束后，我回到家乡，在《先驱论坛报》找到了一份工作，我的梦想终于实现了。我一直坚信，对于作家和出版物而言，享受写作是一种无价的品质。如今，我与那些最初在我脑海中植入这种理念的男男女女共事。伟大的记者们文笔热情洋溢、充满活力，而像维吉尔·汤姆森和雷德·史密斯这样的伟大评论家和专栏作家则文笔优雅，对自己的观点充满自信。在报纸只有两版的时候，第二版的第一页被称为“分版面”，美国最受尊敬的评论家沃尔特·李普曼的政治专栏文章刊登在H·T·韦伯斯特的单幅漫画上方。韦伯斯特是《胆怯的灵魂》的创作者，他也是美国的一位标志性人物。我喜欢这种漫不经心的风格，将两种截然不同的主题并置在同一版面上。没有人想到要把韦伯斯特的作品调到漫画版面。两人都是巨人，是同一等式中的组成部分。

Among those blithe souls a city-desk reporter named John O’Reilly, who was admired for his deadpan coverage of human-interest and animal-interest stories, managed to make whimsy a serious beat. I remember his annual article about the woolly bear, the caterpillar whose brown and black stripes are said to foretell by their width whether the coming winter will be harsh or mild. Every fall O’Reilly would drive to Bear Mountain Park with the photographer Nat Fein, best known for his Pulitzer Prize–winning shot of Babe Ruth’s farewell at Yankee Stadium, to observe a sample of woolly bears crossing the road, and his article was written in mock-scientific museum-expedition style, duly portentous. The paper always ran the story at the bottom of page one under a three-column head, along with a cut of a woolly bear, its stripes none too distinct. In the spring O’Reilly would write a follow-up piece telling his readers whether the woolly bears had been right, and nobody blamed him—or them—if they hadn’t. The point was to give everybody a good time.

在那些轻松愉快的人当中，有一位名叫约翰·奥莱利的城市新闻记者，他以冷静客观的报道风格著称，报道人物和动物的故事，却能把奇思妙想变成严肃的新闻报道。我记得他每年都会写一篇关于毛毛虫的文章，据说这种毛毛虫身上的棕黑条纹的宽度可以预示即将到来的冬天是严寒还是温和。每年秋天，奥莱利都会和摄影师纳特·费恩一起开车去熊山公园，费恩最著名的作品是那张获得普利策奖的贝比·鲁斯在洋基体育场告别赛的照片。他们去观察毛毛虫过马路的情景，奥莱利的文章是用一种戏仿科学博物馆考察的风格写的，颇具神秘感。报纸总是把这篇文章放在头版底部，用三栏标题刊登，旁边还配了一张毛毛虫的图片，它的条纹并不十分清晰。春天的时候，奥莱利会写一篇后续文章，告诉读者毛毛熊的预言是否正确，如果预言错了，也没人会责怪他——或者责怪毛毛熊。关键是要给大家带来欢乐。

Since then I’ve made that sense of enjoyment my credo as a writer and an editor. Writing is such lonely work that I try to keep myself cheered up. If something strikes me as funny in the act of writing, I throw it in just to amuse myself. If I think it’s funny I assume a few other people will find it funny, and that seems to me to be a good day’s work. It doesn’t bother me that a certain number of readers will not be amused; I know that a fair chunk of the population has no sense of humor—no idea that there are people in the world trying to entertain them.

从那时起，我就把这种享受写作乐趣奉为我作为作家和编辑的信条。写作是一项孤独的工作，所以我努力让自己保持愉悦。如果在写作过程中，我突然觉得某个情节很有趣，我就会把它写进去，纯粹是为了自娱自乐。如果我觉得好笑，我就会觉得其他人也会觉得好笑，对我来说，这就算是完成了一项不错的工作。我并不在意有多少读者觉得不好笑；我知道相当一部分人缺乏幽默感——他们根本不知道世界上有人在努力逗他们开心。

When I was teaching at Yale I invited the humorist S. J. Perelman to talk to my students, and one of them asked him, “What does it take to be a comic writer?” He said, “It takes audacity and exuberance and gaiety, and the most important one is audacity.” Then he said: “The reader has to feel that the writer is feeling good.” The sentence went off in my head like a Roman candle: it stated the entire case for enjoyment. Then he added: “Even if he isn’t.” That sentence hit me almost as hard, because I knew that Perelman’s life contained more than the usual share of depression and travail. Yet he went to his typewriter every day and made the English language dance. How could he not be feeling good? He cranked it up.

我在耶鲁教书的时候，邀请幽默作家S·J·佩雷尔曼来给我的学生们讲课。其中一个学生问他：“成为一名喜剧作家需要什么？”他回答说：“需要胆识、热情和快乐，其中最重要的是胆识。”然后他又说：“读者必须感受到作家心情愉悦。”这句话在我脑海里像罗马烟火一样瞬间点燃：它道出了享受阅读的全部理由。接着他又补充道：“即便他心情不好。”这句话几乎同样震撼了我，因为我知道佩雷尔曼的人生充满了远超常人的抑郁和苦难。然而，他每天都坐在打字机前，让英语语言翩翩起舞。他怎么可能心情不好呢？他总是全力以赴。

Writers have to jump-start themselves at the moment of performance, no less than actors and dancers and painters and musicians. There are some writers who sweep us along so strongly in the current of their energy—Norman Mailer, Tom Wolfe, Toni Morrison, William F. Buckley, Jr., Hunter Thompson, David Foster Wallace, Dave Eggers—that we assume that when they go to work the words just flow. Nobody thinks of the effort they made every morning to turn on the switch.

作家和演员、舞蹈家、画家、音乐家一样，都需要在写作的那一刻迅速进入状态。有些作家——比如诺曼·梅勒、汤姆·沃尔夫、托妮·莫里森、小威廉·F·巴克利、亨特·汤普森、大卫·福斯特·华莱士、戴夫·艾格斯——他们笔下的能量如此强大，以至于我们理所当然地认为，他们一旦开始写作，文字就会源源不断地涌现。没有人会想到，他们每天早上为了“开启”写作模式，付出了多少努力。

You also have to turn on the switch. Nobody is going to do it for you.

你还得自己去打开开关。没人会替你做。

Unfortunately, an equally strong negative current—fear—is at work. Fear of writing gets planted in most Americans at an early age, usually at school, and it never entirely goes away. The blank piece of paper or the blank computer screen, waiting to be filled with our wonderful words, can freeze us into not writing any words at all, or writing words that are less than wonderful. I’m often dismayed by the sludge I see appearing on my screen if I approach writing as a task—the day’s work—and not with some enjoyment. My only consolation is that I’ll get another shot at those dismal sentences tomorrow and the next day and the day after. With each rewrite I try to force my personality onto the material.

不幸的是，还有一股同样强大的负面力量——恐惧——在暗中作祟。对写作的恐惧在大多数美国人心中埋下了种子，通常是在学校里，而且这种恐惧从未彻底消失。空白的纸张或空白的电脑屏幕，等待着我们用美妙的文字填满，却可能让我们僵住，一个字也写不出来，或者写出来的文字平淡无奇。如果我把写作当作一项任务——一天的工作——而不是一种享受，那么我常常会对屏幕上出现的那些糟糕文字感到沮丧。我唯一的安慰是，明天、后天、大后天，我都还有机会修改那些令人沮丧的句子。每一次修改，我都试图将自己的个性融入到文字之中。

Probably the biggest fear for nonfiction writers is the fear of not being able to bring off their assignment. With fiction it’s a different situation.
