Otherwise my purpose at this point was to tell the remainder of the story as simply as possible:

其中最难写的一句话是关于司机们摆弄路虎的那句。我希望它和其他句子一样简洁，但又要藏着一个小惊喜——一丝辛辣的幽默。除此之外，我当时的目的是尽可能简单地讲述故事的其余部分：

So the four hours passed before we knew they were gone, as if we had slipped into a different time zone, Sahara time, and in the late afternoon, when the sun’s heat had begun to ebb, we got back into our Land Rovers, which, to my surprise, still worked, and set out across the Sahara for what Mohammed Ali called our “encampment.” I pictured, if not a chieftain’s tent, at least a tent—something that announced itself as an encampment. When we finally did stop, it was at a spot that looked strikingly similar to what we had been driving over all day. It did, however, have one small tree. Some Bedouin women were crouched under it—black-garbed figures, their faces veiled—and Mohammed Ali put us down on the desert next to them.

就这样，四个小时过去了，我们才意识到他们已经走了，仿佛我们进入了另一个时区——撒哈拉时间。傍晚时分，太阳的热度开始消退，我们重新坐进路虎车里——令我惊讶的是，车子居然还能开——然后继续穿越撒哈拉沙漠，前往穆罕默德·阿里所说的“营地”。我想象着，即便不是酋长的帐篷，至少也是个帐篷——一个能表明自己是营地的东西。当我们最终停下时，发现营地和我们一整天行驶的路线惊人地相似。不过，这里多了一棵小树。几个贝都因妇女蹲在树下——她们身着黑衣，面纱遮面——穆罕默德·阿里把我们放在她们旁边的沙漠里。

The women shrank back at the sight of us—white aliens dumped abruptly in their midst. They were huddled so close together that they looked like a frieze. Obviously Mohammed Ali had just stopped at the first sight of “local color” that he happened to find for his tourists, counting on us to manage for ourselves after that. We could only sit and try to look friendly. But we were very conscious of being intruders, and we probably looked as uncomfortable as we felt. Only after we had sat there for a while did the black frieze slowly come apart and turn into four women, three children and two naked babies. Mohammed Ali had gone off somewhere, seemingly not wanting to have anything to do with the Bedouin; perhaps as a Tuareg he considered them desert riffraff.

女人们一看到我们——几个突然闯入她们中间的白人外星人——就吓得往后缩。她们挤在一起，像一幅浮雕。显然，穆罕默德·阿里只是碰巧为他的游客们找到了一些“当地特色”，就停了下来，指望我们之后能自谋生路。我们只能坐着，努力装出一副友善的样子。但我们很清楚自己是闯入者，可能看起来和我们内心的不自在一样。我们坐了一会儿之后，那幅黑色的浮雕才慢慢散开，变成了四个女人、三个孩子和两个赤身裸体的婴儿。穆罕默德·阿里已经走开了，似乎不想和这些贝都因人有任何瓜葛；或许作为一名图阿雷格人，他把他们看作是沙漠里的乌合之众。

But it was the Bedouin who had the grace to put us at ease. One of the women, lowering her veil and revealing a movie star’s smile—white teeth and shining black eyes in a beautiful face—rummaged in her belongings, pulled out a blanket and a straw mat, and brought them over for us to sit on. I remembered from all those books that in the desert there’s no such thing as an intruder; anyone who turns up is somehow expected. Soon after that, two Bedouin men came in from the desert, completing the family unit, which, we now saw, consisted of two men, two wives for each man, and their various children. The older husband, who had a strong and handsome face, greeted both of his wives with a gentle tap on the head, somewhat like a blessing, and then sat down not far from me. One of the women brought him his dinner—some millet in a bowl. He immediately offered the bowl to me. I declined, but the offer is one I won’t forget. We sat in companionable silence while he ate. The children came over to get acquainted. The sun went down and a full moon came up over the Sahara.

但真正让我们感到自在的，是那位贝都因人。一位妇女拉下面纱，露出了电影明星般的笑容——洁白的牙齿，明亮的黑眼睛，美丽的脸庞——她翻找着自己的行李，拿出一条毯子和一张草席，端过来让我们坐下。我记起从那些书里读到的，在沙漠里没有入侵者；任何出现的人都仿佛是命中注定。不久之后，两位贝都因男子从沙漠中走了进来，组成了这个完整的家庭。我们现在才知道，这个家庭由两个男人、每人两个妻子和他们的孩子们组成。年长的丈夫面容英俊健壮，他轻轻地拍了拍两位妻子的头，像是在祝福她们，然后坐在离我不远的地方。一位妇女给他端来了晚餐——一碗小米。他立刻把碗递给我。我婉拒了，但这份心意我永远不会忘记。我们默默地坐着，他吃得津津有味。孩子们过来互相认识。太阳落山了，一轮满月从撒哈拉沙漠升起。

Meanwhile our drivers had spread some blankets next to the two Land Rovers and started a fire with desert wood. We regrouped on our own blankets, watched the stars coming out in the desert sky, had some kind of chicken for dinner, and got ready to turn in. Bathroom facilities were ad hoc—to each his own. We had been warned that Sahara nights were cold and had brought sweaters along. I put on my sweater, rolled up in a blanket, which slightly softened the hardness of the desert, and fell asleep surrounded by an immense stillness. An hour later I was awakened by an equally immense racket—our Bedouin family had brought in their herd of goats and their camels for the night. Then all was quiet again.

与此同时，我们的司机在两辆路虎车旁铺开毯子，用沙漠木柴生起了火。我们各自躺在毯子上，看着沙漠夜空中的繁星，吃了些鸡肉当晚餐，然后准备睡觉。卫生间设施简陋——各人自扫门前雪。我们之前就被告知撒哈拉的夜晚很冷，所以带了毛衣。我穿上毛衣，裹上毯子，毯子稍微缓解了沙漠的寒冷，在万籁俱寂中沉沉睡去。一个小时后，我被一阵同样巨大的喧闹声吵醒——我们的贝都因人家人把他们的羊群和骆驼赶了过来过夜。之后，一切又恢复了平静。

In the morning I noticed paw prints in the sand next to my blanket. Mohammed Ali said that a jackal had come by to clean up the leftovers from our dinner—of which, as I recalled the chicken, there must have been quite a few. But I didn’t hear a thing. I was too busy dreaming that I was Lawrence of Arabia.

早上，我注意到毯子旁边的沙滩上有爪印。穆罕默德·阿里说，一只豺狼过来吃我们晚饭剩下的东西了——我记得晚饭里有鸡肉，所以剩饭肯定不少。但我什么也没听到。我当时正沉浸在幻想中，觉得自己是阿拉伯的劳伦斯。

[END]

[结尾]

A crucial decision about a piece of writing is where to end it. Often the story will tell you where it wants to stop. This ending was not the one I originally had in mind. Because the goal of our trip was to find a salt caravan I assumed that I would have to complete the ancient cycle of trade: to describe how we returned to Timbuktu and saw the salt being unloaded and bought and sold in the market. But the nearer I got to writing that final section, the more I didn’t want to write it. It loomed as drudgery, no fun for me or for the reader.

写作的关键在于如何结尾。通常，故事会告诉你它想在哪里结束。这个结尾并非我最初设想的那样。因为我们此行的目的是寻找盐商队，我以为我必须完整地讲述古老的贸易循环：描述我们如何返回廷巴克图，以及盐是如何在市场上被卸货、买卖的。但越接近写到最后那一部分，我就越不想写。它在我看来就像苦差事，对我和读者来说都毫无乐趣可言。

Suddenly I remembered that I was under no obligation to the actual shape of our trip. I didn’t have to reconstruct everything . The real climax of my story was not finding the salt caravan; it was finding the timeless hospitality of the people who live in the Sahara. Not many moments in my life have matched the one when a family of nomads with almost no possessions offered to share their dinner. Nor could any other moment distill more vividly what I had come to the desert to find and what all those Englishmen had written about—the nobility of living on the edge.

我突然意识到，我并不需要拘泥于我们旅程的实际轨迹。我无需重现一切。我故事的真正高潮并非找到盐商队，而是邂逅撒哈拉沙漠居民那份亘古不变的热情好客。我生命中鲜有时刻能与这几乎一无所有的游牧家庭热情款待我共进晚餐的那一刻相提并论。也没有任何时刻能比这更生动地诠释我来到沙漠的真正目的，以及所有英国人笔下描绘的——在边缘生存的崇高境界。

When you get such a message from your material—when your story tells you it’s over, regardless of what subsequently happened—look for the door. I got out fast, pausing only long enough to make sure that the unities were intact: that the writer-guide who started the trip was the same person who was ending it. The playful reference to Lawrence preserves the persona, wraps up a multitude of associations and brings the journey full circle. The realization that I could just stop was a terrific feeling, not only because my labors were over—the jigsaw puzzle solved—but because the ending felt right. It was the correct decision.

当你从素材中接收到这样的信息——当你的故事告诉你一切都结束了，无论之后发生了什么——那就寻找出口。我迅速离开，只稍作停留，确认故事的完整性：开启这段旅程的作家兼向导，与结束旅程的正是同一个人。对劳伦斯的巧妙引用保留了人物形象，总结了诸多联想，使整个旅程首尾呼应。意识到我可以就此止步，这种感觉棒极了，不仅因为我的劳动结束了——拼图游戏完成了——更因为结局恰到好处。这是个正确的决定。

As a postscript, there’s one last decision I’d like to mention. It has to do with the nonfiction writer’s need to make his or her own luck. An exhortation I often use to keep myself going is “Get on the plane.” Two of the most emotional moments of my life came as a result of getting on the plane in connection with my book Mitchell & Ruff . First I went to Shanghai with the musicians Willie Ruff and Dwike Mitchell when they introduced jazz to China at the Shanghai Conservatory of Music. A year later I went to Venice with Ruff to hear him play Gregorian chants on his French horn in St. Mark’s basilica at night, when nobody else was there, to study the acoustics that inspired the Venetian school of music. In both cases Ruff had no assurance that he would be allowed to play; I might have wasted my time and money by deciding to go along. But I got on the plane, and those two long pieces, which originally ran in The New Yorker , are probably my two best articles. I got on the plane to Timbuktu to look for a camel caravan that was an even bet not to materialize, and I got on the plane to Bradenton for spring training not knowing whether I would be welcomed or rebuffed. My book Writing to Learn was born because of one phone call from a stranger. It raised an educational idea so interesting that I got on the plane to Minnesota to pursue it.

最后，我想提一下我做的最后一个决定。这与非虚构作家需要自己创造机会有关。我经常用来激励自己的一句话是“登上飞机”。我生命中最激动人心的两个时刻都与我为《米切尔与拉夫》这本书登上飞机有关。第一次，我和音乐家威利·拉夫以及德威克·米切尔一起去了上海，当时他们正在上海音乐学院将爵士乐引入中国。一年后，我和拉夫一起去了威尼斯，在圣马可大教堂的夜晚，当教堂里空无一人时，聆听他用法国号演奏格里高利圣咏，以此来研究启发威尼斯音乐学派的音响效果。在这两次经历中，拉夫都无法保证自己会被允许演奏；如果我决定同行，我可能就会浪费时间和金钱。但我还是登上了飞机，而这两篇最初发表在《纽约客》上的长文，或许是我写得最好的两篇文章。我曾飞往廷巴克图寻找一支几乎不可能出现的骆驼商队，也曾飞往布雷登顿参加春季训练，当时我并不知道会受到欢迎还是冷遇。我的书《写作学习》的诞生源于一个陌生人的电话。他提出的教育理念如此引人入胜，以至于我飞往明尼苏达州去实践它。

Getting on the plane has taken me to unusual stories all over the world and all over America, and it still does. That isn’t to say I’m not nervous when I leave for the airport; I always am—that’s part of the deal. (A little nervousness gives writing an edge.) But I’m always replenished when I get back home.

登上飞机，带我踏上世界各地、遍及美国各地的奇闻异事之旅，至今依然如此。但这并不意味着我去机场时不会紧张；我总是会紧张——这是工作的一部分。（一点点紧张感能激发写作的灵感。）但每次回到家，我都会感到精神焕发。

As a nonfiction writer you must get on the plane. If a subject interests you, go after it, even if it’s in the next county or the next state or the next country. It’s not going to come looking for you.

作为一名非虚构作家，你必须主动出击。如果你对某个主题感兴趣，就去追寻它，即使它远在隔壁县、隔壁州，甚至隔壁国家。它不会自己找上门来。

Decide what you want to do. Then decide to do it. Then do it.

决定你想做什么。然后决定去做。然后就去做。

#↩

24

Writing Family History and Memoir

撰写家族史和回忆录

One of the saddest sentences I know is “I wish I had asked my mother about that.” Or my father. Or my grandmother. Or my grandfather. As every parent knows, our children are not as fascinated by our fascinating lives as we are. Only when they have children of their own—and feel the first twinges of their own advancing age—do they suddenly want to know more about their family heritage and all its accretions of anecdote and lore. “What exactly were those stories my dad used to tell about coming to America?” “Where exactly was that farm in the Midwest where my mother grew up?”

我听过最令人伤感的一句话是：“我真希望当初问问我妈妈。”或者我爸爸。或者我奶奶。或者我爷爷。每个父母都知道，我们的孩子不像我们自己那样对我们精彩的生活充满好奇。只有当他们有了自己的孩子——并开始感受到自己正在老去——他们才会突然想要了解更多关于家族传承以及其中积累的各种轶事和传说。“我爸爸以前讲的那些关于他们来到美国的故事到底是怎么回事？”“我妈妈长大的那个中西部农场到底在哪里？”

Writers are the custodians of memory, and that’s what this chapter is about: how to leave some kind of record of your life and of the family you were born into. That record can take many shapes. It can be a formal memoir—a careful act of literary construction. Or it can be an informal family history, written to tell your children and your grandchildren about the family they were born into. It can be the oral history that you extract by tape recorder from a parent or a grandparent too old or too sick to do any writing. Or it can be anything else you want it to be: some hybrid mixture of history and reminiscence. Whatever it is, it’s an important kind of writing. Memories too often die with their owner, and time too often surprises us by running out.

作家是记忆的守护者，而本章的主题正是如此：如何留下关于你的人生以及你出身的家庭的记录。这种记录可以呈现多种形式。它可以是一部正式的回忆录——一部精心构建的文学作品。它也可以是一种非正式的家族史，用来向你的孩子和孙辈讲述他们出生的家庭。它还可以是你用录音机从年迈体弱、无法书写的父母或祖父母那里收集到的口述历史。或者，它也可以是你希望它呈现的任何形式：历史与回忆的某种混合体。无论它是什么，这都是一种重要的写作方式。记忆常常随着主人的离世而消逝，而时间也常常猝不及防地流逝。

My father, a businessman with no literary pretensions, wrote two family histories in his old age. It was the perfect task for a man with few gifts for self-amusement. Sitting in his favorite green leather armchair in an apartment high above Park Avenue, he wrote a history of his side of the family—the Zinssers and the Scharmanns—going back to 19th-century Germany. Then he wrote a history of the family shellac business on West 59th Street that his grandfather founded in 1849. He wrote with a pencil on a yellow legal pad, never pausing—then or ever again—to rewrite. He had no patience with any enterprise that obliged him to reexamine or slow down. On the golf course, walking toward his ball, he would assess the situation, pick a club out of the bag and swing at the ball as he approached it, hardly breaking stride.

我的父亲是一位商人，对文学并无丝毫兴趣，却在晚年撰写了两部家族史。对于一个缺乏自娱自乐天赋的人来说，这无疑是一项完美的任务。他坐在位于公园大道高层公寓里最爱的绿色皮椅上，写下了他这边的家族史——津瑟家族和沙尔曼家族——追溯到19世纪的德国。之后，他又写下了位于西59街的家族虫胶生意史，这家生意是他祖父于1849年创立的。他用铅笔在黄色法律用纸上写作，从未停顿过——无论是当时还是之后——去修改。他无法容忍任何需要他反复检查或放慢速度的事情。在球场上，他走向球时，会评估一下情况，从球包里抽出一根球杆，边走边挥杆，几乎不停顿脚步。

When my father finished writing his histories he had them typed, mimeographed and bound in a plastic cover. He gave a copy, personally inscribed, to each of his three daughters, to their husbands, to me, to my wife, and to his 15 grandchildren, some of whom couldn’t yet read. I like the fact that they all got their own copy; it recognized each of them as an equal partner in the family saga. How many of those grandchildren spent any time with the histories I have no idea. But I’ll bet some of them did, and I like to think that those 15 copies are now squirreled away somewhere in their houses from Maine to California, waiting for the next generation.

父亲写完家族史后，将其打印、油印，并装订成册，用塑料封皮封好。他亲笔题词，将副本分别赠予他的三个女儿、她们的丈夫、我、我的妻子，以及他的十五个孙辈——其中一些孩子当时还不识字。我很喜欢他们每个人都拥有一本的做法；这体现了他们作为家族史中平等成员的地位。至于有多少孙辈真正读过这些家族史，我不得而知。但我敢肯定，他们当中肯定有人读过。我愿意相信，这十五本家族史如今正被珍藏在他们家中的某个角落，从缅因州到加利福尼亚州，等待着下一代的到来。

What my father did strikes me as a model for a family history that doesn’t aspire to be anything more; the idea of having it published wouldn’t have occurred to him. There are many good reasons for writing that have nothing to do with being published. Writing is a powerful search mechanism, and one of its satisfactions is to come to terms with your life narrative. Another is to work through some of life’s hardest knocks—loss, grief, illness, addiction, disappointment, failure—and to find understanding and solace.

我父亲的做法在我看来堪称家族史的典范，他并不追求出版，而是将其作为家族史的一部分。他从未想过要出版这本书。写作的意义有很多，与出版无关。写作是一种强大的探索机制，其乐趣之一在于帮助你理解自己的人生故事。另一个乐趣在于帮助你走出人生中最艰难的困境——失去亲人、悲痛、疾病、成瘾、失望、失败——并从中找到理解和慰藉。

My father’s two histories have steadily grown on me. At first I don’t think I was as generous toward them as I should have been; probably I condescended to the ease with which he brought off a process I found so hard. But over the years I’ve often found myself dipping into them to remind myself of some long-lost relative, or to check some long-lost fact of New York geography, and with every reading I admire the writing more.

我父亲的两部传记渐渐让我着迷。起初，我觉得自己对它们不够宽容；或许是因为我轻视了他轻松完成我苦苦追寻却又无比艰难的过程。但这些年来，我常常翻阅它们，回忆起某个失散多年的亲人，或是查阅一些早已遗忘的纽约地理知识，而每一次阅读，我都更加欣赏他的文笔。

Above all, there’s the matter of voice. Not being a writer, my father never worried about finding his “style.” He just wrote the way he talked, and now, when I read his sentences, I hear his personality and his humor, his idioms and his usages, many of them an echo of his college years in the early 1900s. I also hear his honesty. He wasn’t sentimental about blood ties, and I smile at his terse appraisals of Uncle X, “a second-rater,” or Cousin Y, who “never amounted to much.”

最重要的是声音。父亲并非作家，所以他从不费心寻找自己的“风格”。他只是用说话的方式写作，如今，当我读他的文字时，我能感受到他的个性、他的幽默、他的习语和用词，其中许多都带有他20世纪初大学时代的印记。我也能感受到他的坦诚。他并不看重血缘关系，每当我看到他对某某叔叔的评价——“一个二流人物”或某某表兄——“一事无成”时，我都会会心一笑。

Remember this when you write your own family history. Don’t try to be a “writer.” It now occurs to me that my father was a more natural writer than I am, with my constant fiddling and fussing. Be yourself and your readers will follow you anywhere. Try to commit an act of writing and your readers will jump overboard to get away. Your product is you . The crucial transaction in memoir and personal history is the transaction between you and your remembered experiences and emotions.

撰写家族史时，请记住这一点：不要试图成为一个“作家”。我现在意识到，我父亲比我更有写作天赋，而我总是喜欢摆弄文字，斤斤计较。做你自己，你的读者就会追随你。如果你刻意写作，读者反而会避之不及。你的作品就是你自己。回忆录和个人史的关键在于你与你记忆中的经历和情感之间的互动。

In his family history my father didn’t dodge the central trauma of his childhood: the abrupt end of his parents’ marriage when he and his brother Rudolph were still small boys. Their mother was the daughter of a self-made German immigrant, H. B. Scharmann, who went to California as a teenager in a covered wagon with the Forty-niners and lost both his mother and his sister on the journey. Frida Scharmann inherited his fierce pride and ambition, and when she married William Zinsser, a promising young man in her circle of German-American friends, she saw him as the answer to her cultural aspirations. They would spend their evenings going to concerts and to the opera and holding musical salons. But the promising husband evidently turned out to have no such yearnings. Home was for falling asleep in his chair after dinner.

父亲的家族史中，他无法回避童年时期最深刻的创伤：父母在他和弟弟鲁道夫还是幼童时，婚姻戛然而止。他们的母亲弗里达·沙尔曼的父亲是一位白手起家的德国移民，名叫H·B·沙尔曼。十几岁时，他跟随淘金者们乘坐篷车前往加利福尼亚，途中失去了母亲和妹妹。弗里达继承了父亲强烈的自尊和雄心壮志。当她嫁给威廉·津瑟时，她视他为实现自己文化追求的希望。威廉是她德裔美国朋友圈中一位前途无量的年轻人。他们经常一起去听音乐会、看歌剧，还会举办音乐沙龙。然而，这位前途光明的丈夫显然并没有这样的渴望。对他来说，家的意义在于晚饭后瘫倒在椅子上睡觉。

How bitterly his lassitude must have dawned on the young Frida Zinsser I can imagine from knowing her as an older woman, endlessly pushing herself to Carnegie Hall, playing Beethoven and Brahms on the piano, traveling to Europe and learning foreign languages, prodding my father and my sisters and me to cultural self-improvement. Her drive to fulfill the broken dreams of her marriage never faltered. But she had the German penchant for telling people off, and she died alone at 81, having scolded away all her friends.

我能想象，年轻的弗里达·津瑟（Frida Zinsser）得知父亲的倦怠时该是多么痛苦。我认识她多年，那时她依然坚持不懈地在卡内基音乐厅演出，弹奏贝多芬和勃拉姆斯的钢琴曲，游历欧洲学习外语，并激励我的父亲、姐妹和我提升文化修养。她为实现婚姻中破碎的梦想而奋斗的动力从未动摇。但她也像德国人一样，喜欢训斥别人，最终在81岁时孤独地离世，生前她已经和所有朋友都断绝了关系。

I wrote about her once, many years ago, in a memoir for a book called Five Boyhoods . Describing the grandmother I knew as a boy, I praised her strength but also noted that she was a difficult presence in our lives. After the book came out my mother defended the mother-in-law who had made her own life far from easy. “Grandma was really quite shy,” she said, “and she wanted to be liked.” Maybe so; the truth is somewhere between my mother’s version and mine. But she was like that to me . That was my remembered truth, and that’s how I wrote it.

很多年前，我在一本名为《五个男孩的童年》的回忆录中写过她。在描述我童年记忆中的祖母时，我赞扬了她的坚强，但也指出她是我们生活中一个难以相处的存在。书出版后，我母亲为这位婆婆辩护，尽管她自己也过得并不轻松。“奶奶其实很害羞，”她说，“她渴望被人喜欢。”也许是这样；真相介于我母亲的说法和我的说法之间。但她对我就是这样。那是我记忆中的真相，所以我才这样写。

I mention this because one of the questions often asked by memoir writers is: Should I write from the point of view of the child I once was, or of the adult I am now? The strongest memoirs, I think, are those that preserve the unity of a remembered time and place: books like Russell Baker’s Growing Up , or V.S. Pritchett’s A Cab at the Door , or Jill Ker Conway’s The Road from Coorain , which recall what it was like to be a child or an adolescent in a world of adults contending with life’s adversities.

我之所以提到这一点，是因为回忆录作者经常会问自己：我应该以曾经的孩童视角来写作，还是以现在的成年人视角来写作？我认为，最优秀的回忆录是那些能够保留记忆中特定时空统一性的作品：例如拉塞尔·贝克的《成长》（Growing Up）、V·S·普里切特的《门口的出租车》（A Cab at the Door）以及吉尔·克尔·康威的《库兰之路》（The Road from Coorain），这些作品都回忆了在成人世界中与生活逆境抗争的童年或青少年时期是什么样的体验。

But if you prefer the other route—to write about your younger years from the wiser perspective of your older years—that memoir will have its own integrity. One good example is Poets in Their Youth , in which Eileen Simpson recalls her early life with her first husband, John Berryman, and his famously self-destructive fellow poets, including Robert Lowell and Delmore Schwartz, whose demons she was too young as a bride to understand. When she revisited that period in her memoir as an older woman she had become a writer and a practicing psychotherapist, and she used that clinical knowledge to create an invaluable portrait of a major school of American poetry. But these are two different kinds of writing. Choose one.

但如果你更倾向于另一种方式——以年长者的睿智视角来书写你的青年时代——那么这样的回忆录自有其独特的价值。一个很好的例子是《青年诗人》（Poets in Their Youth），艾琳·辛普森在书中回忆了她与第一任丈夫约翰·贝里曼的早年生活，以及他那些以自我毁灭著称的诗人朋友，包括罗伯特·洛威尔和德尔莫·施瓦茨。当时的她还是个年轻的新娘，对他们的内心挣扎一无所知。当她以一位年长女性的身份重访这段时期时，她已成为一名作家和执业心理治疗师，并运用这些临床知识，为美国诗歌的一个重要流派描绘了一幅弥足珍贵的画像。但这两种写作方式截然不同。选择一种吧。

My father’s family history told me details about his mother’s marriage that I didn’t have when I wrote my memoir. Now, knowing those facts, I can understand the disappointments that made her the woman she became, and if I were to take another shot at the family saga today I would bring to it a lifetime of trying to fathom its Germanic storms and stresses. (My mother’s family of New England Yankees—Knowltons and Joyces—managed to get through life without emotional melodrama.) I would also bring to it a lifetime of regret over the tremendous hole at the center of my father’s story. In his two histories his father gets scant mention and no forgiveness; all sympathy goes to the aggrieved young divorcée and her lifelong grit.

父亲的家族史让我了解到他母亲婚姻中的一些细节，这些是我在撰写回忆录时所不了解的。如今，了解了这些事实，我才能理解那些让她变成后来那样的人的失望经历。如果今天让我重新审视这段家族史，我会带着毕生精力去理解其中蕴含的德国式风暴和压力。（我母亲的家族——诺尔顿家族和乔伊斯家族——是新英格兰的“扬基佬”，他们成功地度过了人生，没有经历过任何情感上的戏剧性事件。）我也会带着毕生的遗憾去讲述父亲故事中那巨大的空白。在他自己的两份家族史中，他的父亲几乎没有被提及，也没有得到任何宽恕；所有的同情都集中在那位饱受委屈的年轻离异女子和她终生坚韧的性格上。

Yet some of my father’s most attractive qualities—the charm, the humor, the lightness, the bluest of blue eyes—must have come from the Zinsser side, not from the brooding, brown-eyed Scharmanns. I’ve always felt deprived of knowing more about that missing grandfather. Whenever I asked my father about him he changed the subject and had no stories to tell. When you write your family history, be a recording angel and record everything your descendants might want to know.

然而，我父亲身上一些最吸引人的特质——魅力、幽默、轻松的性格，以及那双湛蓝的眼睛——想必是遗传自津瑟家族，而非忧郁寡言、棕色眼睛的沙尔曼家族。我一直感到遗憾，没能更多地了解那位失踪的祖父。每当我问起父亲，他总是转移话题，不愿多谈。当你撰写家族史时，请像一位记录天使，记录下所有后代可能想知道的一切。

This brings me to another question that memoir writers often ask: What about the privacy of the people I write about? Should I leave out things that might offend or hurt my relatives? What will my sister think?

这让我想到回忆录作者经常会问的另一个问题：我笔下人物的隐私该如何保障？我是否应该省略那些可能会冒犯或伤害我亲属的事情？我妹妹会怎么想？

Don’t worry about that problem in advance. Your first job is to get your story down as you remember it— now . Don’t look over your shoulder to see what relatives are perched there. Say what you want to say, freely and honestly, and finish the job. Then take up the privacy issue. If you wrote your family history only for your family, there’s no legal or ethical need to show it to anyone else. But if you have in mind a broader audience—a mailing to friends or a possible book—you may want to show your relatives the pages in which they are mentioned. That’s a basic courtesy; nobody wants to be surprised in print. It also gives them their moment to ask you to take certain passages out—which you may or may not agree to do.

别提前担心这个问题。你的首要任务是把你记忆中的故事写下来——就现在。别回头去看哪个亲戚坐在旁边。畅所欲言，坦诚相待，把事情做完。然后再考虑隐私问题。如果你写家谱只是为了家人，那么无论从法律还是道德上，你都没有义务把它给其他人看。但如果你打算面向更广泛的读者——比如寄给朋友或者出版成书——你可能需要把提到他们的页面给亲戚们看看。这是基本的礼貌；没人希望在纸上看到自己的名字时感到意外。这也给了他们机会，让他们可以要求你删除某些段落——你可以选择同意，也可以选择不同意。

Finally, it’s your story—you’re the one who has done all the work. If your sister has a problem with your memoir she can write her own memoir, and it will be just as valid as yours; nobody has a monopoly on the shared past. Some of your relatives will wish you hadn’t said some of the things you said, especially if you reveal various family traits that are less than lovable. But I believe that at some deep level most families want to have a record left of their effort to be a family, however flawed that effort was, and they will give you their blessing and will thank you for taking on the job. If you do it honestly and not for the wrong reasons.

最后，这是你的故事——是你付出了所有努力。如果你的妹妹对你的回忆录有意见，她可以自己写一本，而且她的回忆录和你的一样有价值；没有人能垄断共同的过去。你的一些亲戚可能会希望你没说过某些话，尤其是当你揭露了一些不太讨喜的家庭特质时。但我相信，在内心深处，大多数家庭都希望留下他们努力维系家庭的记录，无论这种努力多么不完美，他们会祝福你，并感谢你承担了这份责任。前提是你真心实意，而不是出于不正当的动机。

What are the wrong reasons? Let me take you back to the memoir-crazed 1990s. Until that decade, memoir writers drew a veil over their most shameful experiences and thoughts; certain civilities were still agreed on by society. Then talk shows came into their own and shame went out the window. Suddenly no remembered episode was too squalid, no family too dysfunctional, to be trotted out for the titillation of the masses on cable TV and in magazines and books. The result was an avalanche of memoirs that were little more than therapy, their authors using the form to wallow in self-revelation and self-pity and to bash everyone who had ever done them wrong. Writing was out and whining was in.

什么才是错误的理由？让我带你回到上世纪90年代那个回忆录盛行的年代。在那之前，回忆录作者都会用面纱掩盖自己最羞耻的经历和想法；社会上还普遍认同某些礼仪规范。后来，脱口秀节目兴起，羞耻感荡然无存。突然间，任何不堪回首的往事，任何功能失调的家庭，都可以被搬上电视、杂志和书籍，供大众消遣。结果就是回忆录如雪崩般涌现，这些回忆录与其说是回忆录，不如说是心理治疗的产物，作者们借此沉溺于自我揭露和自我怜悯，并抨击所有曾经伤害过他们的人。写作不再是正经事，抱怨才是王道。

But nobody remembers those books today; readers won’t connect with whining. Don’t use your memoir to air old grievances and to settle old scores; get rid of that anger somewhere else. The memoirs that we do remember from the 1990s are the ones that were written with love and forgiveness, like Mary Karr’s The Liars’ Club , Frank McCourt’s Angela’s Ashes , Tobias Wolff’s This Boy’s Life , and Pete Hamill’s A Drinking Life . Although the childhoods they describe were painful, the writers are as hard on their younger selves as they are on their elders. We are not victims, they want us to know. We come from a tribe of fallible people and we have survived without resentment to get on with our lives. For them, writing a memoir became an act of healing.

但如今已无人记得那些书；读者对抱怨之词毫无共鸣。不要用回忆录来发泄旧怨、清算旧账；把怒气发泄到别处吧。我们能记住的90年代回忆录，都是那些饱含爱与宽恕的作品，比如玛丽·卡尔的《骗子俱乐部》、弗兰克·麦考特的《安琪拉的灰烬》、托比亚斯·沃尔夫的《男孩的生活》以及皮特·哈米尔的《酗酒人生》。尽管他们笔下的童年充满痛苦，但作者们对年幼的自己和对长辈一样苛刻。他们想让我们明白，我们并非受害者。我们来自一个充满缺陷的群体，但我们不怀怨恨地生存了下来，继续前行。对他们而言，撰写回忆录成为了一种疗愈的方式。

It can also be an act of healing for you. If you make an honest transaction with your own humanity and with the humanity of the people who crossed your life, no matter how much pain they caused you or you caused them, readers will connect with your journey.

这也可以成为你疗愈自己的一种方式。如果你能真诚地面对自己的人性，以及那些曾出现在你生命中的人的人性，无论他们曾给你带来多少痛苦，或者你曾给他们带来多少痛苦，读者都会与你的经历产生共鸣。

Now comes the hard part: how to organize the damn thing. Most people embarking on a memoir are paralyzed by the size of the task. What to put in? What to leave out? Where to start? Where to stop? How to shape the story? The past looms over them in a thousand fragments, defying them to impose on it some kind of order. Because of this anxiety, many memoirs linger for years half-written, or never get written at all.

现在到了最难的部分：如何组织这该死的回忆录。大多数着手写回忆录的人都会被这项任务的庞大所吓倒。该写些什么？该省略些什么？从哪里开始？在哪里结束？如何构建故事？过去如同无数碎片般笼罩着他们，让他们难以从中理出头绪。正是由于这种焦虑，许多回忆录搁置多年，要么只写了一半，要么根本就没写出来。

What can be done?

可以采取哪些措施？

You must make a series of reducing decisions. For example: in a family history, one big decision would be to write about only one branch of the family. Families are complex organisms, especially if you trace them back several generations. Decide to write about your mother’s side of the family or your father’s side, but not both. Return to the other one later and make it a separate project.

你必须做出一系列取舍。例如：在撰写家族史时，一个重要的决定就是只写家族的一个分支。家族是一个复杂的系统，尤其是当你追溯到几代以前时。决定写你母亲那边的家族，或者你父亲那边的家族，但不要两者都写。另一边的家族可以以后再写，作为另一个独立的项目。

Remember that you are the protagonist in your memoir—the tour guide. You must find a narrative trajectory for the story you want to tell and never relinquish control. This means leaving out of your memoir many people who don’t need to be there. Like siblings.

记住，你是你回忆录的主角——是导游。你必须找到你想讲述的故事的叙事轨迹，并且永远不要放弃控制权。这意味着你的回忆录中要省略许多不必要的人，比如兄弟姐妹。

One of my students in a memoir class was a woman who wanted to write about the house in Michigan where she grew up. Her mother had died, the house had been sold, and she and her father and her ten sisters and brothers were about to meet at the house to dispose of its contents. Writing about that task, she thought, would help her to understand her childhood in that large Catholic family. I agreed—it was a perfect framework for a memoir—and I asked her how she was going to proceed.

我教的回忆录写作课上有一位女学生，她想写写她在密歇根州长大的那栋房子。她的母亲去世了，房子也卖掉了，她和父亲以及十个兄弟姐妹即将齐聚老宅，处理里面的物品。她觉得，把这件事写下来，能帮助她更好地理解自己在那个天主教大家庭中的童年生活。我同意她的看法——这的确是一个完美的回忆录框架——于是我问她打算怎么写。

She said she was going to start by interviewing her father and all her brothers and sisters to find out how they remembered the house. I asked her if the story she wanted to write was their story. No, she said, it was her story. In that case, I said, interviewing all those siblings would be an almost complete waste of her time and energy. Only then did she begin to glimpse the proper shape of her story and to prepare her mind for confronting the house and its memories. I saved her hundreds of hours of interviewing and transcribing and trying to fit what she transcribed into her memoir, where it didn’t belong. It’s your story. You only need to interview family members who have a unique insight into a family situation, or an anecdote that unlocks a puzzle you were unable to solve.

她说她打算先采访她的父亲和所有兄弟姐妹，了解他们对那栋房子的记忆。我问她，她想写的故事是不是他们的故事。她说，不，是她自己的故事。我说，既然如此，采访所有兄弟姐妹几乎完全是在浪费她的时间和精力。直到那时，她才开始隐约看到故事的雏形，并做好面对那栋房子和相关记忆的心理准备。我帮她省去了数百小时的采访、整理和硬塞进回忆录里那些不合适的内容。这是你的故事。你只需要采访那些对家庭情况有独特见解的家庭成员，或者那些能解开你一直无法解开的谜题的轶事。

Here’s another story from another class.

这是另一个班级的故事。

A young Jewish woman named Helen Blatt was very eager to write about her father’s experience as a survivor of the Holocaust. He had escaped from his village in Poland at the age of 14—one of the few Jews to get away—and had made his way to Italy, to New Orleans and, finally, to New York. Now he was 80, and his daughter asked him to go back with her to that Polish village so she could hear about his early life and write his story. But he begged off; he was too frail and the past was too painful.

一位名叫海伦·布拉特的年轻犹太女子非常渴望写下她父亲作为大屠杀幸存者的经历。她的父亲14岁时逃离了波兰的村庄——他是少数几个成功逃脱的犹太人之一——之后辗转来到意大利、新奥尔良，最终定居纽约。如今他已80岁高龄，女儿请求他与她一同回到那个波兰村庄，以便了解他早年的生活，并记录下他的故事。但他婉拒了；他身体太过虚弱，往事也太过痛苦。

So she made the trip on her own in 2004. She took notes and photographs and talked with people in the village. But she couldn’t find enough facts to enable her to do justice to her father’s story, and she was deeply upset about that. Her despair hung over the class.

于是，2004年她独自踏上了这段旅程。她做笔记、拍照，并与村民交谈。但她始终找不到足够的史料来完整地讲述父亲的故事，这让她深感沮丧。她的失望笼罩着整个课堂。

For a few moments I couldn’t think of anything to tell her. Finally I said, “It’s not your father’s story.”

我一时语塞，不知道该跟她说些什么。最后，我说：“这不是你父亲的故事。”

She gave me a look that I still remember as it dawned on her what I was saying.

她当时给了我一个我至今记忆犹新的眼神，她似乎明白了我说的话。

“It’s your story,” I told her. I pointed out that nobody has enough facts—not even scholars of the Holocaust—to reconstruct her father’s early life; too much of the Jewish past in Europe has been obliterated. “If you write about your own search for your father’s past,” I said, “you’ll also tell the story of his life and his heritage.”

“这是你的故事，”我告诉她。我指出，没有人掌握足够的史料——即使是研究大屠杀的学者——来重构她父亲的早年生活；欧洲犹太人的历史大多已被抹去。“如果你写下你寻找父亲过往的经历，”我说，“你也将讲述他的人生故事和他的传承。”

I saw a heavy weight drop off her shoulders. She smiled a smile that none of us had seen before and said she would get started on the story right away.

我看到她肩上的重担一下子卸了下来。她露出了我们谁都没见过的笑容，说她马上就开始写这个故事。

The course ended and no paper was handed in. I called her and she said she was still writing and needed more time. Then, one day, a 24-page manuscript arrived in the mail. It was called “Returning Home,” and it described Helen Blatt’s pilgrimage to Plesna, a small rural town in southeastern Poland that wasn’t even on the map. “Sixty-five years later,” she wrote, “I was the first member of the Blatt family the town had seen since 1939.” Gradually making herself known to the townspeople, she found that many of her father’s relatives—grandparents and uncles and aunts—were still remembered. When one old man said, “You look just like your grandmother Helen,” she felt “an overwhelming sense of safety and peacefulness.”

课程结束了，但她没有交论文。我打电话给她，她说她还在写作，需要更多时间。然后有一天，她收到了一份24页的手稿。手稿名为《回家》，讲述了海伦·布拉特前往普莱斯纳的朝圣之旅。普莱斯纳是波兰东南部一个偏远的小镇，甚至在地图上都找不到。“六十五年后，”她写道，“我是自1939年以来，这个小镇见到的第一个布拉特家族成员。”她逐渐与镇民们熟识起来，发现她父亲的许多亲戚——祖父母、叔叔阿姨——仍然被人们记得。当一位老人说：“你长得真像你的祖母海伦”时，她感到“一种难以言喻的安全感和宁静”。

This is how her story ends:

她的故事就此结束：

After I returned home my father and I spent three straight days together. He watched every minute of the four-hour video I made as if it were a masterpiece. He wanted to hear every detail of my trip: who I met, where I went, what I saw, what foods I liked and disliked, and how I was treated. I assured him that I was welcomed with open arms. Although I still have no photos of my family telling me what their faces looked like, I now have a mental picture of their character. The fact that I was treated so well by complete strangers is a reflection of the respect my grandparents earned from the community. I gave my father boxes of letters and gifts from his old friends: Polish vodka and maps and framed photos and drawings of Plesna.

回家后，我和父亲整整三天都待在一起。他像欣赏一部杰作一样，一分钟一分钟地观看了我制作的四个小时的视频。他想知道我旅途中的每一个细节：我遇到了谁，去了哪里，看到了什么，喜欢什么食物，不喜欢什么食物，以及我受到了怎样的对待。我向他保证，我受到了热烈的欢迎。虽然我至今还没有家人的照片，无法辨认他们的长相，但我现在对他们的性格已经有了大致的印象。陌生人对我如此热情，正体现了我的祖父母在当地社区赢得的尊重。我把老朋友们寄来的信件和礼物都送给了父亲：波兰伏特加、地图，还有装裱起来的普莱斯纳的照片和素描。

As I told him my stories he looked like an excited child waiting to open his birthday present. The sadness in his eyes also disappeared; he looked jubilant and giddy. When he saw his family’s property on my video I expected to see him cry, and he did, but they were tears of joy. He seemed so proud, and I asked him, “Daddy, what are you looking at with such pride? Is it your house?” He said, “No, it’s you! You have become my eyes and ears and legs. Thank you for taking this trip. It makes me feel as if I’ve gone there myself.”

当我给他讲我的故事时，他就像个兴奋的孩子，等着拆生日礼物。他眼中的悲伤也消失了，取而代之的是欢欣雀跃。当他在我的视频里看到自家的房子时，我以为他会哭，他确实哭了，但那是喜悦的泪水。他看起来非常自豪，我问他：“爸爸，你这么自豪地看着什么呢？是你的房子吗？” 他说：“不，是你！你成了我的眼睛、耳朵和双腿。谢谢你陪我一起旅行。这让我感觉就像我自己也去了那里一样。”

My final reducing advice can be summed up in two words: Think small. Don’t rummage around in your past—or your family’s past—to find episodes that you think are “important” enough to be worthy of including in your memoir. Look for small self-contained incidents that are still vivid in your memory. If you still remember them it’s because they contain a universal truth that your readers will recognize from their own life.

我最后一条精简建议可以用两个字概括：从小处着手。不要在自己的过去——或者家族的过去——翻箱倒柜地寻找那些你认为“重要”到足以写进回忆录的片段。寻找那些在你记忆中依然鲜活的小事。如果你还记得它们，那是因为它们蕴含着某种普世真理，你的读者会在自己的生活中找到共鸣。

That turned out to be the main lesson I learned by writing a book in 2004 called Writing About Your Life . The book is a memoir of my own life, but along the way, I also pause to explain the reducing and organizing decisions I made. I never felt that my memoir had to include all the important things that ever happened to me—a common temptation when old people sit down to summarize their life journey. Many of the chapters in my memoir are about small episodes that were not objectively “important” but that were important to me . Because they were important to me they also struck an emotional chord with readers, touching a universal truth that was important to them .

这最终成为我在2004年创作《书写你的人生》一书时学到的最重要的一课。这本书是我自己的生活回忆录，但其中也穿插着我所做的精简和整理的决定。我从未觉得我的回忆录必须囊括我人生中所有重要的事件——这是老年人在总结人生历程时常犯的错误。我的回忆录中有很多章节讲述的是一些客观上并不“重要”的小事，但这些事对我来说却意义非凡。正因为它们对我而言如此重要，所以也触动了读者的情感，触及了他们心中某种普遍存在的真理。

One chapter is about a mechanical baseball game I played for thousands of hours with my boyhood friend Charlie Willis. The chapter begins by explaining that in 1983 I wrote an article in the New York Times describing that youthful obsession. I said that my mother must have thrown my game away when I went into the army. “But in the mists of memory I see the word WOLVERINE . What ‘Rosebud’ was to Citizen Kane, ‘Wolverine’ is to me—a clue almost irrecoverably faint. I mention it in case anyone finds the game in an attic or a basement or a garage. I can be there on the next plane—and so can Charlie Willis.”

其中一章讲的是我和儿时好友查理·威利斯一起玩了数千小时的一款机械棒球游戏。这一章开头解释说，1983年我在《纽约时报》上发表了一篇文章，描述了我年少时对这款游戏的痴迷。我说，我参军的时候，我母亲肯定把我的游戏扔掉了。“但在记忆的迷雾中，我隐约看到‘金刚狼’这个词。就像‘玫瑰花蕾’之于《公民凯恩》，‘金刚狼’之于我——一条几乎无法挽回的模糊线索。我提到它，是为了万一有人在阁楼、地下室或车库里发现了这款游戏。我可以搭下一班飞机过去——查理·威利斯也可以。”

It only took a few days for letters to arrive from other men who once owned the game and who recalled playing it incessantly with boyhood friends. The last one was postmarked Booneville, Arkansas, and I could hardly believe the return address: WOLVERINE TOY COMPANY . The letter was from William W. Lehren, vice president for sales. “We stopped making the ‘Pennant Winner’ in 1950,” he said, “but I dug around in our museum and found that we still had one. If you ever happen to be in this vicinity I’d love to take you on for a few games.”

没过几天，就收到了其他几位男士的来信，他们也都曾拥有过这款游戏，并回忆起小时候和朋友们没日没夜地玩这款游戏的情景。最后一封信的邮戳是阿肯色州布恩维尔，我简直不敢相信回信地址：金刚狼玩具公司。信是销售副总裁威廉·W·莱伦写的。“我们1950年就停产‘冠军牌’游戏了，”他说，“但我翻遍了我们的博物馆，发现我们还有一套。如果你有机会路过附近，我很乐意请你玩几局。”

I never made it to Booneville, but in 1999 Bill Lehren retired to Connecticut, and one day he gave me a call. He said he had bought that last “Pennant Winner” from Wolverine and he wanted to know if I was still up for a game. A few days later he came to my office in New York and unwrapped the game I hadn’t seen in more than 60 years.

我一直没能去布恩维尔，但1999年比尔·莱伦退休搬到康涅狄格州后，有一天他给我打了个电话。他说他从金刚狼队买下了最后一张“冠军赛”卡，问我是否还想玩。几天后，他来到我在纽约的办公室，拆开了那张我六十多年没见过的卡。

It was a thing of beauty, and as I gazed upon its shiny green metallic infield I could still feel in my fingertips the bat as I used to hold it back on its tightly coiled spring, waiting for the pitch. I could also feel the “fast” and “slow” buttons, one on each side, that delivered the pitch at various speeds. Bill and I lifted the game down onto the rug and went to work—two men in their seventies kneeling at opposite ends and getting up every half-inning to change sides. Outside, the sun went down and the sky over Lexington Avenue turned dark. But we didn’t notice.

那真是一件精美的物件。我凝视着它闪亮的绿色金属内场，指尖仿佛还能感受到球棒的触感，就像我以前握着它，紧紧地扣在弹簧上，等待投手投球一样。我还能感觉到球棒两侧的“快”和“慢”按钮，它们可以控制球速。我和比尔把游戏搬到地毯上，开始玩了起来——两个七十多岁的老人跪在游戏的两端，每半局就起身交换位置。外面，太阳落山了，莱克星顿大道上空的天空渐渐暗了下来。但我们浑然不觉。

That’s a highly specialized subject for a piece of writing; not many people owned a mechanical baseball game. But everybody had a favorite childhood toy or game or doll. The fact that I had such a toy, and that it was brought back to me at the other end of my life, can’t help connecting with readers who would like to hold their favorite toy or game or doll one more time. They don’t identify with my baseball game; they identify with the idea of the game—a universal idea. Remember this when you write your memoir and worry that your story isn’t big enough to interest anyone else. The small stories that still stick in your memory have a resonance of their own. Trust them.

那是一个非常小众的写作题材；拥有机械棒球游戏的人并不多。但每个人都有自己童年时最喜欢的玩具、游戏或玩偶。我拥有这样一款玩具，而且它在我生命的尽头又回到了我身边，这无疑会与那些想要再次拥有自己心爱玩具、游戏或玩偶的读者产生共鸣。他们并非认同我的棒球游戏本身，而是认同游戏所代表的理念——一种普世的理念。当你撰写回忆录，担心自己的故事不够精彩而无法引起他人兴趣时，请记住这一点。那些至今仍留在你记忆中的小故事，自有其独特的魅力。相信它们。

Another chapter in Writing About Your Life is about serving in the army in World War II. Like most men of my generation, I recall that war as the pivotal experience of my life. But in my memoir I don’t write anything about the war itself. I just tell one story about one trip I took across North Africa after our troopship landed at Casablanca. My fellow GIs and I were put on a train consisting of decrepit wooden boxcars called “forty-and-eights,” so named because they were first used by the French in World War I to transport forty men or eight horses. The words QUARANTE HOMMES OU HUIT CHEVAUX were still stenciled on them.

《书写你的人生》的另一章讲述了我在二战期间的军旅生涯。和同龄的大多数人一样，我把那场战争视为我人生的转折点。但在我的回忆录中，我并没有写到战争本身。我只是讲述了一个故事：我们的运兵船在卡萨布兰卡登陆后，我乘坐火车穿越北非。我和我的战友们被安排在一列由破旧木制车厢组成的火车上，这种车厢被称为“四十八节车厢”，之所以这样命名，是因为法国人在一战期间首次使用这种车厢来运送四十名士兵或八匹马。车厢上仍然印着“四十人或八匹马”的字样。

For six days I sat in the open door of that boxcar with my feet hanging out over Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia. It was the most uncomfortable ride I ever took—and the best. I couldn’t believe I was in North Africa. I was the sheltered son of Northeastern WASPs; nobody in my upbringing or my education had ever mentioned the Arabs. Now, suddenly, I was in a landscape where everything was new—every sight and sound and smell. The eight months I would spend in that exotic land were the start of a romance that has never cooled. They would make me a lifelong traveler to Africa and Asia and other remote cultures and would forever change how I thought about the world.

整整六天，我坐在敞开的货车车厢门上，双脚悬在窗外，俯瞰着摩洛哥、阿尔及利亚和突尼斯。那是我经历过的最不舒服的旅程——也是最棒的旅程。我简直不敢相信自己身处北非。我来自美国东北部，父母都是盎格鲁-撒克逊新教徒，从小到大，我的教育中从未有人提及阿拉伯人。而现在，我突然置身于一片全新的土地——所有的一切都是那么新鲜——每一处景象、每一声响、每一缕气味。我在那片异域土地上度过的八个月，开启了一段至今未曾冷却的浪漫之旅。这段经历让我终生热爱旅行，足迹遍布非洲、亚洲和其他遥远的文化，也永远改变了我对世界的看法。

Remember: Your biggest stories will often have less to do with their subject than with their significance—not what you did in a certain situation, but how that situation affected you and shaped the person you became.

记住：你最伟大的故事往往与故事的主题关系不大，而与故事的意义关系更大——不是你在某个特定情况下做了什么，而是那个情况如何影响了你，塑造了你成为怎样的人。

As for how to actually put your memoir together, my final advice is—again—think small. Tackle your life in manageable chunks. Don’t visualize the finished product: the grand edifice you have vowed to construct. That will only make you anxious.

至于如何真正着手撰写回忆录，我最后的建议是——再次强调——从小处着手。把你的人生分成一个个易于处理的小块。不要去想象最终的成品：你立志要构建的宏伟大厦。那样只会让你焦虑不安。

Here’s what I suggest.

我的建议是这样的。

Go to your desk on Monday morning and write about some event that’s still vivid in your memory. It doesn’t have to be long—three pages, five pages—but it should have a beginning and an end. Put that episode in a folder and get on with your life. On Tuesday morning, do the same thing. Tuesday’s episode doesn’t have to be related to Monday’s episode. Take whatever memory comes calling; your subconscious mind, having been put to work, will start delivering your past.

周一早上，坐在书桌前，写下一件你记忆犹新的事。不必长篇大论——三页、五页都行——但一定要有开头和结尾。把这件事记下来，放进文件夹里，然后继续你的生活。周二早上，重复同样的步骤。周二的事件不必与周一的事件相关。随心所欲地回忆，你的潜意识在被调动起来之后，会开始梳理你的过往。

Keep this up for two months, or three months, or six months. Don’t be impatient to start writing your “memoir”—the one you had in mind before you began. Then, one day, take all your entries out of their folder and spread them on the floor. (The floor is often a writer’s best friend.) Read them through and see what they tell you and what patterns emerge. They will tell you what your memoir is about—and what it’s not about. They will tell you what’s primary and what’s secondary, what’s interesting and what’s not, what’s emotional, what’s important, what’s unusual, what’s funny, what’s worth pursuing and expanding. You’ll begin to glimpse your story’s narrative shape and the road you want to take.

坚持这样做两个月、三个月，甚至六个月。不要急于开始写你的“回忆录”——就是你开始写作之前就构思好的那部。然后，有一天，把所有写好的片段从文件夹里拿出来，摊在地板上。（地板往往是作家的好朋友。）通读一遍，看看它们告诉你什么，从中发现了什么模式。它们会告诉你你的回忆录是关于什么的——以及它不是关于什么的。它们会告诉你什么是主要的，什么是次要的；什么是有趣的，什么是无趣的；什么是感人的；什么是重要的；什么是不同寻常的；什么是有趣的；什么是值得深入挖掘和拓展的。你会开始看到故事的叙事结构，以及你想要走的路。

Then all you have to do is put the pieces together.

然后你只需要把这些部件组装起来就行了。

#↩

25

Write as Well as You Can

尽你所能写好

I’m occasionally asked if I can recall the moment when I knew I wanted to be a writer. No such blinding flash occurred; I only knew that I thought I would like to work for a newspaper. But I can point to a set of attitudes that I inherited early in life and that have guided me ever since. They came from both sides of my family, by different routes.

我偶尔会被问到是否还记得自己何时意识到想成为一名作家。其实并没有那种灵光乍现的时刻；我只知道自己想为报社工作。但我可以指出，我从小就继承了一些人生态度，这些态度一直指引着我。它们来自我家族的双方，途径不同。

My mother loved good writing, and she found it as often in newspapers as she did in books. She regularly clipped columns and articles out of the paper that delighted her with their graceful use of language, or their wit, or their original vision of life. Because of her I knew at an early age that good writing can appear anywhere, even in the lowly newspaper, and that what matters is the writing itself, not the medium where it’s published. Therefore I’ve always tried to write as well as I could by my own standards; I’ve never changed my style to fit the size or the presumed education of the audience I was writing for. My mother was also a woman of humor and optimism. These are lubricants in writing, as they are in life, and a writer lucky enough to have them in his baggage will start the day with an extra round of confidence.

我的母亲热爱优秀的文字，她发现报纸和书籍一样多。她经常剪下报纸上那些令她赏心悦目的专栏文章，或是那些语言优美、妙语连珠、或是独具匠心的人生观。正因为如此，我从小就知道，好的文字可以出现在任何地方，即使是不起眼的报纸上，而真正重要的是文字本身，而不是发表的媒介。因此，我一直努力按照自己的标准写出最好的文章；我从未为了迎合读者的规模或假定的教育水平而改变自己的风格。我的母亲也是一位幽默乐观的人。正如它们在生活中一样，它们也是写作的润滑剂，一个幸运地拥有这些品质的作家，每天都会充满自信地开始新的一天。

Originally I wasn’t meant to be a writer. My father was a businessman. His grandfather had come from Germany in the great immigration of 1848 with a formula for making shellac. He built a small house and factory in a rocky field far uptown in Manhattan—at what is now 59th Street and Tenth Avenue—and started a business called William Zinsser & Company. I still have a photograph of that pastoral scene; the land slopes down toward the Hudson River, and the only living creature is a goat. The firm stayed at that location until 1973, when it moved to New Jersey.

我原本并非注定要成为作家。我的父亲是一位商人。他的祖父在1848年的大移民潮中从德国来到美国，并带来了制作虫胶的配方。他在曼哈顿北部一片岩石遍布的田野上——也就是现在的第五十九街和第十大道交汇处——建造了一座小房子和工厂，并创办了威廉·津瑟公司（William Zinsser & Company）。我至今还保存着一张当时田园风光的照片：地势向哈德逊河倾斜，唯一的活物是一只山羊。公司一直在那里经营到1973年，之后搬迁到了新泽西州。

For a business to remain in the same family on the same Manhattan block for more than a century is rare, and as a boy I couldn’t escape the naggings of continuity, for I was the fourth William Zinsser and the only son; my father’s fate was to have three daughters first. In those Dark Ages the idea that daughters could run a business as well as sons, or better, was still two decades off. My father was a man who loved his business. When he talked about it I never felt that he regarded it as a venture for making money; it was an art, to be practiced with imagination and only the best materials. He had a passion for quality and had no patience with the second-rate; he never went into a store looking for a bargain. He charged more for his product because he made it with the best ingredients, and his company prospered. It was a ready-made future for me, and my father looked forward to the day when I would join him.

一个家族企业能在曼哈顿同一街区经营一个多世纪实属罕见。从小我就深受家族传承的困扰，因为我是第四代威廉·津瑟，也是家中唯一的儿子；我父亲的命运是先有了三个女儿。在那个年代，女儿能像儿子一样经营企业，甚至做得更好，这种观念还远未普及。我父亲热爱他的事业。他谈起生意来，我从没觉得他把它当成赚钱的工具；在他眼里，那是一门艺术，需要用心去构思，并且只选用最好的材料。他对品质有着近乎狂热的追求，对劣质产品毫无耐心；他从不去商店寻便宜货。他坚持使用最好的原料，所以产品定价更高，而他的公司也因此蒸蒸日上。这对我来说，仿佛是一条现成的未来之路，我父亲也一直盼望着我能加入他的事业。

But inevitably a different day arrived, and not long after I came home from the war I went to work for the New York Herald Tribune and had to tell my father I wasn’t going to carry on the family business. He accepted the news with his usual generosity and wished me well in my chosen field. No boy or girl could receive a finer gift. I was liberated from having to fulfill somebody else’s expectations, which were not the right ones for me. I was free to succeed or fail on my own terms.

但终究还是迎来了不同的日子。战后不久，我回到家乡，便进入《纽约先驱论坛报》工作，不得不告诉父亲我不会继承家业。他一如既往地宽容大度地接受了这个消息，并祝愿我在自己选择的领域一切顺利。这对我来说是莫大的恩赐。我终于摆脱了必须满足他人期望的束缚，那些期望并不适合我。我可以自由地按照自己的方式去面对成功或失败。

Only later did I realize that I took along on my journey another gift from my father: a bone-deep belief that quality is its own reward. I, too, have never gone into a store looking for a bargain. Although my mother was the literary one in our family—magpie collector of books, lover of the English language, writer of dazzling letters—it was from the world of business that I absorbed my craftsman’s ethic, and over the years, when I found myself endlessly rewriting what I had endlessly rewritten, determined to write better than everybody who was competing for the same space, the inner voice I was hearing was the voice of my father talking about shellac.

后来我才意识到，我人生旅途中还带着父亲留给我的另一份礼物：一种根深蒂固的信念——品质本身就是一种回报。我也从未走进商店寻觅便宜货。虽然我母亲是我们家的文学爱好者——她像喜鹊一样收集书籍，热爱英语，写出过许多精彩绝伦的信件——但我却是在商业世界中汲取了工匠精神。多年来，当我发现自己一遍又一遍地修改着那些已经修改过无数遍的作品，决心要写得比所有争夺同一版面的人都好时，我内心听到的声音，正是父亲谈论虫胶时的声音。

Besides wanting to write as well as possible, I wanted to write as entertainingly as possible. When I tell aspiring writers that they should think of themselves as part entertainer, they don’t like to hear it—the word smacks of carnivals and jugglers and clowns. But to succeed you must make your piece jump out of a newspaper or a magazine by being more diverting than everyone else’s piece. You must find some way to elevate your act of writing into an entertainment. Usually this means giving the reader an enjoyable surprise. Any number of devices will do the job: humor, anecdote, paradox, an unexpected quotation, a powerful fact, an outlandish detail, a circuitous approach, an elegant arrangement of words. These seeming amusements in fact become your “style.” When we say we like the style of certain writers, what we mean is that we like their personality as they express it on paper. Given a choice between two traveling companions—and a writer is someone who asks us to travel with him—we usually choose the one who we think will make an effort to brighten the trip.

除了想写出尽可能好的文章，我还想写出尽可能引人入胜的文章。当我告诉那些有抱负的作家，他们应该把自己看作是半个娱乐者时，他们并不喜欢听——这个词听起来就像嘉年华、杂耍艺人和小丑。但要想成功，你必须让你的文章从报纸或杂志上脱颖而出，比其他所有人的文章都更具娱乐性。你必须找到某种方法，将你的写作行为提升为一种娱乐。通常这意味着给读者带来令人愉悦的惊喜。许多技巧都能做到这一点：幽默、轶事、悖论、出人意料的引语、有力的事实、奇特的细节、迂回的叙述方式、优雅的文字安排。这些看似有趣的技巧实际上会成为你的“风格”。当我们说我们喜欢某些作家的风格时，我们指的是我们喜欢他们通过文字表达的个性。如果要在两个旅行伙伴之间做出选择——而作家就是那种会邀请我们和他一起旅行的人——我们通常会选择我们认为会努力让旅途变得有趣的那个人。

Unlike medicine or the other sciences, writing has no new discoveries to spring on us. We’re in no danger of reading in our morning newspaper that a breakthrough has been made in how to write a clear English sentence—that information has been around since the King James Bible. We know that verbs have more vigor than nouns, that active verbs are better than passive verbs, that short words and sentences are easier to read than long ones, that concrete details are easier to process than vague abstractions.

与医学或其他科学领域不同，写作领域并没有什么新的发现会突然出现。我们不用担心会在晨报上读到关于如何写出清晰英语句子的突破性进展——这些信息早在《钦定版圣经》时期就已存在。我们知道动词比名词更有力，主动语态比被动语态更好，短词短句比长词短句更容易阅读，具体细节比抽象概念更容易理解。

Obviously the rules have often been bent. Victorian writers had a taste for the ornate and didn’t consider brevity a virtue, and many modern writers, like Tom Wolfe, have broken out of the cage, turning a headlong exuberance of language into a source of positive energy. Such skillful acrobats, however, are rare; most nonfiction writers will do well to cling to the ropes of simplicity and clarity. We may be given new technologies like the computer to ease the burdens of composition, but on the whole we know what we need to know. We’re all working with the same words and the same principles.

显然，规则常常被打破。维多利亚时代的作家崇尚华丽辞藻，并不认为简洁是一种美德；许多现代作家，例如汤姆·沃尔夫，更是打破了束缚，将语言的奔放热情转化为积极能量的源泉。然而，这种技艺精湛的作家凤毛麟角；大多数非虚构作家最好还是坚守简洁明了的原则。我们或许会借助计算机等新技术来减轻写作的负担，但总的来说，我们已经掌握了所需的知识。我们都在使用同样的词汇，遵循同样的原则。

Where, then, is the edge? Ninety percent of the answer lies in the hard work of mastering the tools discussed in this book. Add a few points for such natural gifts as a good musical ear, a sense of rhythm and a feeling for words. But the final advantage is the same one that applies in every other competitive venture. If you would like to write better than everybody else, you have to want to write better than everybody else. You must take an obsessive pride in the smallest details of your craft. And you must be willing to defend what you’ve written against the various middlemen—editors, agents and publishers—whose sights may be different from yours, whose standards not as high. Too many writers are browbeaten into settling for less than their best.

那么，优势究竟在哪里呢？答案的九成在于努力掌握本书所讨论的各种技巧。拥有良好的乐感、节奏感和文字感等天赋也能加分。但最终的优势与其他所有竞争领域一样：如果你想写得比别人好，就必须渴望写得比别人好。你必须对作品的每一个细节都精益求精，甚至到了痴迷的地步。而且，你必须勇于捍卫自己的作品，对抗那些与你目标不同、标准可能不如你高的中间人——编辑、经纪人和出版商。太多作家被迫妥协，最终只能写出低于自己最佳水平的作品。

I’ve always felt that my “style”—the careful projection onto paper of who I think I am—is my main marketable asset, the one possession that might set me apart from other writers. Therefore I’ve never wanted anyone to tinker with it, and after I submit an article I protect it fiercely. Several magazine editors have told me I’m the only writer they know who cares what happens to his piece after he gets paid for it. Most writers won’t argue with an editor because they don’t want to annoy him; they’re so grateful to be published that they agree to having their style—in other words, their personality—violated in public.

我一直觉得我的“风格”——也就是我精心构思并呈现在纸上的自我形象——是我最重要的卖点，也是我区别于其他作家的唯一优势。因此，我从不希望任何人随意改动它，文章投稿后我会竭力保护它。好几位杂志编辑都告诉我，我是他们认识的唯一一个在稿费到手后还关心作品命运的作家。大多数作家不会跟编辑争论，因为他们不想惹恼编辑；他们感激作品能够发表，所以甘愿让自己的风格——换句话说，就是他们的个性——在公众面前被随意践踏。

Yet to defend what you’ve written is a sign that you are alive. I’m a known crank on this issue—I fight over every semicolon. But editors put up with me because they can see that I’m serious. In fact, my crankiness has brought me more work than it has driven away. Editors with an unusual assignment often thought of me because they knew I would do it with unusual care. They also knew they would get the article on time and that it would be accurate. Remember that the craft of nonfiction writing involves more than writing. It also means being reliable. Editors will properly drop a writer they can’t count on.

然而，捍卫自己写的东西恰恰表明你还活着。在这个问题上，我出了名的固执——我甚至会为每一个分号据理力争。但编辑们容忍我，因为他们看得出我是认真的。事实上，我的固执反而给我带来了更多的工作机会。那些接到特殊任务的编辑常常会想到我，因为他们知道我会格外认真负责地完成。他们也知道文章会按时交付，而且准确无误。记住，非虚构写作的技艺远不止于写作本身，它还意味着可靠性。编辑们会毫不犹豫地放弃一个他们无法信任的作者。

Which brings us to editors. Are they friends or enemies—gods who save us from our sins or bums who trample on our poetic souls? Like the rest of creation, they come in all varieties. I think with gratitude of a half-dozen editors who sharpened my writing by changing its focus or emphasis, or questioning its tone, or detecting weaknesses of logic or structure, or suggesting a different lead, or letting me talk a problem through with them when I couldn’t decide between several routes, or cutting various forms of excess. Twice I threw out an entire chapter of a book because editors told me it was unnecessary. But above all I remember those good editors for their generosity. They had an enthusiasm for whatever project we were trying to bring off together as writer and editor. Their confidence that I could make it work kept me going.

这就引出了编辑的话题。他们是朋友还是敌人？是拯救我们脱离罪恶的神明，还是践踏我们诗意灵魂的恶棍？如同世间万物，他们形形色色。我由衷地感谢六位编辑，他们通过改变文章的焦点或重点、质疑文章的语气、指出逻辑或结构上的漏洞、提出不同的开头建议、在我犹豫不决时耐心倾听我的想法、以及删减各种冗余内容，使我的文章更加精炼。我曾两次因为编辑认为某些章节不必要而将其全部删除。但最令我难忘的，是这些优秀编辑的慷慨。无论我们作为作者还是编辑共同努力完成什么项目，他们都充满热情。他们对我的信心，相信我能成功，正是这份信心支撑着我不断前行。

What a good editor brings to a piece of writing is an objective eye that the writer has long since lost, and there is no end of ways in which an editor can improve a manuscript: pruning, shaping, clarifying, tidying a hundred inconsistencies of tense and pronoun and location and tone, noticing all the sentences that could be read in two different ways, dividing awkward long sentences into short ones, putting the writer back on the main road if he has strayed down a side path, building bridges where the writer has lost the reader by not paying attention to his transitions, questioning matters of judgment and taste. An editor’s hand must also be invisible. Whatever he adds in his own words shouldn’t sound like his own words; they should sound like the writer’s words.

一位优秀的编辑能为文章带来作者早已失去的客观视角。编辑能从方方面面改进稿件：精简、润色、澄清、修正时态、人称代词、位置和语气上的诸多不一致之处；注意到所有可以有两种不同解读的句子；将冗长的句子拆分成短句；如果作者偏离了正轨，则将其拉回正轨；在作者因疏忽过渡而导致读者难以理解的地方搭建桥梁；质疑作者的判断和品味。编辑的介入必须做到“隐形”。他添加的任何文字都不应带有他自己的风格，而应与作者的文字浑然一体。

For all these acts of salvation, editors can’t be thanked fervently enough. Unfortunately, they can also do considerable harm. In general the damage takes two forms: altering style and altering content. Let’s look at style first.

对于编辑们所做的这些拯救之举，我们怎么感谢都不为过。然而不幸的是，他们有时也会造成相当大的损害。这种损害通常体现在两个方面：改变风格和改变内容。我们先来看风格方面。

A good editor likes nothing better than a piece of copy he hardly has to touch. A bad editor has a compulsion to tinker, proving with busywork that he hasn’t forgotten the minutiae of grammar and usage. He is a literal fellow, catching cracks in the road but not enjoying the scenery. Very often it simply doesn’t occur to him that a writer is writing by ear, trying to achieve a particular sound or cadence, or playing with words just for the pleasures of wordplay. One of the bleakest moments for writers is the one when they realize that their editor has missed the point of what they are trying to do.

优秀的编辑最喜欢的就是几乎不用改动的稿件。而糟糕的编辑则总爱刨根问底，用繁琐的修改来证明自己没有忘记语法和用法的细枝末节。他就像个拘泥于字面意思的人，只盯着路上的裂缝，却忽略了沿途的风景。很多时候，他根本意识不到作者是在凭感觉写作，努力追求某种特定的音韵或节奏，或者只是为了文字游戏而玩味文字。对作者来说，最沮丧的时刻之一莫过于意识到自己的编辑完全没理解他们的创作意图。

I remember many such dismal revelations. A minor one that comes to mind involved an article I wrote about a program called Visiting Artists, which brought artists and musicians to a group of economically depressed Midwestern cities. Describing them, I wrote: “They don’t look like cities that get visited by many visiting artists.” When the galleys came back the sentence said: “They don’t look like cities that are on the itinerary of many visiting artists.” A small point? Not to me. I had used repetition because it’s a device I like—it takes readers by surprise and refreshes them in midsentence. But the editor remembered the rule about substituting synonyms for words that are repeated, and he corrected my error. When I called to protest, he was amazed. We argued for a long time, neither of us yielding. Finally he said, “You really feel strongly about this, don’t you?” I feel strongly that one such erosion leads to another and that the writer must take a stand. I’ve even bought articles back from magazines that made changes I wouldn’t accept. If you allow your distinctiveness to be edited out, you will lose one of your main virtues. You will also lose your virtue.

我记得很多类似的令人沮丧的发现。其中一个不太明显的例子，是我写的一篇关于“艺术家访问计划”的文章，该计划将艺术家和音乐家带到中西部一些经济萧条的城市。在描述这些城市时，我写道：“它们看起来不像有很多艺术家会来的城市。” 校样返回后，这句话变成了：“它们看起来不像很多艺术家会去的城市。” 这点小错误？对我来说可不是。我用了重复，因为我喜欢这种修辞手法——它能让读者感到意外，并在阅读过程中让他们重新想起某个句子。但编辑记得要用同义词替换重复的词语，于是他纠正了我的错误。当我打电话抗议时，他很惊讶。我们争论了很久，谁也不肯让步。最后他说：“你对这件事真的很在意，是吗？” 我强烈地认为，这种错误会引发更多的错误，作家必须表明立场。我甚至还从杂志社买回过一些文章，因为他们做了我无法接受的修改。如果你允许自己的独特之处被抹杀，你就会失去一项最重要的美德，也会失去你的美德本身。

Ideally the relationship between a writer and an editor should be one of negotiation and trust. Frequently an editor will make a change to clarify a muddy sentence and will inadvertently lose an important point—a fact or a nuance that the writer included for reasons the editor didn’t know about. In such cases the writer should ask to have his point back. The editor, if he agrees, should oblige. But he should also insist on his right to fix whatever had been unclear. Clarity is what every editor owes the reader. An editor should never allow something to get into print that he doesn’t understand. If he doesn’t understand it, at least one other person won’t, and that’s one too many. The process, in short, is one in which the writer and the editor proceed through the manuscript together, finding for every problem the solution that best serves the finished article.

理想情况下，作者和编辑之间的关系应该是协商和信任的。编辑经常会为了澄清晦涩的句子而进行修改，却无意中遗漏了重要的信息——作者出于编辑不知情的原因而添加的事实或细微差别。在这种情况下，作者应该要求恢复这些信息。如果编辑同意，就应该照办。但他也应该坚持自己有权修改任何不清晰的内容。清晰明了是每位编辑对读者应尽的义务。编辑绝不应该允许自己不理解的内容付梓。如果他自己都不理解，至少还会有一个人不理解，这太多了。简而言之，整个过程就是作者和编辑共同审阅稿件，为每个问题找到最有利于最终成文的解决方案。

It’s a process that can be done just as well over the phone as in person. Don’t let editors use distance or their own disarray as an excuse for altering your work without your consent. “We were on deadline,” “we were already late,” “the person who usually deals with you was out sick,” “we had a big shake-up here last week,” “our new publisher has just come on board,” “it got put in the wrong pile,” “the editor’s on vacation”—these dreary phrases cloak a multitude of inefficiencies and sins. One unpleasant change in the publishing profession has been the erosion of courtesies that were once routine. Magazine editors, especially, have become cavalier about a whole series of procedures that should be automatic: notifying the writer that the piece has arrived, reading it with reasonable speed, telling the writer whether it’s O.K., returning it immediately if it’s not, working supportively with the writer if the piece needs changes, sending the writer galley proofs, seeing that the writer gets paid promptly. Writers are vulnerable enough without being put through the repeated indignities of calling to learn the status of their article and to beg for their money.

这个过程完全可以通过电话完成，就像当面沟通一样。不要让编辑以距离或自身混乱为借口，未经你同意就修改你的作品。“我们赶截稿日期了”、“我们已经迟交了”、“平时负责对接的人生病了”、“我们上周人事变动很大”、“我们的新出版商刚上任”、“稿件放错堆了”、“编辑休假了”——这些令人沮丧的借口掩盖了诸多低效和错误。出版业一个令人不快的变化就是曾经习以为常的礼貌逐渐消失。杂志编辑尤其对一系列本应自动化的流程变得漫不经心：通知作者稿件已收到、以合理的速度阅读稿件、告知作者稿件是否合格、如果不合格立即退回、在稿件需要修改时给予作者支持、发送校样、确保作者及时收到稿费。作者本就脆弱，不应该再让他们经历反复打电话询问稿件状态和乞求稿费的屈辱。

The prevailing notion is that such “courtesies” are merely frills and can therefore be dismissed. On the contrary, they are organic to the craft. They are the code of honor that anchors the whole enterprise, and editors who forget them are toying with nothing less than the writer’s fundamental rights.

人们普遍认为，这些“礼节”不过是锦上添花，可以忽略不计。然而恰恰相反，它们是写作这门技艺不可或缺的一部分。它们是维系整个写作事业的荣誉准则，而那些忘记遵守这些准则的编辑，无异于在玩弄作者的基本权利。

This arrogance is at its most injurious when an editor goes beyond changes of style or structure and enters the sacred realm of content. I often hear freelance writers say, “When I got the magazine I looked for my article and I didn’t even recognize it. They had written a whole new lead and had me saying things that aren’t what I believe.” That’s the cardinal sin—tampering with a writer’s opinions. But editors will do what writers allow them to do, especially if time is short. Writers conspire in their own humiliation, allowing their piece to be rewritten by an editor to serve his own purposes. With every surrender they remind editors that they can be treated like hired help.

这种傲慢最伤人的地方在于，当编辑越过风格或结构的改变，闯入神圣的内容领域时。我经常听到自由撰稿人抱怨：“我拿到杂志后，找到自己的文章，却完全认不出来了。他们重新写了个开头，让我说了一些我根本不认同的话。” 这就是大忌——篡改作者的观点。但编辑往往会按照作者允许的方式行事，尤其是在时间紧迫的情况下。作者们自甘堕落，任由编辑为了自身利益而改写自己的作品。每一次妥协，他们都在提醒编辑，自己也可以被当作雇工对待。

But finally the purposes that writers serve must be their own. What you write is yours and nobody else’s. Take your talent as far as you can and guard it with your life. Only you know how far that is; no editor knows. Writing well means believing in your writing and believing in yourself, taking risks, daring to be different, pushing yourself to excel. You will write only as well as you make yourself write.

但归根结底，写作的目的必须由作者自己决定。你写的东西只属于你，与他人无关。尽你所能发挥你的才华，并像守护生命一样守护它。只有你自己知道你的才华能发挥到什么程度；任何编辑都无从知晓。写好文章意味着相信你的作品，相信你自己，敢于冒险，敢于与众不同，不断鞭策自己追求卓越。只有你让自己写得好，你才能写出好文章。

My favorite definition of a careful writer comes from Joe DiMaggio, though he didn’t know that’s what he was defining. DiMaggio was the greatest player I ever saw, and nobody looked more relaxed. He covered vast distances in the outfield, moving in graceful strides, always arriving ahead of the ball, making the hardest catch look routine, and even when he was at bat, hitting the ball with tremendous power, he didn’t appear to be exerting himself. I marveled at how effortless he looked because what he did could only be achieved by great daily effort. A reporter once asked him how he managed to play so well so consistently, and he said: “I always thought that there was at least one person in the stands who had never seen me play, and I didn’t want to let him down.”

我最喜欢的关于“谨慎写作”的定义来自乔·迪马乔，尽管他本人可能并不知道自己是在定义这个概念。迪马乔是我见过的最伟大的球员，而且他看起来总是那么轻松自如。他在外野奔跑时覆盖了广阔的距离，步伐优雅，总是能抢在球之前到达，即使是最难的接球也显得轻而易举。即使在打击时，他挥棒击球的力量惊人，却也丝毫没有吃力。我惊叹于他如此轻松自如的姿态，因为他所取得的成就只能通过日复一日的刻苦训练才能获得。一位记者曾问他如何才能保持如此稳定的高水平发挥，他回答说：“我总觉得看台上至少有一个人从未看过我打球，我不想让他失望。”

#↩

#↩

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

关于作者

W ILLIAM Z INSSER is a writer, editor and teacher. He began his career with the New York Herald Tribune and has been a longtime contributor to leading magazines. His 17 books include Writing to Learn; Mitchell & Ruff; Spring Training; American Places; Easy to Remember: The Great American Songwriters and Their Songs; and most recently Writing About Your Life . During the 1970s he taught writing at Yale, where he was master of Branford College. He now teaches at the New School, in New York, his hometown, and at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

威廉·津瑟是一位作家、编辑和教师。他的职业生涯始于《纽约先驱论坛报》，并长期为多家知名杂志撰稿。他著有17本书，包括《写作学习》、《米切尔与拉夫》、《春季训练》、《美国风土人情》、《易于记忆：伟大的美国歌曲作家及其歌曲》以及最近出版的《书写你的人生》。20世纪70年代，他曾在耶鲁大学教授写作，并担任布兰福德学院院长。如今，他在家乡纽约的新学院和哥伦比亚大学新闻研究生院任教。

Visit www.AuthorTracker.com for exclusive information on your favorite HarperCollins authors.

访问 www.AuthorTracker.com 获取您最喜爱的哈珀柯林斯出版社作者的独家信息。

#↩
